title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> </div></th><td>1236</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;Coronation of King <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">Mindaugas</a> </div></th><td>6 July 1253</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Union_of_Krewo" title="Union of Krewo">Union with Poland</a> </div></th><td>2 February 1386</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish&#8211;Lithuanian<br/>Commonwealth</a> created </div></th><td>1 July 1569</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">Partitions of the Commonwealth</a> </div></th><td>24 October 1795</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">Independence declared</a></span> </div></th><td>16 February 1918</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">1st Soviet occupation</a> </div></th><td>15 June 1940</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<span class="nowrap"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Lithuania_by_Nazi_Germany" title="Occupation of Lithuania by Nazi Germany">Nazi German occupation</a></span> </div></th><td>22 June 1941</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1944)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1944)">2nd Soviet occupation</a> </div></th><td>July 1944</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">Independence restored</a> </div></th><td>11 March 1990</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_711" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 711">Admitted</a> to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> </div></th><td>17 September 1991</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_NATO" title="Enlargement of NATO">Admitted</a> to <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a></span> </div></th><td>29 March 2004</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">Joined</a> the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a></span> </div></th><td>1 May 2004</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">\n</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Lithuania" title="Geography of Lithuania">Area </a></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;Total</div></th><td>65,300&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (25,200&#160;sq&#160;mi) (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">121st</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;Water&#160;(%)</div></th><td>1.35</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em; font-size:90%;">\n<li value="1">Also <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">.eu</a>, shared with other European Union member states.</li>\n</ol></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Lithuania&amp;params=55_N_24_E_region:LT_type:country"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">55&#176;N</span> <span class="longitude">24&#176;E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">&#65279; / &#65279;</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">55&#176;N 24&#176;E</span><span style="display:none">&#65279; / <span class="geo">55; 24</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>\n</p><p><b>Lithuania</b> (<span class="nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/&#716;/: secondary stress follows">&#716;</span><span title="\'l\' in \'lie\'">l</span><span title="/&#618;/: \'i\' in \'kit\'">&#618;</span><span title="/&#952;j/: \'th\' in \'enthuse\'">&#952;j</span><span title="/u/: \'u\' in \'influence\'">u</span><span title="/&#712;/: primary stress follows">&#712;</span><span title="/e&#618;/: \'a\' in \'face\'">e&#618;</span><span title="\'n\' in \'nigh\'">n</span><span title="/i/: \'y\' in \'happy\'">i</span><span title="/&#601;/: \'a\' in \'about\'">&#601;</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Lithuania.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/En-us-Lithuania.ogg" title="En-us-Lithuania.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>: <i lang="lt">Lietuva</i> <small></small><span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Lithuanian" title="Help:IPA/Lithuanian">[l&#690;&#618;&#603;t&#650;&#712;v&#592;]</a></span>), officially the <b>Republic of Lithuania</b> (Lithuanian: <i lang="lt">Lietuvos Respublika</i>), is a country in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_region" title="Baltic region">Baltic region</a> of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>. Since its independence, Lithuania is considered to be one of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic states</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-heritage_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-heritage-11">[11]</a></sup> It is situated along the southeastern shore of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, to the east of <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> and <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>. It is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> to the east and south, <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> to the south, and <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">Kaliningrad Oblast</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russian</a> <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">exclave</a>) to the southwest. Lithuania has an estimated population of 2.7 million people as of  2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, and its capital and largest city is <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>. Other major cities are <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaip&#279;da">Klaip&#279;da</a>. <a href="/wiki/Lithuanians" title="Lithuanians">Lithuanians</a> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_people" title="Baltic people">Baltic people</a>. The official language, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a>, is one of only two living languages in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">Baltic branch</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a> language family.\n</p><p>For centuries, the southeastern shores of the Baltic Sea were inhabited by various <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Baltic tribes</a>. In the 1230s, the Lithuanian lands were united by <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">Mindaugas</a>, the King of Lithuania, and the first unified Lithuanian state, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lithuania" title="Kingdom of Lithuania">Kingdom of Lithuania</a>, was created on 6 July 1253. During the 14th century, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> was the largest country in Europe; present-day Lithuania, Belarus, Ukraine, and parts of Poland and Russia were the territories of the Grand Duchy. With the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lublin_Union" title="Lublin Union">Lublin Union</a> of 1569, Lithuania and Poland formed a voluntary two-state <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>. The Commonwealth lasted more than two centuries, until neighbouring countries <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">systematically dismantled</a> it from 1772 to 1795, with the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> annexing most of Lithuania\'s territory.\n</p><p>As <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> neared its end, Lithuania\'s <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">Act of Independence</a> was signed on 16 February 1918, declaring the founding of the modern Republic of Lithuania. In the midst of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, Lithuania was first <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">occupied by the Soviet Union</a> and then by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Lithuania_by_Nazi_Germany" title="Occupation of Lithuania by Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. As World War II neared its end and the Germans retreated, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1944)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1944)">Soviet Union reoccupied Lithuania</a>. On 11 March 1990, a year before the formal <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, Lithuania became the first Baltic state<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> to declare itself independent, resulting in <a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">the restoration of an independent State of Lithuania</a>.\n</p><p>Lithuania is a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> and <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>. It is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">Nordic Investment Bank</a>, and part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NB8" title="NB8">Nordic-Baltic</a> cooperation of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">Northern European</a> countries. The United Nations <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> lists Lithuania as a "very high human development" country.\n</p>\n<div class="toc" id="toc"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctext">1939&#8211;1944</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-10"><a href="#1944&#8211;1990"><span class="tocnumber">2.5.3</span> <span class="toctext">1944&#8211;1990</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-11"><a href="#1990&#8211;present"><span class="tocnumber">2.5.4</span> <span class="toctext">1990&#8211;present</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Geography"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Geography</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-13"><a href="#Climate"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">Climate</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-14"><a href="#Environment"><span class="tocnumber">3.2</span> <span class="toctext">Environment</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-15"><a href="#Biodiversity"><span class="tocnumber">3.3</span> <span class="toctext">Biodiversity</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-16"><a href="#Politics"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Politics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-17"><a href="#Government"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Government</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-18"><a href="#Political_parties_and_elections"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Political parties and elections</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19"><a href="#Law_and_law_enforcement"><span class="tocnumber">4.3</span> <span class="toctext">Law and law enforcement</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Administrative_divisions"><span class="tocnumber">4.4</span> <span class="toctext">Administrative divisions</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21"><a href="#Foreign_relations"><span class="tocnumber">4.5</span> <span class="toctext">Foreign relations</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-22"><a href="#Military"><span class="tocnumber">4.6</span> <span class="toctext">Military</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-23"><a href="#Economy"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Economy</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-24"><a href="#Companies"><span class="tocnumber">5.1</span> <span class="toctext">Companies</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25"><a href="#Agriculture"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Agriculture</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26"><a href="#Science_and_technology"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Science and technology</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27"><a href="#Tourism"><span class="tocnumber">5.4</span> <span class="toctext">Tourism</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-28"><a href="#Infrastructure"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Infrastructure</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29"><a href="#Communication"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Communication</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-30"><a href="#Transport"><span class="tocnumber">6.2</span> <span class="toctext">Transport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-31"><a href="#Water_supply_and_sanitation"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">Water supply and sanitation</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32"><a href="#Energy"><span class="tocnumber">6.4</span> <span class="toctext">Energy</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-33"><a href="#Demographics"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Demographics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-34"><a href="#Ethnic_groups"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Ethnic groups</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-35"><a href="#Urbanization"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Urbanization</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-36"><a href="#Health"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Health</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-37"><a href="#Religion"><span class="tocnumber">7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Religion</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">7.5</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-39"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-40"><a href="#Lithuanian_language"><span class="tocnumber">8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Lithuanian language</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-41"><a href="#Literature"><span class="tocnumber">8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Literature</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-42"><a href="#Architecture"><span class="tocnumber">8.3</span> <span class="toctext">Architecture</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-43"><a href="#Arts_and_museums"><span class="tocnumber">8.4</span> <span class="toctext">Arts and museums</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-44"><a href="#Theatre"><span class="tocnumber">8.5</span> <span class="toctext">Theatre</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-45"><a href="#Cinema"><span class="tocnumber">8.6</span> <span class="toctext">Cinema</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-46"><a href="#Music"><span class="tocnumber">8.7</span> <span class="toctext">Music</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-47"><a href="#Rock_and_protest_music"><span class="tocnumber">8.7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Rock and protest music</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-48"><a href="#Cuisine"><span class="tocnumber">8.8</span> <span class="toctext">Cuisine</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-49"><a href="#Media"><span class="tocnumber">8.9</span> <span class="toctext">Media</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-50"><a href="#Public_holidays_and_festivals"><span class="tocnumber">8.10</span> <span class="toctext">Public holidays and festivals</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-51"><a href="#Sports"><span class="tocnumber">8.11</span> <span class="toctext">Sports</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-52"><a href="#International_rankings"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">International rankings</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-53"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-54"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-55"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-56"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Lithuania" title="Name of Lithuania">Name of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="316" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg/220px-Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg/330px-Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg/440px-Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuania\'s name in writing 1009</div></div></div>\n<p>The first known record of the name of Lithuania (<a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>: <i lang="lt">Lietuva</i>) is in a 9 March 1009 story of <a href="/wiki/Bruno_of_Querfurt" title="Bruno of Querfurt">Saint Bruno</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quedlinburg_Chronicle" title="Quedlinburg Chronicle">Quedlinburg Chronicle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> The Chronicle recorded a Latinized form of the name Lietuva: <i>Litua</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> (pronounced <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[litua]</span>). Due to the lack of reliable evidence, the true meaning of the name is unknown. Nowadays, scholars still debate the meaning of the word and there are a few plausible versions.\n</p><p>Since the word <i>Lietuva</i> has a suffix (-<i>uva</i>), the original word should have no suffix. A likely candidate is <i>Liet&#257;</i>. Because many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_language" title="Baltic language">Baltic</a> <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonyms</a> originated from <a href="/wiki/Hydronym" title="Hydronym">hydronyms</a>, linguists have searched for its origin among local hydronyms. Usually such names evolved through the following process: hydronym &#8594; toponym &#8594; <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas2_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zigmas2-15">[15]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lietava_River" title="Lietava River">Lietava</a>, a small river not far from <a href="/wiki/Kernav%C4%97" title="Kernav&#279;">Kernav&#279;</a>, the core area of the <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Duchy of Lithuania">early Lithuanian state</a> and a possible first capital of the eventual <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a>, is usually credited as the source of the name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas2_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-Zigmas2-15">[15]</a></sup> However, the river is very small and some find it improbable that such a small and local object could have lent its name to an entire nation. On the other hand, such a naming is not unprecedented in world history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zigmas-16">[16]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Art&#363;ras Dubonis\' proposed another hypothesis,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> that Lietuva relates to the word <i><a href="/wiki/Lei%C4%8Diai" title="Lei&#269;iai">lei&#269;iai</a></i> (plural of <i>leitis</i>). From the middle of the 13th century, <i>lei&#269;iai</i> were a distinct warrior social group of the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanians" title="Lithuanians">Lithuanian</a> society subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_rulers_of_Lithuania" title="List of rulers of Lithuania">Lithuanian ruler</a> or the state itself. The word <i>lei&#269;iai</i> is used in the 14&#8211;16th-century historical sources as an <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> for Lithuanians (but not <a href="/wiki/Samogitians" title="Samogitians">Samogitians</a>) and is still used, usually poetically or in historical contexts, in the <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian language</a>, which is closely related to Lithuanian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Lithuania" title="History of Lithuania">History of Lithuania</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Duchy of Lithuania">Duchy of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seges_is_senkapio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="977" data-file-width="653" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Seges_is_senkapio.jpg/150px-Seges_is_senkapio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Seges_is_senkapio.jpg/225px-Seges_is_senkapio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Seges_is_senkapio.jpg/300px-Seges_is_senkapio.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seges_is_senkapio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian brooches from 9th&#8211;12th centuries</div></div></div>\n<p>The first people settled in the territory of Lithuania after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Last_glacial_period" title="Last glacial period">last glacial period</a> in the 10th millennium BC: <a href="/wiki/Kunda_culture" title="Kunda culture">Kunda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neman_culture" title="Neman culture">Neman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Narva_culture" title="Narva culture">Narva cultures</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Polom&#233;Winter2011_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-Polom&#233;Winter2011-20">[20]</a></sup> They were traveling hunters and did not form stable settlements. In the 8th millennium BC, the climate became much warmer, and forests developed. The inhabitants of what is now Lithuania then traveled less and engaged in local hunting, gathering and fresh-water fishing. Agriculture did not emerge until the 3rd millennium BC due to a harsh climate and terrain and a lack of suitable tools to cultivate the land. Crafts and trade also started to form at this time. Over a millennium, the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-Europeans</a>, who arrived in the 3rd &#8211; 2nd millennium BC, mixed with the local population and formed various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_tribes" title="Baltic tribes">Baltic tribes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baltic-amber-colours.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="933" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Baltic-amber-colours.JPG/220px-Baltic-amber-colours.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Baltic-amber-colours.JPG/330px-Baltic-amber-colours.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Baltic-amber-colours.JPG/440px-Baltic-amber-colours.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Baltic-amber-colours.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_Amber" title="Baltic Amber">Baltic Amber</a>, that dates 44 million years ago, is a valuable trade resource. It was once transported to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Amber_Road" title="Amber Road">Amber Road</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_tribes" title="Baltic tribes">Baltic tribes</a> did not maintain close cultural or political contacts with the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacDonald1996_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-MacDonald1996-22">[22]</a></sup> but they did maintain trade contacts (see <a href="/wiki/Amber_Road" title="Amber Road">Amber Road</a>). <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">Tacitus</a>, in his study <i><a href="/wiki/Germania_(book)" title="Germania (book)">Germania</a></i>, described the <a href="/wiki/Aesti" title="Aesti">Aesti</a> people, inhabitants of the south-eastern <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> shores who were probably Balts, around the year 97 AD. The Western Balts differentiated and became known to outside chroniclers first. <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a> in the 2nd century AD knew of the <a href="/wiki/Galindians" title="Galindians">Galindians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yotvingians" title="Yotvingians">Yotvingians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">early medieval</a> chroniclers mentioned <a href="/wiki/Old_Prussians" title="Old Prussians">Old Prussians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Curonians" title="Curonians">Curonians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Semigallians" title="Semigallians">Semigallians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian language</a> is considered to be very <a href="/wiki/Conservative_(language)" title="Conservative (language)">conservative</a> for its close connection to Indo-European roots. It is believed to have differentiated from the <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian language</a>, the most closely related existing language, around the 7th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bumblauskas_13_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bumblauskas_13-24">[24]</a></sup> Traditional <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_mythology" title="Lithuanian mythology">Lithuanian pagan customs and mythology</a>, with many archaic elements, were long preserved. Rulers\' bodies were cremated up until the conversion to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>: the descriptions of the cremation ceremonies of the grand dukes <a href="/wiki/Algirdas" title="Algirdas">Algirdas</a> and <a href="/wiki/K%C4%99stutis" title="K&#281;stutis">K&#281;stutis</a> have survived.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bumblauskas_24-25_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bumblauskas_24-25-25">[25]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="875" data-file-width="624" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg/150px-Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg/225px-Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg/300px-Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_Mindaugas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The only surviving <a href="/wiki/Seal_of_Mindaugas" title="Seal of Mindaugas">Seal of Mindaugas</a> from 1255</div></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Grand Duchy of Lithuania">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lithuania" title="Kingdom of Lithuania">Kingdom of Lithuania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1411" data-file-width="1010" decoding="async" height="559" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png/400px-Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png/600px-Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png/800px-Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png 2x" width="400"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_state_in_13-15th_centuries.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Changes in the territory of Lithuania from the 13th to 15th century. At its peak, Lithuania was the largest state in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Lithuania\'s strength was its <a href="/wiki/Toleration" title="Toleration">toleration</a> of various <a href="/wiki/Culture" title="Culture">cultures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>From the 9th to the 11th centuries, coastal Balts were subjected to raids by the <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kasekamp2017_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kasekamp2017-28">[28]</a></sup> and the kings of <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> collected tribute at times.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> During the 10&#8211;11th centuries, Lithuanian territories were among the lands paying tribute to <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus\'">Kievan Rus\'</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise" title="Yaroslav the Wise">Yaroslav the Wise</a> was among the <a href="/wiki/Ruthenia" title="Ruthenia">Ruthenian</a> rulers who invaded Lithuania (from 1040). From the mid-12th century, it was the Lithuanians who were invading Ruthenian territories. In 1183, <a href="/wiki/Polotsk" title="Polotsk">Polotsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pskov" title="Pskov">Pskov</a> were ravaged, and even the distant and powerful <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod Republic</a> was repeatedly threatened by the excursions from the emerging Lithuanian war machine toward the end of the 12th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>\n</p><p>From the late 12th century, an organized Lithuanian military force existed; it was used for external raids, plundering and the gathering of slaves. Such military and pecuniary activities fostered social differentiation and triggered a struggle for power in Lithuania. This initiated the formation of early statehood, from which the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Initially inhabited by fragmented Baltic tribes, in the 1230s the Lithuanian lands were united by <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">Mindaugas</a>, who was crowned as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Lithuania" title="King of Lithuania">King of Lithuania</a> on 6 July 1253.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voruta2001_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-voruta2001-31">[31]</a></sup> After his assassination in 1263, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_mythology" title="Lithuanian mythology">pagan Lithuania</a> was a target of the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Crusades" title="Northern Crusades">Christian crusades</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" title="Teutonic Knights">Teutonic Knights</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Order" title="Livonian Order">Livonian Order</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siege_of_Pil%C4%97nai" title="Siege of Pil&#279;nai">Siege of Pil&#279;nai</a> is noted for the Lithuanians\' heroic defense against the intruders. Despite the devastating century-long struggle with the Orders, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> expanded rapidly, overtaking former Slavic principalities of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus\'">Kievan Rus\'</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swanson2015_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Swanson2015-32">[32]</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 22 September 1236, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Saul%C4%97" title="Battle of Saul&#279;">Battle of Saul&#279;</a> between <a href="/wiki/Samogitians" title="Samogitians">Samogitians</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Brothers_of_the_Sword" title="Livonian Brothers of the Sword">Livonian Brothers of the Sword</a> took place close to <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai" title="&#352;iauliai">&#352;iauliai</a>. The Livonian Brothers were smashed during it and their further conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Balts</a> lands were stopped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> The battle inspired rebellions among the <a href="/wiki/Curonians" title="Curonians">Curonians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semigallians" title="Semigallians">Semigallians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Selonians" title="Selonians">Selonians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oeselians" title="Oeselians">Oeselians</a>, tribes previously conquered by the Sword-Brothers. Some thirty years\' worth of conquests on the left bank of <a href="/wiki/Daugava" title="Daugava">Daugava</a> were lost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> In 2000, the Lithuanian and Latvian parliaments declared 22 September to be the Day of Baltic Unity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle,_2009.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1832" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg/220px-Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg/330px-Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg/440px-Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle,_2009.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Trakai_Island_Castle" title="Trakai Island Castle">Trakai Island Castle</a>, the former residence of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Duke_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duke of Lithuania">Grand Dukes</a> and capital city of the medieval state</div></div></div>\n<p>According to the legend, Grand Duke <a href="/wiki/Gediminas" title="Gediminas">Gediminas</a> was once hunting near the <a href="/wiki/Vilnia_River" title="Vilnia River">Vilnia River</a>; tired after the successful hunt, he settled in for the night and dreamed of a huge <a href="/wiki/Iron_Wolf_(character)" title="Iron Wolf (character)">Iron Wolf</a> standing on top a hill and howling as strong and loud as a hundred wolves. <i>Krivis</i> (pagan priest) Lizdeika interpreted the dream that the Iron Wolf represents <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vilnius_Castles" title="Vilnius Castles">Vilnius Castles</a>. Gediminas, obeying the will of gods, built the city, and gave it the name <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> &#8211; from the stream of the Vilnia River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1362 or 1363, Grand Duke <a href="/wiki/Algirdas" title="Algirdas">Algirdas</a> achieved a decisive victory in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Blue_Waters" title="Battle of Blue Waters">Battle of Blue Waters</a> against <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a> and stopped its further expansion in the present-day <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>. The victory brought the city of <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a> and a large part of present-day Ukraine, including sparsely populated <a href="/wiki/Podolia" title="Podolia">Podolia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dykra" title="Dykra">Dykra</a>, under the control of the expanding Grand Duchy of Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baran_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-baran-37">[37]</a></sup> After taking Kiev, Lithuania became a direct neighbor and rival of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>\n</p><p>By the end of the 14th century, Lithuania was one of the largest countries in Europe and included present-day <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, and parts of <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The geopolitical situation between the west and the east determined the multicultural and multi-confessional character of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. The ruling elite practised religious tolerance and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chancery_Slavonic" title="Chancery Slavonic">Chancery Slavonic</a> language was used as an auxiliary language to the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> for official documents.\n</p><p>In 1385, the Grand Duke <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jogaila" title="Jogaila">Jogaila</a> accepted Poland\'s offer to become its king. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jogaila" title="Jogaila">Jogaila</a> embarked on gradual <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Lithuania" title="Christianization of Lithuania">Christianization of Lithuania</a> and established a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> between Poland and Lithuania. Lithuania was one of the last <a href="/wiki/Romuva_(religion)" title="Romuva (religion)">pagan</a> areas of Europe to adopt Christianity.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jan_Matejko,_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1553" data-file-width="3571" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg/220px-Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg/330px-Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg/440px-Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jan_Matejko,_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great" title="Vytautas the Great">Vytautas the Great</a> in the centre</div></div></div>\n<p>After two civil wars, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great" title="Vytautas the Great">Vytautas the Great</a> became the Grand Duke of Lithuania in 1392. During his reign, Lithuania reached the peak of its territorial expansion, centralization of the state began, and the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_nobility" title="Lithuanian nobility">Lithuanian nobility</a> became increasingly prominent in state politics. In the great <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Vorskla_River" title="Battle of the Vorskla River">Battle of the Vorskla River</a> in 1399, the combined forces of <a href="/wiki/Tokhtamysh" title="Tokhtamysh">Tokhtamysh</a> and Vytautas were defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Mongols</a>. Thanks to close cooperation, the armies of Lithuania and Poland achieved a great victory over the Teutonic Knights in 1410 at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald</a>, one of the largest battles of medieval Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lane_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lane-40">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In January 1429, at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Lutsk" title="Congress of Lutsk">Congress of Lutsk</a> Vytautas received the title of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Lithuania" title="King of Lithuania">King of Lithuania</a> with the backing of <a href="/wiki/Sigismund,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor">Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor</a>, but the envoys who were transporting the crown were stopped by Polish <a href="/wiki/Magnate" title="Magnate">magnates</a> in autumn of 1430. Another crown was sent, but Vytautas died in the <a href="/wiki/Trakai_Island_Castle" title="Trakai Island Castle">Trakai Island Castle</a> several days before it reached Lithuania. He was buried in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Vilnius" title="Cathedral of Vilnius">Cathedral of Vilnius</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>\n</p><p>After the deaths of Jogaila and Vytautas, the Lithuanian nobility attempted to break the union between <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> and Lithuania, independently selecting Grand Dukes from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jagiellon_dynasty" title="Jagiellon dynasty">Jagiellon dynasty</a>. But, at the end of the 15th century, Lithuania was forced to seek a closer alliance with Poland when the growing power of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a> threatened Lithuania\'s Russian principalities and sparked the <a href="/wiki/Muscovite%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Wars" title="Muscovite&#8211;Lithuanian Wars">Muscovite&#8211;Lithuanian Wars</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Livonian_War" title="Livonian War">Livonian War</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Autor_nieznany_(malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego),_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2506" data-file-width="3966" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg/220px-Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg/330px-Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg/440px-Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Autor_nieznany_(malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego),_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>During the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Orsha" title="Battle of Orsha">Battle of Orsha</a> in 1514 Lithuanians hopelessly trounced the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a> forces</div></div></div>\n<p>On 8 September 1514, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Orsha" title="Battle of Orsha">Battle of Orsha</a> between Lithuanians, commanded by the <a href="/wiki/Hetmans_of_the_Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Hetmans of the Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Grand Hetman</a> <a href="/wiki/Konstanty_Ostrogski" title="Konstanty Ostrogski">Konstanty Ostrogski</a>, and Muscovites was fought. According to <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rerum_Moscoviticarum_Commentarii" title="Rerum Moscoviticarum Commentarii">Rerum Moscoviticarum Commentarii</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_von_Herberstein" title="Sigismund von Herberstein">Sigismund von Herberstein</a>, the primary source for information on the battle, the much smaller army of Poland&#8211;Lithuania (under 30,000 men) defeated a force of 80,000 Muscovite soldiers, capturing their camp and commander.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> The battle destroyed a military alliance against Lithuania and Poland. Thousands of Muscovites were captured as prisoners and used as laborers in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_palaces_and_manor_houses_in_Lithuania" title="List of palaces and manor houses in Lithuania">Lithuanian manors</a>, while Konstanty Ostrogski delivered the captured Muscovite flags to the Cathedral of Vilnius.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Livonian War was ceased for ten years with a <a href="/wiki/Truce_of_Yam-Zapolsky" title="Truce of Yam-Zapolsky">Truce of Yam-Zapolsky</a> signed on 15 January 1582 according to which the already <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> recovered <a href="/wiki/Livonia" title="Livonia">Livonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polotsk" title="Polotsk">Polotsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Velizh" title="Velizh">Velizh</a>, but transferred <a href="/wiki/Velikiye_Luki" title="Velikiye Luki">Velikiye Luki</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Truce" title="Truce">truce</a> was extended for twenty years in 1600, when a <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_mission" title="Diplomatic mission">diplomatic mission</a> to Moscow led by <a href="/wiki/Lew_Sapieha" title="Lew Sapieha">Lew Sapieha</a> concluded negotiations with Tsar <a href="/wiki/Boris_Godunov" title="Boris Godunov">Boris Godunov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> The truce was broken when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1605%E2%80%9318)" title="Polish&#8211;Muscovite War (1605&#8211;18)">the Poles invaded Muscovy in 1605</a>.\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Polish.E2.80.93Lithuanian_Commonwealth"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian_Commonwealth">Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_(T._Mako%C5%ADski,_1600).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="560" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29.jpg/220px-Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29.jpg/330px-Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29.jpg/440px-Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_(T._Mako%C5%ADski,_1600).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania" title="Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania">Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania</a>, marked 6, in 1600</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> was created in 1569 by the Union of Lublin. As a member of the Commonwealth, Lithuania retained its institutions, including a separate army, currency, and statutory laws - <a href="/wiki/Statutes_of_Lithuania" title="Statutes of Lithuania">the Statute of Lithuania</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> Eventually <a href="/wiki/Polonization" title="Polonization">Polonization</a> affected all aspects of Lithuanian life: politics, language, culture, and national identity. From the mid-16th to the mid-17th centuries, culture, arts, and education flourished, fueled by the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>. From 1573, the Kings of Poland and Grand Dukes of Lithuania were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_election_(Polish_throne)" title="Free election (Polish throne)">elected by the nobility</a>, who were granted ever increasing <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">Golden Liberties</a>. These liberties, especially the <i><a href="/wiki/Liberum_veto" title="Liberum veto">liberum veto</a></i>, led to anarchy and the eventual dissolution of the state.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kirholm_1605_I.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1986" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kirholm_1605_I.JPG/220px-Kirholm_1605_I.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kirholm_1605_I.JPG/330px-Kirholm_1605_I.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kirholm_1605_I.JPG/440px-Kirholm_1605_I.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kirholm_1605_I.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kircholm" title="Battle of Kircholm">Battle of Kircholm</a>, 1605</div></div></div>\n<p>The Commonwealth reached its <a href="/wiki/Polish_Golden_Age" title="Polish Golden Age">Golden Age</a> in the early 17th century. Its powerful <a href="/wiki/Sejm" title="Sejm">parliament</a> was dominated by nobles who were reluctant to get involved in the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years\' War">Thirty Years\' War</a>; this neutrality spared the country from the ravages of a political-religious conflict that devastated most of contemporary Europe. The Commonwealth held its own against <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Empire" title="Swedish Empire">Sweden</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>, and vassals of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and even launched successful <a href="/wiki/Expansionism" title="Expansionism">expansionist</a> offensives against its neighbors. In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1605%E2%80%9318)" title="Polish&#8211;Muscovite War (1605&#8211;18)">several invasions</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Time_of_Troubles" title="Time of Troubles">Time of Troubles</a>, Commonwealth troops entered Russia and managed to take <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> and hold it from 27 September 1610 to 4 November 1612, when they were driven out <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1605%E2%80%9318)#The_war_resumes_(1611)" title="Polish&#8211;Muscovite War (1605&#8211;18)">after a siege</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1153" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg/220px-Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg/330px-Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg/440px-Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Emila_Plater_conducting_Polish_scythemen_in_1831.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Emilia_Plater" title="Emilia Plater">Emilia Plater</a>, often nicknamed as a Lithuanian <a href="/wiki/Joan_of_Arc" title="Joan of Arc">Joan of Arc</a>, leading peasant <a href="/wiki/Kosynierzy" title="Kosynierzy">scythemen</a> during the 1831 uprising</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1655, after the extinguishing <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vilnius_(1655)" title="Battle of Vilnius (1655)">battle</a>, for the first time in history Lithuanian capital Vilnius was taken by the foreign army. Russian army looted the city, splendid churches, manors. 8000-10000 citizens were killed; the city burned 17 days. Those who returned after the catastrophe didn\'t recognise the city. Russian occupation of Grand Duchy of Lithuania lasted up to 1661. Many artefacts and cultural heritage were either lost or looted, significant parts of the state archive &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Metrica" title="Lithuanian Metrica">Lithuanian Metrica</a>, collected since 13th century, were lost and the rest is moved out of the country. During the <a href="/wiki/Second_Northern_War" title="Second Northern War">Northern Wars</a> (1655&#8211;1661), the Lithuanian territory and economy were devastated by the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Empire" title="Swedish Empire">Swedish</a> army. Almost all territory of Grand Duchy of Lithuania was occupied by Swedish and Russian armies. This period is known as <i>Tvanas</i> (<a href="/wiki/Deluge_(history)" title="Deluge (history)">The Deluge</a>).\n</p><p>Before it could fully recover, Lithuania was ravaged during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> (1700&#8211;1721). The war, <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War_plague_outbreak" title="Great Northern War plague outbreak">a plague</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Great_Frost_of_1709" title="Great Frost of 1709">a famine</a> caused the deaths of approximately 40% of the country\'s population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Foreign powers, especially Russia, became dominant in the domestic politics of the Commonwealth. Numerous fractions among the nobility used the Golden Liberties to prevent any reforms.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_3_May_1791" title="Constitution of 3 May 1791">Constitution of 3 May 1791</a> was adopted by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Sejm" title="Great Sejm">Great Sejm</a> (parliament) of the Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth trying to save the state. The legislation was designed to redress the Commonwealth\'s political defects due to the system of Golden Liberties, also known as the "Nobles\' Democracy," had conferred disproportionate rights on the nobility (szlachta) and over time had corrupted politics. The constitution sought to supplant the prevailing anarchy fostered by some of the country\'s <a href="/wiki/Magnates_of_Poland_and_Lithuania" title="Magnates of Poland and Lithuania">magnates</a> with a more democratic <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>. It introduced elements of political equality between townspeople and nobility, and placed the peasants under the protection of the government, thus mitigating the worst abuses of <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">serfdom</a>. It banned parliamentary institutions such as the <i>liberum veto</i>, which had put the Sejm at the mercy of any deputy who could revoke all the legislation that had been passed by that Sejm. It was drafted in relation to a copy of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">United States Constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Others have called it the world\'s second-oldest codified national governmental constitution after the 1787 U.S. Constitution.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_Empire">Russian Empire</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Russian Empire">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Eventually, <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">the Commonwealth was partitioned</a> in 1772, 1792, and 1795 by the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_Austria" title="Habsburg Austria">Habsburg Austria</a>.\n</p><p>The largest area of Lithuanian territory became part of the Russian Empire. After unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">uprisings in 1831</a> and <a href="/wiki/January_Uprising" title="January Uprising">1863</a>, the Tsarist authorities implemented a number of <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">Russification</a> policies. In 1840 the <a href="/wiki/Statutes_of_Lithuania#Third_Statute" title="Statutes of Lithuania">Third Statute of Lithuania</a> was abolished. They <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_press_ban" title="Lithuanian press ban">banned the Lithuanian press</a>, closed cultural and educational institutions, and made Lithuania part of a new administrative region called <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Krai" title="Northwestern Krai">Northwestern Krai</a>. The Russification failed owing to an extensive network of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Book_smuggler" title="Book smuggler">book smugglers</a> and secret Lithuanian home schooling.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Valancius.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="304" data-file-width="227" decoding="async" height="295" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Valancius.jpg/220px-Valancius.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/46/Valancius.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Valancius.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bishop <a href="/wiki/Motiejus_Valan%C4%8Dius" title="Motiejus Valan&#269;ius">Motiejus Valan&#269;ius</a> (1801&#8211;1875) urged to resist Russification, to protest against closing of catholic churches and monasteries, organised book printing in Lithuanian in <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_Minor" title="Lithuania Minor">Lithuania Minor</a> and distribution channels in occupied Lithuania</div></div></div>\n<p>After the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877&#8211;1878)">Russo-Turkish War (1877&#8211;1878)</a>, when German diplomats assigned what were seen as Russian spoils of war to Turkey, the relationship between Russia and the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a> became complicated. The Russian Empire resumed the construction of fortresses at its western borders for defence against a potential invasion from Germany in the West. On 7 July 1879 the <a href="/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia" title="Alexander II of Russia">Russian Emperor Alexander II</a> approved of a proposal from the Russian military leadership to build the largest "first-class" defensive structure in the entire state &#8211; the 65&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (25&#160;sq&#160;mi) <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Fortress" title="Kaunas Fortress">Kaunas Fortress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kauno_tvirtov&#279;_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kauno_tvirtov&#279;-53">[53]</a></sup> Large numbers of Lithuanians went to the United States in 1867&#8211;1868 after a <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><a href="/wiki/Simonas_Daukantas" title="Simonas Daukantas">Simonas Daukantas</a> promoted a return to Lithuania\'s pre-<a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian Commonwealth">Commonwealth</a> traditions, which he depicted as a Golden Age of Lithuania and a renewal of the native culture, based on the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian language</a> and customs. With those ideas in mind, he wrote already in 1822 a history of Lithuania in Lithuanian &#8211; <i>Darbai sen&#371;j&#371; lietuvi&#371; ir &#382;emai&#269;i&#371;</i> (<i>The Deeds of Ancient Lithuanians and Samogitians</i>), though still not yet published at that time. A colleague of S.Daukantas, <a href="/wiki/Teodor_Narbutt" title="Teodor Narbutt">Teodor Narbutt</a> wrote in Polish a voluminous <i>Ancient History of the Lithuanian Nation</i> (1835&#8211;1841), where he likewise expounded and expanded further on the concept of historic Lithuania, whose days of glory had ended with the Union of Lublin in 1569. Narbutt, invoking the German scholarship, pointed out the relationship between the Lithuanian and <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> languages. A <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Revival" title="Lithuanian National Revival">Lithuanian National Revival</a>, inspired by the ancient Lithuanian history, language and culture, laid the foundations of the modern Lithuanian nation and independent Lithuania.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_and_21st_centuries">20th and 21st centuries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: 20th and 21st centuries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<h4><span id="1918.E2.80.931939"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1918&#8211;1939">1918&#8211;1939</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: 1918&#8211;1939">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="655" data-file-width="945" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg/220px-Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg/330px-Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg/440px-Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The original 20 members of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Lithuania" title="Council of Lithuania">Council of Lithuania</a> after signing the <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">Act of Independence of Lithuania</a>, 16 February 1918.</div></div></div>\n<p>As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Retreat_(Russian)" title="Great Retreat (Russian)">Great Retreat</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, Germany occupied the entire territory of Lithuania and <a href="/wiki/Courland" title="Courland">Courland</a> by the end of 1915.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> A new administrative entity, <a href="/wiki/Ober_Ost" title="Ober Ost">Ober Ost</a>, was established. Lithuanians lost all political rights they had gained: personal freedom was restricted, and at the beginning the Lithuanian press was banned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> However, the Lithuanian intelligentsia tried to take advantage of the existing geopolitical situation and began to look for opportunities to restore Lithuania\'s independence. On 18&#8211;22 September 1917, the <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Conference" title="Vilnius Conference">Vilnius Conference</a> elected the 20-member <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Lithuania" title="Council of Lithuania">Council of Lithuania</a>. The council adopted the <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">Act of Independence of Lithuania</a> on 16 February 1918 which proclaimed the restoration of the independent state of Lithuania governed by democratic principles, with <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> as its capital. The state of Lithuania which had been built within the framework of the Act lasted from 1918 until 1940.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2483" data-file-width="3816" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg/220px-Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg/330px-Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg/440px-Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lietuvos_%C5%A1arvuotas_traukinys_Gediminas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian <a href="/wiki/Armoured_train" title="Armoured train">armoured train</a> <i>Gediminas 3</i>, used in <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Wars_of_Independence" title="Lithuanian Wars of Independence">Lithuanian Wars of Independence</a> and Lithuanian soldiers</div></div></div>\n<p>Following the capitulation of Germany in November 1918, the first Provisional <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">Constitution of Lithuania</a> was adopted and the first government of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Augustinas_Voldemaras" title="Augustinas Voldemaras">Augustinas Voldemaras</a> was organized. At the same time, the army and other state institutions began to be organized. Lithuania fought <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Wars_of_Independence" title="Lithuanian Wars of Independence">three wars of independence</a>: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="Lithuanian&#8211;Soviet War">against the Bolsheviks</a> who proclaimed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic_(1918%E2%80%931919)" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1918&#8211;1919)">Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, against the <a href="/wiki/West_Russian_Volunteer_Army" title="West Russian Volunteer Army">Bermontians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_War" title="Polish&#8211;Lithuanian War">against Poland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> As a result of the staged <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBeligowski%27s_Mutiny" title="&#379;eligowski\'s Mutiny">&#379;eligowski\'s Mutiny</a> in October 1920, <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Poland</a> took control of <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Region" title="Vilnius Region">Vilnius Region</a> and annexed it as <a href="/wiki/Wilno_Voivodeship_(1926%E2%80%931939)" title="Wilno Voivodeship (1926&#8211;1939)">Wilno Voivodeship</a> in 1922.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iskauskas_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Iskauskas-59">[59]</a></sup> Lithuania continued to claim Vilnius as its <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> capital and relations with Poland remained particularly tense and hostile for the entire interwar period. In January 1923, Lithuania staged the <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Revolt" title="Klaip&#279;da Revolt">Klaip&#279;da Revolt</a> and captured <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region" title="Klaip&#279;da Region">Klaip&#279;da Region</a> (Memel territory) which was detached from <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>. The region became an autonomous region of Lithuania.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1487" data-file-width="971" decoding="async" height="260" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg/170px-Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg/255px-Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg/340px-Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Antanas_Smetona" title="Antanas Smetona">Antanas Smetona</a> was the first and last president of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interbellum" title="Interbellum">interbellum</a></i> Lithuania (1919&#8211;1920, 1926&#8211;1940)</div></div></div>\n<p>On 15 May 1920, the first meeting of the democratically elected <a href="/wiki/Constituent_assembly" title="Constituent assembly">constituent assembly</a> took place. The documents it adopted, i. e. the temporary (1920) and permanent (1922) constitutions of Lithuania, strove to regulate the life of the new state. Land, finance, and educational reforms started to be implemented. The currency of Lithuania, the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_litas" title="Lithuanian litas">Lithuanian litas</a>, was introduced. The <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Magnus_University" title="Vytautas Magnus University">University of Lithuania</a> was opened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> All major public institutions had been established. As Lithuania began to gain stability, foreign countries started to recognize it.
