In 1921 Lithuania was admitted to the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 17 December 1926, a military <a href="/wiki/1926_Lithuanian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1926 Lithuanian coup d\'&#233;tat">coup d\'&#233;tat</a> took place resulting in the replacement of the democratically elected government with a conservative authoritarian government led by Antanas Smetona. <a href="/wiki/Augustinas_Voldemaras" title="Augustinas Voldemaras">Augustinas Voldemaras</a> was appointed to form a government. The so-called authoritarian phase had begun strengthening the influence of one party, the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Nationalist_Union" title="Lithuanian Nationalist Union">Lithuanian Nationalist Union</a>, in the country. In 1927, the Seimas was released.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> A new constitution adopted in 1928, which consolidated presidential powers. Gradually the opposition parties were banned, the censorship was tightened, and the rights of national minorities were narrowed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="483" data-file-width="795" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg/220px-Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg/330px-Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg/440px-Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lituanica_Above_New_York.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Lituanica" title="Lituanica">Lituanica</a></i> above <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a> in 1933. The transatlantic flight was one of the most precise in aviation history. It equaled, and in some aspects surpassed, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Lindbergh" title="Charles Lindbergh">Charles Lindbergh</a>\'s classic flight.</div></div></div>\n<p>On 15 July 1933, <a href="/wiki/Steponas_Darius" title="Steponas Darius">Steponas Darius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stasys_Gir%C4%97nas" title="Stasys Gir&#279;nas">Stasys Gir&#279;nas</a>, Lithuanian pilots, emigrants to the United States, made a significant flight in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aviation_history" title="Aviation history">history of world aviation</a>. They flew across the Atlantic Ocean, covering a distance of 3,984 miles (6,411 kilometers) without landing, in 37 hours and 11 minutes (107.1&#160;mph). In terms of comparison, as far as the distance of non-stop flights was concerned, their result ranked second only to that of <a href="/wiki/Russell_Boardman" title="Russell Boardman">Russell Boardman</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Polando" title="John Polando">John Polando</a>.\n</p><p>The temporary capital Kaunas, which was nicknamed the <i>Little Paris</i>, and the country itself had a <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western</a> standard of living with sufficiently high salaries and low prices. At the time, qualified workers there were earning very similar <a href="/wiki/Real_wages" title="Real wages">real wages</a> as workers in <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, the country also had a surprisingly high <a href="/wiki/Rate_of_natural_increase" title="Rate of natural increase">natural increase in population</a> of 9.7 and the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_production" title="Industrial production">industrial production</a> of Lithuania increased by 160% from 1913 to 1940.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The situation was aggravated by the global economic crisis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> The purchase price of agricultural products had declined significantly. In 1935, farmers began strikes in <a href="/wiki/Suvalkija" title="Suvalkija">Suvalkija</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dz%C5%ABkija" title="Dz&#363;kija">Dz&#363;kija</a>. In addition to economic ones, political demands were made. The government cruelly suppressed the unrest. In the spring of 1936, four peasants were sentenced to death for starting the riots.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span id="1939.E2.80.931944"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1939&#8211;1944">1939&#8211;1944</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: 1939&#8211;1944">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">Occupation of the Baltic states</a>, <a href="/wiki/June_Uprising_in_Lithuania" title="June Uprising in Lithuania">June Uprising in Lithuania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Lithuania_during_World_War_II" title="German occupation of Lithuania during World War II">German occupation of Lithuania during World War II</a></div>\n<p>On 20 March 1939, after years of rising tensions, Lithuania was handed an ultimatum by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> demanding to relinquish the <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region" title="Klaip&#279;da Region">Klaip&#279;da Region</a>. Two days later, the Lithuanian government accepted the ultimatum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> When Nazi Germany and Soviet Union concluded the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov&#8211;Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov&#8211;Ribbentrop Pact</a>, Lithuania was initially assigned to the German <a href="/wiki/Sphere_of_influence" title="Sphere of influence">sphere of influence</a> but later was transferred to the Soviet sphere. At the outbreak of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Lithuania declared <a href="/wiki/Neutral_powers_during_World_War_II" title="Neutral powers during World War II">neutrality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="654" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg/220px-Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg/330px-Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg/440px-Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian delegation to negotiate the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Mutual_Assistance_Treaty" title="Soviet&#8211;Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty">Soviet&#8211;Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In October 1939, Lithuania was forced to sign the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Mutual_Assistance_Treaty" title="Soviet&#8211;Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty">Soviet&#8211;Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty</a>: five Soviet military bases with 20,000 troops were established in Lithuania in exchange for <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> that the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">Soviets captured from Poland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> Delayed by the <a href="/wiki/Winter_War" title="Winter War">Winter War</a> with Finland, the <a href="/wiki/1940_Soviet_ultimatum_to_Lithuania" title="1940 Soviet ultimatum to Lithuania">Soviets issued an ultimatum to Lithuania</a> on 14 June 1940. They demanded to replace the Lithuanian government and to allow <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> into the country. The government decided that with Soviet bases already in Lithuania armed resistance was impossible and accepted the ultimatum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> President Smetona fled the country while more than 200,000 Soviet Red Army soldiers crossed the <a href="/wiki/Belarus%E2%80%93Lithuania_border" title="Belarus&#8211;Lithuania border">Belarus&#8211;Lithuania border</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> The next day, identical ultimatums were presented to Latvia and Estonia. The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">Baltic states were occupied</a>. The Soviets followed semi-constitutional procedures for transforming the independent countries into soviet republics and incorporating them into the Soviet Union.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Dekanozov" title="Vladimir Dekanozov">Vladimir Dekanozov</a> was sent to supervise the formation of the puppet <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Government_of_Lithuania" title="People\'s Government of Lithuania">People\'s Government</a> and the rigged election to the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Seimas" title="People\'s Seimas">People\'s Seimas</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic">Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic</a> was proclaimed on 21 July and accepted into the Soviet Union on 3 August. Lithuania was rapidly sovietizied: political parties and various organizations (except the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Lithuania" title="Communist Party of Lithuania">Communist Party of Lithuania</a>) were outlawed, some 12,000 people, including many prominent figures, were arrested and imprisoned in <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">Gulag</a> as "enemies of the people", larger private property was nationalized, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_litas" title="Lithuanian litas">Lithuanian litas</a> was exchanged to <a href="/wiki/Soviet_ruble" title="Soviet ruble">Soviet ruble</a>, farm taxes were increased by 50&#8211;200%, Lithuanian Army was transformed into the <a href="/wiki/29th_Rifle_Corps_(Soviet_Union)" title="29th Rifle Corps (Soviet Union)">29th Rifle Corps of the Red Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArmyDestruction_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArmyDestruction-74">[74]</a></sup> On 14&#8211;18 June 1941, less than a week before the Nazi invasion, some 17,000 Lithuanians were deported to <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>, where many perished due to inhumane living conditions (see the <a href="/wiki/June_deportation" title="June deportation">June deportation</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> The occupation was not recognized by Western powers and the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Diplomatic_Service" title="Lithuanian Diplomatic Service">Lithuanian Diplomatic Service</a>, based on pre-war consulates and legations, continued to represent independent Lithuania until 1990.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="700" data-file-width="1049" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg/220px-Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg/330px-Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg/440px-Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tuskulenai_columbarium.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Columbarium of the victims killed by the Soviets near the <a href="/wiki/Tuskul%C4%97nai_Manor" title="Tuskul&#279;nai Manor">Tuskul&#279;nai Manor</a></div></div></div>\n<p>When Nazi Germany <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">attacked the Soviet Union</a> on 22 June 1941, Lithuanians began the anti-Soviet <a href="/wiki/June_Uprising_in_Lithuania" title="June Uprising in Lithuania">June Uprising</a>, organized by the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Activist_Front" title="Lithuanian Activist Front">Lithuanian Activist Front</a>. Lithuanians proclaimed independence and organized the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania" title="Provisional Government of Lithuania">Provisional Government of Lithuania</a>. This government quickly self-disbanded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mi47_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-mi47-77">[77]</a></sup> Lithuania became part of the <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ostland" title="Reichskommissariat Ostland">Reichskommissariat Ostland</a>, German civil administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG/220px-9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG/330px-9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG/440px-9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:9-_Vilnius-Maison_verte-DSC05325-Massacre_de_Paneriai.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ponary_massacre" title="Ponary massacre">Paneriai massacre</a>, where the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_Nazi" title="German Nazi">German Nazis</a> and their collaborators executed up to 100,000 people of various nationalities. About 70,000 of them were Jews.</div></div></div>\n<p>By 1 December 1941, over 120,000 <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Jews" title="Lithuanian Jews">Lithuanian Jews</a>, or 91&#8211;95% of Lithuania\'s pre-war Jewish community, had been killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBBG_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-PBBG-79">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>110</span></sup> Nearly 100,000 Jews, Poles, Russians and Lithuanians were <a href="/wiki/Ponary_massacre" title="Ponary massacre">murdered at Paneriai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Approximately 13,000 men served in the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Auxiliary_Police_Battalions" title="Lithuanian Auxiliary Police Battalions">Lithuanian Auxiliary Police Battalions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> 10 of the 26 Lithuanian Auxiliary Police Battalions working with the Nazi <a href="/wiki/Einsatzkommando" title="Einsatzkommando">Einsatzkommando</a>, were involved in the mass killings. Rogue units organised by <a href="/wiki/Algirdas_Klimaitis" title="Algirdas Klimaitis">Algirdas Klimaitis</a> and supervised by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SS" title="SS">SS</a> <i>Brigadef&#252;hrer</i> Walter Stahlecker started <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_pogrom" title="Kaunas pogrom">Kaunas pogrom</a> in and around <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> on 25 June 1941.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> In 1941, the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Security_Police" title="Lithuanian Security Police">Lithuanian Security Police</a> (<i>Lietuvos saugumo policija</i>), subordinate to Nazi Germany\'s Security Police and Nazi Germany\'s Criminal Police, was created. The <i>Lietuvos saugumo policija</i> targeted the communist underground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>\n</p><p>However, thousands of Lithuanian families risking their lives also protected Jews from the Holocaust.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> has recognized 893 Lithuanians (as of 1 January 2018) as <a href="/wiki/Righteous_Among_the_Nations" title="Righteous Among the Nations">Righteous Among the Nations</a> for risking their lives to save Jews during the Holocaust.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>\n</p><p>A new occupation had begun. Nationalized assets were not returned to the residents. Some of them were forced to fight for Nazi Germany or were taken to German territories as a forced laborers. <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jewish</a> people were herded into ghettos and gradually killed by shooting or sending them out to concentration camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span id="1944.E2.80.931990"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1944&#8211;1990">1944&#8211;1990</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: 1944&#8211;1990">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic">Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1746" data-file-width="3104" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG/220px-Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG/330px-Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG/440px-Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Naujoji_Vilnia_train_station_4.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Monument in <a href="/wiki/Naujoji_Vilnia" title="Naujoji Vilnia">Naujoji Vilnia</a> in memory of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_deportations_from_Lithuania" title="Soviet deportations from Lithuania">Soviet deportations from Lithuania</a></div></div></div>\n<p>After the retreat of the <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">German armed forces</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_and_annexation_of_the_Baltic_states_by_the_Soviet_Union_(1944)" title="Occupation and annexation of the Baltic states by the Soviet Union (1944)">Soviets reestablished their control of Lithuania</a> in July&#8211;October 1944. The <a href="/wiki/Deportation" title="Deportation">massive deportations</a> to <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> were resumed and lasted until the death of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Stalin</a> in 1953. All Lithuanian national symbols were banned. Under the pretext of Lithuania\'s economic recovery, the <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> authorities encouraged the migration of workers and other specialists to Lithuania with the intention to further integrate Lithuania into the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and to develop the country\'s industry. At the same time, Lithuanians were lured to work in the USSR by promising them all the privileges of settling in a new place.\n</p><p>The second Soviet occupation was accompanied by the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_partisans" title="Lithuanian partisans">guerrilla warfare</a> of the Lithuanian population, which took place in 1944&#8211;1953. It sought to restore an independent state of Lithuania, to consolidate democracy by destroying communism in the country, returning national values and the freedom of religion. Classified as bandits by the Soviets, Lithuanians took to the forests and fought them with a gun in their hands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In the later stages of the partisan war, Lithuanians formed the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lithuanian_Freedom_Fighters" title="Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters">Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters</a> and its leader <a href="/wiki/Jonas_%C5%BDemaitis" title="Jonas &#381;emaitis">Jonas &#381;emaitis</a> (codename Vytautas) was posthumously recognized as the president of Lithuania. The number of people in a group fell to 3&#8211;5 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> Despite the fact that the guerrilla warfare did not achieve its goal of liberating Lithuania and that it resulted in more than 20,000 deaths, the armed resistance <i>de facto</i> demonstrated that Lithuania did not voluntarily join the USSR and it also legitimized the will of the people of Lithuania to be independent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-k&#252;ng1999_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-k&#252;ng1999-92">[92]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._(2).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="455" data-file-width="952" decoding="async" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._%282%29.jpg/220px-Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._%282%29.jpg/330px-Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._%282%29.jpg/440px-Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mitingas_Vingio_parke_Vilniuje_1988_m._(2).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-Soviet" title="Anti-Soviet">Anti-Soviet</a> rally in <a href="/wiki/Vingis_Park" title="Vingis Park">Vingis Park</a> of about 250,000 people. <a href="/wiki/S%C4%85j%C5%ABdis" title="S&#261;j&#363;dis">S&#261;j&#363;dis</a> was a movement which led to the restoration of an Independent State of Lithuania.</div></div></div>\n<p>Even with the suppression of partisan resistance, the Soviet government failed to stop the movement for the independence of Lithuania. The underground dissident groups were active publishing the underground press and Catholic literature. The most active participants of the movement included <a href="/wiki/Vincentas_Sladkevi%C4%8Dius" title="Vincentas Sladkevi&#269;ius">Vincentas Sladkevi&#269;ius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sigitas_Tamkevi%C4%8Dius" title="Sigitas Tamkevi&#269;ius">Sigitas Tamkevi&#269;ius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nijol%C4%97_Sad%C5%ABnait%C4%97" title="Nijol&#279; Sad&#363;nait&#279;">Nijol&#279; Sad&#363;nait&#279;</a>. In 1972, after <a href="/wiki/Romas_Kalanta" title="Romas Kalanta">Romas Kalanta\'s</a> public self-immolation, the unrest in <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> lasted for several days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2624" data-file-width="3936" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg/220px-Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg/330px-Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg/440px-Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">Baltic Way</a>, the human chain connecting the three Baltic capitals</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Helsinki_Group" title="Lithuanian Helsinki Group">Helsinki Group</a>, which was founded in Lithuania after the international conference in Helsinki (Finland), where the post-WWII borders were acknowledged, announced a declaration for Lithuania\'s independence on foreign radio station.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> The Helsinki Group informed the Western world about the situation in the Soviet Lithuania and violations of human rights. With the beginning of the increased openness and transparency in government institutions and activities (<i><a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a></i>) in the Soviet Union, on 3 June 1988, the <a href="/wiki/S%C4%85j%C5%ABdis" title="S&#261;j&#363;dis">S&#261;j&#363;dis</a> was established in Lithuania. Very soon it began to seek country\'s independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Landsbergis" title="Vytautas Landsbergis">Vytautas Landsbergis</a> became movement\'s leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> The supporters of S&#261;j&#363;dis joined movement\'s groups all over Lithuania. On 23 August 1988 a big rally took place at the <a href="/wiki/Vingis_Park" title="Vingis Park">Vingis Park</a> in Vilnius. It was attended by approx. 250,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> A year later, on 23 August 1989 celebrating the 50th anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov&#8211;Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact</a> and aiming to draw the attention of the whole world to the occupation of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic States</a>, a political demonstration, the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">Baltic Way</a>, was organized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> The event, led by <a href="/wiki/S%C4%85j%C5%ABdis" title="S&#261;j&#363;dis">S&#261;j&#363;dis</a>, was a human chain spanning about 600 kilometres (370&#160;mi) across the three Baltic capitals&#8212;<a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">Riga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>. The peaceful demonstration showed the desire of the people of Lithuania, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a> to break away from the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">USSR</a>.\n</p>\n<h4><span id="1990.E2.80.93present"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1990&#8211;present">1990&#8211;present</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: 1990&#8211;present">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:382px;max-width:382px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:245px;max-width:245px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:186px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_(2).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="780" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg/243px-Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg/365px-Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg/486px-Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="243"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:133px;max-width:133px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:186px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="1136" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png/131px-Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png/197px-Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png/262px-Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png 2x" width="131"/></a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:transparent">On 11 March 1990, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_%E2%80%93_Reconstituent_Seimas" title="Supreme Council &#8211; Reconstituent Seimas">Supreme Council</a> announced the <a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">restoration of Lithuania\'s independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bell2002_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bell2002-99">[99]</a></sup> After refusal to revocate the Act, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">Soviet forces</a> stormed the <a href="/wiki/Seimas_Palace" title="Seimas Palace">Seimas Palace</a>, while Lithuanians defended their <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratically</a> elected Council. The Act was the first such declaration in the USSR and later served as a model, inspiration to other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_republics" title="Soviet republics">Soviet republics</a>, and strongly influenced the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_USSR" title="Dissolution of the USSR">dissolution of the USSR</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>On 11 March 1990, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_%E2%80%93_Reconstituent_Seimas" title="Supreme Council &#8211; Reconstituent Seimas">Supreme Council</a> announced the restoration of Lithuania\'s independence. Lithuania became the first Soviet occupied state to announce restitution of independence. On 20 April 1990, the USSR imposed an <a href="/wiki/Blockade" title="Blockade">economic blockade</a> by stopping to deliver supplies of raw materials (primarily oil) to Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Not only the domestic industry, but also the population started feeling the lack of fuel, essential goods, and even hot water. Although the blockade lasted for 74 days, Lithuania did not renounce the declaration of independence.\n</p><p>Gradually, the economic relations had been restored. However, the tension had peaked again in January 1991. At that time, attempts were made to carry out a coup using the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Armed_Forces" title="Soviet Armed Forces">Soviet Armed Forces</a>, the Internal Army of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the USSR Committee for State Security (<a href="/wiki/KGB" title="KGB">KGB</a>). Because of the bad economic situation in Lithuania, the forces in Moscow thought the <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d\'&#233;tat">coup d\'&#233;tat</a> would receive a strong public support. But the situation was the opposite.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="514" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg/220px-January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg/330px-January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg/440px-January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>On <a href="/wiki/January_Events_(Lithuania)" title="January Events (Lithuania)">13 January 1991</a>, Soviets began shooting and crushing with tanks unarmed independence supporters. To this day, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> refuses to extradite <a href="/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity" title="Crimes against humanity">criminals against humanity</a> that are responsible for the bloody events.</div></div></div>\n<p>People from all over Lithuania flooded to <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> to defend their legitimately elected <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_%E2%80%93_Reconstituent_Seimas" title="Supreme Council &#8211; Reconstituent Seimas">Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania</a> and independence. The coup ended with a few casualties of peaceful civilians and caused huge material loss. Not a single person who defended <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">Lithuanian Parliament</a> or other state institutions used a weapon, but the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">Soviet Army</a> did. Soviet soldiers killed 14 people and injured hundreds. A large part of the Lithuanian population participated in the <a href="/wiki/January_Events_(Lithuania)" title="January Events (Lithuania)">January Events</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-102">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Shortly after, on 11 February 1991, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al%C3%BEingi" title="Al&#254;ingi">Icelandic parliament</a> voted to confirm that <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>\'s 1922 recognition of Lithuanian independence was still in full effect, as it never formally recognized the Soviet Union\'s control over Lithuania,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> and that full diplomatic relations should be established as soon as possible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 31 July 1991, Soviet paramilitaries killed seven Lithuanian border guards on the Belarusian border in what became known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medininkai_Massacre" title="Medininkai Massacre">Medininkai Massacre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> On 17 September 1991, Lithuania was admitted to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.\n</p><p>On 25 October 1992, the citizens of Lithuania voted in the referendum to adopt the current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">constitution</a>. On 14 February 1993, during the direct general elections, <a href="/wiki/Algirdas_Brazauskas" title="Algirdas Brazauskas">Algirdas Brazauskas</a> became the first president after the restoration of independence of Lithuania. On 31 August 1993, the last units of the Soviet Army left the territory of Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> Since 29 March 2004, Lithuania has been part of the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. On 1 May 2004, it became a full-fledged member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, and a member of the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a> on 21 December 2007.\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Lithuania" title="Geography of Lithuania">Geography of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1653" data-file-width="2361" decoding="async" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png/350px-LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png/525px-LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png/700px-LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LithuaniaPhysicalMap-en.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Physical map and geomorphological subdivision of the Lithuania.</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania is located in the Baltic region of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a><sup class="reference plainlinks nourlexpansion" id="ref_NoteA"><a href="#endnote_NoteA">Note</a></sup> and covers an area of 65,200&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (25,200&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/53rd_parallel_north" title="53rd parallel north">53&#176;</a> and <a href="/wiki/57th_parallel_north" title="57th parallel north">57&#176; N</a>, and mostly between longitudes <a href="/wiki/21st_meridian_east" title="21st meridian east">21&#176;</a> and <a href="/wiki/27th_meridian_east" title="27th meridian east">27&#176; E</a> (part of the <a href="/wiki/Curonian_Spit" title="Curonian Spit">Curonian Spit</a> lies west of 21&#176;). It has around 99 kilometres (61.5&#160;mi) of sandy coastline, only about 38 kilometres (24&#160;mi) of which face the open <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, less than the other two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea_countries" title="Baltic Sea countries">Baltic Sea countries</a>. The rest of the coast is sheltered by the Curonian sand peninsula. Lithuania\'s major <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warm-water_port" title="Warm-water port">warm-water port</a>, <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaip&#279;da">Klaip&#279;da</a>, lies at the narrow mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Curonian_Lagoon" title="Curonian Lagoon">Curonian Lagoon</a> (Lithuanian: <i>Kur&#353;i&#371; marios</i>), a shallow lagoon extending south to <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad" title="Kaliningrad">Kaliningrad</a>. The country\'s main and largest river, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nemunas_River" title="Nemunas River">Nemunas River</a>, and some of its tributaries carry international shipping.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg/220px-Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg/330px-Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg/440px-Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Geographic centre of Europe according to Affholder\'s theory.</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania lies at the edge of the <a href="/wiki/North_European_Plain" title="North European Plain">North European Plain</a>. Its landscape was smoothed by the glaciers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Last_glacial_period" title="Last glacial period">last ice age</a>, and is a combination of moderate lowlands and highlands. Its highest point is <a href="/wiki/Auk%C5%A1tojas_Hill" title="Auk&#353;tojas Hill">Auk&#353;tojas Hill</a> at 294 metres (965&#160;ft) in the eastern part of the country. The terrain features <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_in_Lithuania" title="List of lakes in Lithuania">numerous lakes</a> (<a href="/wiki/Lake_Vi%C5%A1tytis" title="Lake Vi&#353;tytis">Lake Vi&#353;tytis</a>, for example) and wetlands, and a mixed forest zone covers over 33% of the country. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dr%C5%ABk%C5%A1iai" title="Dr&#363;k&#353;iai">Dr&#363;k&#353;iai</a> is the largest, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tauragnas" title="Tauragnas">Tauragnas</a> is the deepest and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asveja" title="Asveja">Asveja</a> is the longest lake in Lithuania.\n</p><p>After a re-estimation of the boundaries of the <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continent</a> of Europe in 1989, Jean-George Affholder, a scientist at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Institut_g%C3%A9ographique_national_(France)" title="Institut g&#233;ographique national (France)">Institut G&#233;ographique National</a> (French National Geographic Institute), determined that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geographic_centre_of_Europe" title="Geographic centre of Europe">geographic centre of Europe</a> was in Lithuania, at <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Lithuania&amp;params=54_54_N_25_19_E_type:landmark&amp;title=Purnu%C5%A1k%C4%97s+%28centre+of+gravity%29"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">54&#176;54&#8242;N</span> <span class="longitude">25&#176;19&#8242;E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">&#65279; / &#65279;</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="vcard"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">54.900&#176;N 25.317&#176;E</span><span style="display:none">&#65279; / <span class="geo">54.900; 25.317</span></span><span style="display:none">&#65279; (<span class="fn org">Purnu&#353;k&#279;s (centre of gravity)</span>)</span></span></span></a></span>, 26 kilometres (16&#160;mi) north of Lithuania\'s capital city of <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Affholder accomplished this by calculating the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_of_gravity" title="Centre of gravity">centre of gravity</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Europe" title="Geography of Europe">geometrical figure</a> of Europe.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Lithuania#Climate" title="Geography of Lithuania">Geography of Lithuania &#167;&#160;Climate</a></div>\n<p>Lithuania\'s climate, which ranges between <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" title="Maritime climate">maritime</a> and <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental</a>, is relatively mild. Average temperatures on the coast are &#8722;2.5&#160;&#176;C (27.5&#160;&#176;F) in January and 16&#160;&#176;C (61&#160;&#176;F) in July. In Vilnius the average temperatures are &#8722;6&#160;&#176;C (21&#160;&#176;F) in January and 17&#160;&#176;C (63&#160;&#176;F) in July. During the summer, 20&#160;&#176;C (68&#160;&#176;F) is common during the day while 14&#160;&#176;C (57&#160;&#176;F) is common at night; in the past, temperatures have reached as high as 30 or 35&#160;&#176;C (86 or 95&#160;&#176;F). Some winters can be very cold. &#8722;20&#160;&#176;C (&#8722;4&#160;&#176;F) occurs almost every winter. Winter extremes are &#8722;34&#160;&#176;C (&#8722;29&#160;&#176;F) in coastal areas and &#8722;43&#160;&#176;C (&#8722;45&#160;&#176;F) in the east of Lithuania.\n</p><p>The average annual precipitation is 800&#160;mm (31.5&#160;in) on the coast, 900&#160;mm (35.4&#160;in) in the Samogitia highlands and 600&#160;mm (23.6&#160;in) in the eastern part of the country. Snow occurs every year, it can snow from October to April. In some years sleet can fall in September or May. The growing season lasts 202 days in the western part of the country and 169 days in the eastern part. Severe storms are rare in the eastern part of Lithuania but common in the coastal areas.\n</p><p>The longest records of measured temperature in the Baltic area cover about 250 years. The data show warm periods during the latter half of the 18th century, and that the 19th century was a relatively cool period. An early 20th century warming culminated in the 1930s, followed by a smaller cooling that lasted until the 1960s. A warming trend has persisted since then.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania experienced a drought in 2002, causing forest and <a href="/wiki/Peat" title="Peat">peat</a> bog fires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The country suffered along with the rest of Northwestern Europe during a heat wave in the summer of 2006.\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<table class="wikitable" style="width:100%; text-align:center; line-height: 1.2em; margin:auto;">\n<caption>Climate data for Lithuania\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th scope="row">Month\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Jan\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Feb\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Mar\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Apr\n</th>\n<th scope="col">May\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Jun\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Jul\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Aug\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Sep\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Oct\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Nov\n</th>\n<th scope="col">Dec\n</th>\n<th scope="col" style="border-left-width:medium">Year\n</th></tr>\n<tr style="text-align: center;">\n<th scope="row" style="height: 16px;">Record high &#176;C (&#176;F)\n</th>\n<td style="background: #FFC78F; color:#000000;">0.9<br/>(33.6)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #D7D7FF; color:#000000;">&#8722;2.9<br/>(26.8)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #C4C4FF; color:#000000;">&#8722;6.3<br/>(20.7)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #7D7DFF; color:#FFFFFF; border-left-width:medium">&#8722;42.9<br/>(&#8722;45.2)\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="text-align: center;">\n<th scope="row" style="height: 16px;">Average <a href="/wiki/Precipitation" title="Precipitation">precipitation</a> mm (inches)\n</th>\n<td style="background: #C9C9FF; color:#000000;">36.2<br/>(1.43)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #CDCDFF; color:#000000;">30.1<br/>(1.19)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #CCCCFF; color:#000000;">33.9<br/>(1.33)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #BCBCFF; color:#000000;">42.9<br/>(1.69)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #B1B1FF; color:#000000;">52.0<br/>(2.05)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #9494FF; color:#000000;">69.0<br/>(2.72)\n</td>\n<td style="background: #8C8CFF;
