color:#000000; border-left-width:medium">625.5<br/>(24.63)\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="14" style="text-align:center;font-size:95%;">Source #1: Records of Lithuanian climate<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-meteolt_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-meteolt-113">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="14" style="text-align:center; font-size:95%;">Source #2: Weatherbase<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weatherbase_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-weatherbase-115">[115]</a></sup>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Environment">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg/200px-%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg/300px-%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg/400px-%C5%BDadvaini%C5%B3_e%C5%BEeras.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">Typical Lithuanian flatlands with lakes, swamps and forests. Thousands of various lakes lies in Lithuania and creates magnificent sights from the bird\'s eye view.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nida_sand_dunes_(14573723178).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2315" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="94" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg/200px-Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg/300px-Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg/400px-Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">Sand dunes of the <a href="/wiki/Curonian_Spit" title="Curonian Spit">Curonian Spit</a> near <a href="/wiki/Nida,_Lithuania" title="Nida, Lithuania">Nida</a>, which are the highest drifting sand dunes in Europe (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>\n<p>After the restoration of Lithuania\'s independence in 1990, the <i>Aplinkos apsaugos &#303;statymas</i> (Environmental Protection Act) was adopted already in 1992. The law provided the foundations for regulating social relations in the field of environmental protection, established the basic rights and obligations of legal and natural persons in preserving the biodiversity inherent in Lithuania, ecological systems and the landscape.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Lithuania agreed to cut <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carbon_emissions" title="Carbon emissions">carbon emissions</a> by at least 20% of 1990 levels by the year 2020 and by at least 40% by the year 2030, together with all European Union members. Also, by 2020 at least 20% (27% by 2030) of country\'s total energy consumption should be from the <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In 2016, Lithuania introduced especially effective <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Container_deposit_legislation" title="Container deposit legislation">container deposit legislation</a>, which resulted in collecting 92% of all packagings in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania does not have high mountains and its landscape is dominated by blooming meadows, dense forests and fertile fields of cereals. However it stands out by the abundance of <a href="/wiki/Hillfort" title="Hillfort">hillforts</a>, which previously had castles where the ancient Lithuanians burned altars for pagan gods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gamta_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-gamta-120">[120]</a></sup> Lithuania is a particularly watered region with more than 3,000 lakes, mostly in northeastern Lithuania. Many rivers are also flowing in Lithuania, most notably the longest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nemunas" title="Nemunas">Nemunas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gamta_120-1"><a href="#cite_note-gamta-120">[120]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Forest has long been one of the most important natural resources in Lithuania. Forests occupy one third of the country\'s territory and timber-related industrial production accounts for almost 11% industrial production in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> Lithuania has five <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> 30 <a href="/wiki/Regional_park" title="Regional park">regional parks</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> 402 <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">nature reserves</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> 668 state-protected natural heritage objects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania is ranked 5th, second to Sweden (first 3 places are not granted) in Climate Change Performance Index (CCPI).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Biodiversity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Lithuania" title="Fauna of Lithuania">Fauna of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg/220px-White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg/330px-White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg/440px-White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:White_Stork-Mindaugas_Urbonas-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">White stork</a> is the national bird of Lithuania<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> and it has the highest-density stork population in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuanian ecosystems include natural and semi-natural (forests, bogs, wetlands, meadows), and anthropogenic (agrarian and urban) ecosystems. Among natural ecosystems, forests are particularly important to Lithuania, covering 33% of the country\'s territory. Wetlands (raised bogs, fens, transitional mires, etc.) cover 7.9% of the country, with 70% of wetlands having been lost due to drainage and peat extraction between 1960 and 1980. Changes in wetland plant communities resulted in the replacement of moss and grass communities by trees and shrubs, and fens not directly affected by land reclamation have become drier as a result of a drop in the water table. There are 29,000 rivers with a total length of 64,000&#160;km in Lithuania, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nemunas_River" title="Nemunas River">Nemunas River</a> basin occupying 74% of the territory of the country. Due to the construction of dams, approximately 70% of spawning sites of potential catadromous fish species have disappeared. In some cases, river and lake ecosystems continue to be impacted by anthropogenic eutrophication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-129">[129]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Agricultural land comprises 54% of Lithuania\'s territory (roughly 70% of that is arable land and 30% meadows and pastures), approximately 400,000 ha of agricultural land is not farmed, and acts as an ecological niche for weeds and invasive plant species. Habitat deterioration is occurring in regions with very productive and expensive lands as crop areas are expanded. Currently, 18.9% of all plant species, including 1.87% of all known fungi species and 31% of all known species of lichens, are listed in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_extinct_and_endangered_species_of_Lithuania" title="List of extinct and endangered species of Lithuania">Lithuanian Red Data Book</a>. The list also contains 8% of all fish species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd_129-1"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-129">[129]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The wildlife populations have rebounded as the hunting became more restricted and urbanization allowed replanting forests (forests already tripled in size since their lows). Currently, Lithuania has approximately 250,000 larger wild animals or 5 per each square kilometer. The most prolific large wild animal in every part of Lithuania is the <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">roe deer</a>, with 120,000 of them. They are followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boar" title="Boar">boars</a> (55,000). Other ungulates are the <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">deer</a> (~22,000), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fallow-deer" title="Fallow-deer">fallow-deer</a> (~21,000) and the largest one: <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">moose</a> (~7,000). Among the Lithuanian predators, <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">foxes</a> are the most common (~27,000). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wolve" title="Wolve">Wolves</a> are, however, more ingrained into the mythology as there are just 800 in Lithuania. Even rarer are the <a href="/wiki/Lynx" title="Lynx">lynxes</a> (~200). The large animals mentioned above exclude the <a href="/wiki/Rabbit" title="Rabbit">rabbit</a>, ~200,000 of which may live in the Lithuanian forests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Politics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Lithuania" title="Politics of Lithuania">Politics of Lithuania</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Lithuania" title="Government of Lithuania">Government of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg/220px-Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg/330px-Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg/440px-Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">Seimas</a> &#8212; (Parliament of Lithuania)</div></div></div>\n<p>Since Lithuania declared the restoration of its independence on 11 March 1990, it has maintained strong democratic traditions. It held its first independent general elections on 25 October 1992, in which 56.75% of voters supported the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">new constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referenda_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-referenda-131">[131]</a></sup> There were intense debates concerning the constitution, particularly the role of the president. A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_presidency_referendum,_1992" title="Lithuanian presidency referendum, 1992">separate referendum</a> was held on 23 May 1992 to gauge public opinion on the matter, and 41% of voters supported the restoration of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_Lithuania" title="President of Lithuania">President of Lithuania</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referenda_131-1"><a href="#cite_note-referenda-131">[131]</a></sup> Through compromise, a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a> was agreed on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lina_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lina-2">[2]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:right; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg"><img alt="Dalia Grybauskait&#279;.jpg" data-file-height="395" data-file-width="280" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg/125px-Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg/188px-Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg/250px-Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg 2x" width="125"/></a>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg"><img alt="Saulius Skvernelis.jpg" data-file-height="896" data-file-width="659" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg/131px-Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg/197px-Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg/262px-Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg 2x" width="131"/></a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskait&#279;">Dalia Grybauskait&#279;</a><br/><small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_Lithuania" title="President of Lithuania">President</a></small>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Saulius_Skvernelis" title="Saulius Skvernelis">Saulius Skvernelis</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Lithuania" title="Prime Minister of Lithuania">Prime Minister</a></small>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The Lithuanian <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> is the president, directly elected for a five-year term and serving a maximum of two terms. The president oversees foreign affairs and national security, and is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military. The president also appoints the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Lithuania" title="Prime Minister of Lithuania">prime minister</a> and, on the latter\'s nomination, the rest of the cabinet, as well as a number of other top civil servants and the judges for all courts.\n</p><p>The current Lithuanian head of state, <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskait&#279;">Dalia Grybauskait&#279;</a> was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_presidential_election,_2009" title="Lithuanian presidential election, 2009">elected on 17 May 2009</a>, becoming the first female president in the country\'s history, and the second female head of state in the Baltic States after <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> elected their first female political leader in 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Dalia Grybauskait&#279; was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_presidential_election,_2014" title="Lithuanian presidential election, 2014">re-elected for a second term in 2014</a>.\n</p><p>The judges of the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Lithuania" title="Constitutional Court of Lithuania">Constitutional Court</a> (<i>Konstitucinis Teismas</i>) serve nine-year terms. They are appointed by the President, the Chairman of the Seimas, and the Chairman of the Supreme Court, each of whom appoint three judges. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> Lithuanian parliament, the <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">Seimas</a>, has 141 members who are elected to four-year terms. 71 of the members of its members are elected in single member constituencies, and the others in a nationwide vote by <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>. A party must receive at least 5% of the national vote to be eligible for any of the 70 national seats in the Seimas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seimas_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-Seimas-133">[133]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_parties_and_elections">Political parties and elections</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Political parties and elections">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Lithuania" title="Elections in Lithuania">Elections in Lithuania</a></div>\n<p>Lithuania exhibits a fragmented multi-party system,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> with a number of small parties in which coalition governments are common. Ordinary elections to the <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">Seimas</a> take place on the second Sunday of October every four years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seimas_133-1"><a href="#cite_note-Seimas-133">[133]</a></sup> To be eligible for election, candidates must be at least 25 years old on the election day, not under allegiance to a foreign state and permanently reside in Lithuania. Persons serving or due to serve a sentence imposed by the court 65 days before the election are not eligible. Also, judges, citizens performing military service, and servicemen of professional military service and officials of statutory institutions and establishments may not stand for election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Peasant_and_Greens_Union" title="Lithuanian Peasant and Greens Union">Lithuanian Peasant and Greens Union</a> won the Lithuanian parliamentary election in 2016 and gained 54 of 141 seats in the parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_(2015).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_%282015%29.jpg/220px-Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_%282015%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_%282015%29.jpg/330px-Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_%282015%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_%282015%29.jpg/440px-Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_%282015%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Re-Establishment_of_Lithuania_commemoration_in_Seimas_(2015).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Commemoration of the <a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania</a> in the historical Seimas hall where it was originally signed in 1990. The ceremony is attended by the Lithuanian President, Prime Minister, Chairman of the Seimas and other high-ranking officials.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_Lithuania" title="President of Lithuania">President of Lithuania</a> is the head of state of the country, elected to a five-year term in a majority vote. Elections take place on the last Sunday no more than two months before the end of current presidential term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-137">[137]</a></sup> To be eligible for election, candidates must be at least 40 years old on the election day and reside in Lithuania for at least three years, in addition to satisfying the eligibility criteria for a member of the parliament. Same President may serve for not more than two terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskait&#279;">Dalia Grybauskait&#279;</a> has won two recent consecutive elections as an independent candidate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Each municipality in Lithuania is governed by a <a href="/wiki/Municipal_council" title="Municipal council">municipal council</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">mayor</a>, who is a member of the municipal council. The number of members, elected on a four-year term, in each municipal council depends on the size of the municipality and varies from 15 (in municipalities with fewer than 5,000 residents) to 51 (in municipalities with more than 500,000 residents). 1,524 municipal council members were elected in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> Members of the council, with the exception of the mayor, are elected using proportional representation. Starting with 2015, the mayor is elected directly by the majority of residents of the municipality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Lithuania" title="Social Democratic Party of Lithuania">Social Democratic Party of Lithuania</a> won most of the positions in the 2015 elections (372 municipal councils seats and 16 mayors).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>\n</p><p>As of 2014, the number of seats in the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> allocated to Lithuania was 11.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> Ordinary elections take place on a Sunday on the same day as in other EU countries. The vote is open to all citizens of Lithuania, as well as citizens of other EU countries that permanently reside in Lithuania, who are at least 18 years old on the election day. To be eligible for election, candidates must be at least 21 years old on the election day, citizen of Lithuania or citizen of another EU country permanently residing in Lithuania. Candidates are not allowed to stand for election in more than one country. Persons serving or due to serve a sentence imposed by the court 65 days before the election are not eligible. Also, judges, citizens performing military service, and servicemen of professional military service and officials of statutory institutions and establishments may not stand for election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> Seven political parties representatives gained seats in the 2014 elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_law_enforcement">Law and law enforcement</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Law and law enforcement">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Lithuania" title="Law of Lithuania">Law of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg/220px-Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg/330px-Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg/440px-Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_police_Audi_A6_in_Vilnius.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian Police officers</div></div></div>\n<p>After regaining of independence in 1990, the largely modified Soviet legal codes were in force for about a decade. The current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">Constitution of Lithuania</a> was adopted on 25 October 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> In 2001, the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Code_of_Lithuania" title="Civil Code of Lithuania">Civil Code of Lithuania</a> was passed in <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">Seimas</a>. It was succeeded by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criminal_Code" title="Criminal Code">Criminal Code</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criminal_Procedure" title="Criminal Procedure">Criminal Procedure</a> Code in 2003. The approach to the <a href="/wiki/Criminal_law" title="Criminal law">criminal law</a> is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inquisitorial" title="Inquisitorial">inquisitorial</a>, as opposed to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adversarial" title="Adversarial">adversarial</a>; it is generally characterised by an insistence on formality and rationalisation, as opposed to practicality and informality. Normative legal act enters into force on the next day after its publication in the <i>Teis&#279;s akt&#371; registras</i>, unless it has a later entry into force date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">European Union law</a> is an integral part of the Lithuanian legal system since 1 May 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania, after breaking away from the Soviet Union had a difficult crime situation, however the Lithuanian law enforcement agencies eliminated many criminals over the years, making Lithuania a reasonably safe country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Crime in Lithuania has been declining rapidly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Law enforcement in Lithuania is primarily the responsibility of local <i>Lietuvos policija</i> (Lithuanian Police) commissariats. They are supplemented by the <i>Lietuvos policijos antiteroristini&#371; operacij&#371; rinktin&#279; Aras</i> (Anti-Terrorist Operations Team of the Lithuanian Police <i>Aras</i>), <i>Lietuvos kriminalin&#279;s policijos biuras</i> (Lithuanian Criminal Police Bureau), <i>Lietuvos policijos kriminalistini&#371; tyrim&#371; centras</i> (Lithuanian Police Forensic Research Center) and <i>Lietuvos keli&#371; policijos tarnyba</i> (Lithuanian Road Police Service).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2017, there were 63,846 crimes registered in Lithuania. Of these, thefts comprised a large part with 19,630 cases (13.2% less than in 2016). While 2,835 crimes were very hard and hard (crimes that may result in more than six years imprisonment), which is 14.5% less than in 2016. Totally, 129 homicides or attempted homicide occurred (19.9% less than in 2016), while serious bodily harm was registered 178 times (17.6% less than in 2016). Another problematic crime <a href="/wiki/Contraband" title="Contraband">contraband</a> cases also decreased by 27.2% from 2016 numbers. Meanwhile, crimes in electronic data and information technology security fields noticeably increased by 26.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> In the 2013 Special Eurobarometer, 29% of Lithuanians said that corruption affects their daily lives (EU average 26%). Moreover, 95% of Lithuanians regarded corruption as widespread in their country (EU average 76%), and 88% agreed that bribery and the use of connections is often the easiest way of obtaining certain public services (EU average 73%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> Though, according to local branch of Transparency International, corruption levels have been decreasing over the past decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Lithuania" title="Capital punishment in Lithuania">Capital punishment in Lithuania</a> was suspended in 1996 and fully eliminated in 1998.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> Lithuania has the highest number of prison inmates in the EU. According to scientist Gintautas Sakalauskas, this is not because of a high criminality rate in the country, but due to Lithuania\'s high repression level and the lack of trust of the convicted, who are frequently sentenced to a jail imprisonment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Lithuania" title="Administrative divisions of Lithuania">Administrative divisions of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Lithuania" title="Counties of Lithuania">Counties of Lithuania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Lithuania" title="Municipalities of Lithuania">Municipalities of Lithuania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elderships_of_Lithuania" title="Elderships of Lithuania">Elderships of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="floatright noresize" role="img" style="width: 500px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Apskritis_of_Lithuania.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="556" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="371" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Apskritis_of_Lithuania.png/500px-Apskritis_of_Lithuania.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a2/Apskritis_of_Lithuania.png 1.5x" width="500"/></a>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:239px; top:317px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alytus_County_COA.png"><img alt="Alytus County COA.png" data-file-height="597" data-file-width="519" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Alytus_County_COA.png/15px-Alytus_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Alytus_County_COA.png/23px-Alytus_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Alytus_County_COA.png/30px-Alytus_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Alytus_County" title="Alytus County">Alytus County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:239px; top:202px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg"><img alt="LTU Kauno apskritis COA.svg" data-file-height="891" data-file-width="774" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg/15px-LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg/23px-LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg/30px-LTU_Kauno_apskritis_COA.svg.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Kaunas_County" title="Kaunas County">Kaunas County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:54px; top:127px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg"><img alt="LTU Klaip&#279;dos apskritis COA.svg" data-file-height="856" data-file-width="744" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg/15px-LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg/23px-LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg/30px-LTU_Klaip%C4%97dos_apskritis_COA.svg.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_County" title="Klaip&#279;da County">Klaip&#279;da<br/>County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:174px; top:242px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marijampole_County_COA.png"><img alt="Marijampole County COA.png" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="520" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Marijampole_County_COA.png/15px-Marijampole_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Marijampole_County_COA.png/23px-Marijampole_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Marijampole_County_COA.png/30px-Marijampole_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Marijampol%C4%97_County" title="Marijampol&#279; County">Marijampol&#279;<br/>County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:279px; top:77px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panevezys_County_COA.png"><img alt="Panevezys County COA.png" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="522" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Panevezys_County_COA.png/15px-Panevezys_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Panevezys_County_COA.png/23px-Panevezys_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Panevezys_County_COA.png/30px-Panevezys_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys_County" title="Panev&#279;&#382;ys County">Panev&#279;&#382;ys County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:179px; top:82px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Siauliai_County_COA.png"><img alt="Siauliai County COA.png" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="522" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Siauliai_County_COA.png/15px-Siauliai_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Siauliai_County_COA.png/23px-Siauliai_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Siauliai_County_COA.png/30px-Siauliai_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai_County" title="&#352;iauliai County">&#352;iauliai County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:104px; top:162px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taurage_County_COA.png"><img alt="Taurage County COA.png" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="522" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Taurage_County_COA.png/15px-Taurage_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Taurage_County_COA.png/23px-Taurage_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Taurage_County_COA.png/30px-Taurage_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Taurag%C4%97_County" title="Taurag&#279; County">Taurag&#279; County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:89px; top:77px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Telsiai_County_COA.png"><img alt="Telsiai County COA.png" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="520" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Telsiai_County_COA.png/15px-Telsiai_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Telsiai_County_COA.png/23px-Telsiai_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Telsiai_County_COA.png/30px-Telsiai_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Tel%C5%A1iai_County" title="Tel&#353;iai County">Tel&#353;iai County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:354px; top:137px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Utena_County_COA.png"><img alt="Utena County COA.png" data-file-height="597" data-file-width="522" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Utena_County_COA.png/15px-Utena_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Utena_County_COA.png/23px-Utena_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Utena_County_COA.png/30px-Utena_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Utena_County" title="Utena County">Utena County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:319px; top:242px"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vilnius_County_COA.png"><img alt="Vilnius County COA.png" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="534" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Vilnius_County_COA.png/15px-Vilnius_County_COA.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Vilnius_County_COA.png/23px-Vilnius_County_COA.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Vilnius_County_COA.png/30px-Vilnius_County_COA.png 2x" width="15"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Vilnius_County" title="Vilnius County">Vilnius County</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:-11px; top:117px"><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_sea" title="Baltic sea"><span style="color: #3399cc;">Baltic sea</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:369px; top:22px"><i><a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia"><span style="color: grey;">Latvia</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:444px; top:242px"><i><a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus"><span style="color: grey;">Belarus</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:144px; top:342px"><i><a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland"><span style="color: grey;">Poland</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:94px; top:242px"><i><a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia"><span style="color: grey;">Russia</span></a></i></div>\n</div>\n<p>The current system of administrative division was established in 1994 and modified in 2000 to meet the requirements of the European Union. The country\'s <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Lithuania" title="Counties of Lithuania">10 counties</a> (Lithuanian: singular &#8211; <i>apskritis</i>, plural &#8211; <i>apskritys</i>) are subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Lithuania" title="Municipalities of Lithuania">60 municipalities</a> (Lithuanian: singular &#8211; <i>savivaldyb&#279;</i>, plural &#8211; <i>savivaldyb&#279;s</i>), and further divided into 500 <a href="/wiki/Elderships_of_Lithuania" title="Elderships of Lithuania">elderships</a> (Lithuanian: singular &#8211; <i>seni&#363;nija</i>, plural &#8211; <i>seni&#363;nijos</i>).\n</p><p>Municipalities have been the most important unit of administration in Lithuania since the system of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/County_governor_(Lithuania)" title="County governor (Lithuania)">county governorship</a> (<i>apskrities vir&#353;ininkas</i>) was dissolved in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-county_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-county-157">[157]</a></sup> Some municipalities are historically called "district municipalities" (often shortened to "district"), while others are called "city municipalities" (sometimes shortened to "city"). Each has its own elected government. The election of municipality councils originally occurred every three years, but now takes place every four years. The council appoints <a href="/wiki/Elder_(administrative_title)" title="Elder (administrative title)">elders</a> to govern the elderships. Mayors have been directly elected since 2015; prior to that, they were appointed by the council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Elderships, numbering over 500, are the smallest administrative units and do not play a role in national politics. They provide necessary local public services&#8212;for example, registering births and deaths in rural areas. They are most active in the social sector, identifying needy individuals or families and organizing and distributing welfare and other forms of relief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-elderates_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-elderates-159">[159]</a></sup> Some citizens feel that elderships have no real power and receive too little attention, and that they could otherwise become a source of local initiative for addressing rural problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th style="width:140px;">County</th>\n<th style="width:70px;">Area (km&#178;)</th>\n<th style="width:50px;">Population (thousands) in 2017<sup id="cite_ref-Counties_161-1"><a href="#cite_note-Counties-161">[161]</a></sup></th>\n<th style="width:50px;">Nominal GDP per capita EUR in 2017<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Counties_161-2"><a County</a>\n</td>\n<td>7,881\n</td>\n<td>222\n</td>\n<td>2.5\n</td>\n<td>11,000\n</td>\n<td>24,100\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td><a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai_County" title="&#352;iauliai
