County">Taurag&#279; County</a>\n</td>\n<td>4,411\n</td>\n<td>97\n</td>\n<td>0.8\n</td>\n<td>8,200\n</td>\n<td>17,900\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Tel%C5%A1iai_County" title="Tel&#353;iai County">Tel&#353;iai County</a>\n</td>\n<td>4,350\n</td>\n<td>136\n</td>\n<td>1.5\n</td>\n<td>10,700\n</td>\n<td>23,400\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Utena_County" title="Utena County">Utena County</a>\n</td>\n<td>7,201\n</td>\n<td>132\n</td>\n<td>1.2\n</td>\n<td>9,100\n</td>\n<td>19,900\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Vilnius_County" title="Vilnius County">Vilnius County</a>\n</td>\n<td>9,729\n</td>\n<td>805\n</td>\n<td>17.2\n</td>\n<td>21,300\n</td>\n<td>46,600\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Lithuania\n</th>\n<th>65,300\n</th>\n<th>2,828\n</th>\n<th>42.2\n</th>\n<th>14,900\n</th>\n<th>32,600\n</th></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Lithuania" title="Foreign relations of Lithuania">Foreign relations of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1959" data-file-width="2942" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg/220px-Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg/330px-Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg/440px-Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuania is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_State_of_the_European_Union" title="Member State of the European Union">member of the European Union</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania became a member of the United Nations on 18 September 1991, and is a signatory to a number of its organizations and other international agreements. It is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe">Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> and its adjunct North Atlantic Coordinating Council. Lithuania gained membership in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> on 31 May 2001, and joined the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> on 5 July 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lithuania\'s_accession_to_the_OECD_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lithuania\'s_accession_to_the_OECD-163">[163]</a></sup> while also seeking membership in other Western organizations.\n</p><p>Lithuania has established diplomatic relations with 149 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2011, Lithuania hosted the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> Ministerial Council Meeting. During the second half of 2013, Lithuania assumed the role of the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">presidency of the European Union</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="614" data-file-width="858" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/220px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/330px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/440px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The stamp is dedicated to Lithuania\'s presidency of the European Union. Post of Lithuania, 2013.</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania is also active in developing cooperation among northern European countries. It has been a member of the Baltic Council since its establishment in 1993. The Baltic Council, located in <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>, is a permanent organisation of international cooperation that operates through the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Assembly" title="Baltic Assembly">Baltic Assembly</a> and the Baltic Council of Ministers.\n</p><p>Lithuania also cooperates with Nordic and the two other Baltic countries through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NB8" title="NB8">NB8</a> format. A similar format, NB6, unites Nordic and Baltic members of EU. NB6\'s focus is to discuss and agree on positions before presenting them to the Council of the European Union and at the meetings of EU foreign affairs ministers.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Baltic_Sea_States" title="Council of the Baltic Sea States">Council of the Baltic Sea States</a> (CBSS) was established in <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> in 1992 as an informal regional political forum. Its main aim is to promote integration and to close contacts between the region\'s countries. The members of CBSS are Iceland, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Germany, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Poland, Russia, and the European Commission. Its observer states are Belarus, France, Italy, Netherlands, Romania, Slovakia, Spain, the United States, the United Kingdom, and Ukraine.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Council" title="Nordic Council">Nordic Council of Ministers</a> and Lithuania engage in political cooperation to attain mutual goals and to determine new trends and possibilities for joint cooperation. The Council\'s information office aims to disseminate <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">Nordic</a> concepts and to demonstrate and promote Nordic cooperation.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_(2015).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1227" data-file-width="2126" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_%282015%29.jpg/220px-Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_%282015%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_%282015%29.jpg/330px-Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_%282015%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_%282015%29.jpg/440px-Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_%282015%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bachelet_en_Consejo_de_Seguridad_de_la_ONU_(2015).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuania was recently a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>. Its representatives are on the right side.</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania, together with the five Nordic countries and the two other Baltic countries, is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">Nordic Investment Bank (NIB)</a> and cooperates in its NORDPLUS programme, which is committed to education.\n</p><p>The Baltic Development Forum (BDF) is an independent nonprofit organization that unites large companies, cities, business associations and institutions in the Baltic Sea region. In 2010 the BDF\'s 12th summit was held in Vilnius.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania maintains greatly warm mutual relations with <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> and strongly supports its European Union and NATO aspirations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Georgian_War" title="Russo-Georgian War">Russo-Georgian War</a> in 2008, when the Russian troops were occupying the territory of Georgia and approaching towards the Georgian capital <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a>, President <a href="/wiki/Valdas_Adamkus" title="Valdas Adamkus">Valdas Adamkus</a>, together with the Polish and Ukrainian presidents, went to Tbilisi by answering to the Georgians request of the international assistance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Shortly, Lithuanians and the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Lithuania" title="Catholic Church in Lithuania">Lithuanian Catholic Church</a> also began collecting financial support for the war victims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2004&#8211;2009, <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskait&#279;">Dalia Grybauskait&#279;</a> served as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Financial_Programming_and_the_Budget" title="European Commissioner for Financial Programming and the Budget">European Commissioner for Financial Programming and the Budget</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Manuel_Barroso" title="Jos&#233; Manuel Barroso">Jos&#233; Manuel Barroso</a>-led Commission.\n</p><p>In 2013, Lithuania was elected to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> for a two-year term,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> becoming the first <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic</a> country elected to this post. During its membership, Lithuania actively supported <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and often condemned <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014&#8211;present)">military intervention in Ukraine</a>, immediately earning vast Ukrainians esteem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> As the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">War in Donbass</a> progressed, President Dalia Grybauskait&#279; has compared the Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Josef_Stalin" title="Josef Stalin">Josef Stalin</a> and to <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>, she has also called Russia a "terrorist state".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup>\nIn 2018 Lithuania, along with Latvia and Estonia were awarded the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Peace_of_Westphalia_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Peace of Westphalia Prize (page does not exist)">Peace of Westphalia Prize</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationaler_Preis_des_Westf%C3%A4lischen_Friedens" title="de:Internationaler Preis des Westf&#228;lischen Friedens">de</a>]</span> &#8211; for their exceptional model of democratic development and contribution to peace in the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Military">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Armed_Forces" title="Lithuanian Armed Forces">Lithuanian Armed Forces</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1983" data-file-width="4039" decoding="async" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg/220px-Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg/330px-Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg/440px-Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Closing_ceremony_for_Iron_Sword_2014.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian Army soldiers with their <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> allies during Iron Sword 2014</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_(8123251773).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2241" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg/220px-Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg/330px-Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg/440px-Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_(8123251773).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian Army soldiers marching with their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dress_uniform" title="Dress uniform">dress uniforms</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>. An <a href="/wiki/Officer_(armed_forces)" title="Officer (armed forces)">officer</a> stands out with a <a href="/wiki/Sword" title="Sword">sword</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The Lithuanian Armed Forces is the name for the unified armed forces of <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Land_Force" title="Lithuanian Land Force">Lithuanian Land Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Air_Force" title="Lithuanian Air Force">Lithuanian Air Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Naval_Force" title="Lithuanian Naval Force">Lithuanian Naval Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Special_Operations_Force" title="Lithuanian Special Operations Force">Lithuanian Special Operations Force</a> and other units: Logistics Command, Training and Doctrine Command, Headquarters Battalion, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Lithuania)" title="Military Police (Lithuania)">Military Police</a>. Directly subordinated to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_of_Defence" title="Chief of Defence">Chief of Defence</a> are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_Operations_Forces" title="Special Operations Forces">Special Operations Forces</a> and Military Police. The Reserve Forces are under command of the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Defence_Volunteer_Forces" title="Lithuanian National Defence Volunteer Forces">Lithuanian National Defence Volunteer Forces</a>.\n</p><p>The Lithuanian Armed Forces consist of some 17,000 active personnel, which may be supported by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reserve_forces" title="Reserve forces">reserve forces</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> Compulsory <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> ended in 2008 but was reintroduced in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> The Lithuanian Armed Forces currently have deployed personnel on international missions in Afghanistan, Kosovo, Mali and Somalia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In March 2004, Lithuania became a full member of the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. Since then, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fighter_jets" title="Fighter jets">fighter jets</a> of NATO members are deployed in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zokniai_airport" title="Zokniai airport">Zokniai airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Air_Policing" title="Baltic Air Policing">provide safety for the Baltic airspace</a>.\n</p><p>Since the summer of 2005 Lithuania has been part of the <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a> in Afghanistan (ISAF), leading a <a href="/wiki/Provincial_Reconstruction_Team" title="Provincial Reconstruction Team">Provincial Reconstruction Team</a> (PRT) in the town of <a href="/wiki/Chaghcharan" title="Chaghcharan">Chaghcharan</a> in the province of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghor" title="Ghor">Ghor</a>. The PRT includes personnel from <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>, Iceland and USA. There are also <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Special_Operations_Force" title="Lithuanian Special Operations Force">special operation forces</a> units in Afghanistan, placed in <a href="/wiki/Kandahar_Province" title="Kandahar Province">Kandahar Province</a>. Since joining international operations in 1994, Lithuania has lost two soldiers: 1st Lt. Normundas Valteris fell in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosnia" title="Bosnia">Bosnia</a>, as his patrol vehicle drove over a mine. Sgt. Ar&#363;nas Jarmalavi&#269;ius was fatally wounded during an attack on the camp of his Provincial Reconstruction Team in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Lithuanian National Defence Policy aims to guarantee the preservation of the <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">independence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> of the state, the <a href="/wiki/Integrity" title="Integrity">integrity</a> of its land, territorial waters and airspace, and its constitutional order. Its main strategic goals are to defend the country\'s interests, and to maintain and expand the capabilities of its armed forces so they may contribute to and participate in the missions of NATO and European Union member states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WB_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-WB-182">[182]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_of_the_Republic_of_Lithuania" title="Ministry of Defense of the Republic of Lithuania">defense ministry</a> is responsible for combat forces, <a href="/wiki/Search_and_rescue" title="Search and rescue">search and rescue</a>, and intelligence operations. The 5,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_Border_Guard_Service_(Lithuania)" title="State Border Guard Service (Lithuania)">border guards</a> fall under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interior_Ministry" title="Interior Ministry">Interior Ministry</a>\'s supervision and are responsible for border protection, passport and customs duties, and share responsibility with the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Naval_Force" title="Lithuanian Naval Force">navy</a> for <a href="/wiki/Smuggling" title="Smuggling">smuggling</a> and drug trafficking interdiction. A special security department handles VIP protection and <a href="/wiki/Communications_security" title="Communications security">communications security</a>. In 2015 <a href="/wiki/National_Cyber_Security_Centre_of_Lithuania" title="National Cyber Security Centre of Lithuania">National Cyber Security Centre of Lithuania</a> was created. Paramilitary organisation <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Riflemen%27s_Union" title="Lithuanian Riflemen\'s Union">Lithuanian Riflemen\'s Union</a> acts as civilian self-defence institution.\n</p><p>According to NATO, in 2017 Lithuania allocated 1.77% of its <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> to the national defense. For a long time Lithuania lagged behind NATO allies in terms of defense spending, but in recent years it has begun to rapidly increase the funding. In 2018 Lithuania intends to allocate 2.06% of its <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> to the defense sector and reach the required funding standard for NATO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Lithuania" title="Economy of Lithuania">Economy of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GNI-2016-Lithuania.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="420" data-file-width="743" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/GNI-2016-Lithuania.png/220px-GNI-2016-Lithuania.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/GNI-2016-Lithuania.png/330px-GNI-2016-Lithuania.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/GNI-2016-Lithuania.png/440px-GNI-2016-Lithuania.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GNI-2016-Lithuania.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuania, GNI per capita, PPP (current international $), 2016<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="690" data-file-width="645" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/220px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/330px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/440px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuania is part of a monetary union, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> (dark blue), and of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" title="Internal Market (European Union)">EU single market</a>.</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5864" data-file-width="5239" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg/200px-Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg/300px-Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg/400px-Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Countries_with_larger_GDP_PPP_per_capita_than_Lithuania_in_1995_vs_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Countries with larger GDP PPP per capita than Lithuania in 1995 vs 2017<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Exports-2016-Lithuania.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="595" data-file-width="1366" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Exports-2016-Lithuania.png/220px-Exports-2016-Lithuania.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Exports-2016-Lithuania.png/330px-Exports-2016-Lithuania.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Exports-2016-Lithuania.png/440px-Exports-2016-Lithuania.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Exports-2016-Lithuania.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>What does Lithuania export? (2016)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania has open and <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> that is classified as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-income_economy" title="High-income economy">high-income economy</a> by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> \nAccording to data from 2016, the three largest sectors in Lithuanian economy are &#8211; services (68.3% of GDP), industry (28.5%) and agriculture (3.3%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup><a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum\'s</a> <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">Global Competitiveness Report</a> ranks Lithuania 41st (of 137 ranked countries).\n</p><p>Lithuania joined NATO in 2004,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> EU in 2004,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen</a> in 2007<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lithuania\'s_accession_to_the_OECD_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lithuania\'s_accession_to_the_OECD-163">[163]</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 1 January 2015, euro became the national currency replacing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Litas" title="Litas">litas</a> at the rate of EUR 1.00 = LTL 3.45280.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iso4217news2014_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-iso4217news2014-192">[192]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Agricultural products and food made 18.3%, chemical products and plastics &#8211; 17.8%, machinery and appliances &#8211; 15.8%, mineral products &#8211; 14.7%, wood and furniture &#8211; 12.5% of exports.\n<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> According to data from 2016, more than half of all Lithuanian exports go to 7 countries including Russia (14%), Latvia (9,9%), Poland (9,1%), Germany (7,7%), Estonia (5,3%), Sweden (4,8%) and United Kingdom (4,3%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> Export generated 74 percent of Lithuania\'s GDP in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuanian GDP experienced very high real growth rates for decade up to 2009, peaking at 11.1% in 2007. As a result, the country was often termed as a <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Tiger" title="Baltic Tiger">Baltic Tiger</a>. However, in 2009 due to a <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007&#8211;2008">global financial crisis</a> marked experienced a drastic decline &#8211; GDP contracted by 14.9%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> and unemployment rate reached 17.8% in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> After the decline of 2009, Lithuanian annual economic growth has been much slower compared to pre-2009 years. According to IMF, financial conditions are conducive to growth and financial soundness indicators remain strong. The public debt ratio in 2016 fell to 40 percent of GDP, to compare with 42.7 in 2015 (before global finance crisis &#8211; 15 percent of GDP in 2008).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup>\n</p><p>On average, more than 95% of all <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> in Lithuania comes from <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> countries. Sweden is historically the largest investor with 20% &#8211; 30% of all FDI in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> FDI into Lithuania spiked in 2017, reaching its highest ever recorded number of greenfield investment projects. In 2017, Lithuania was third country, after <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a> by the average job value of investment projects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>\nThe US was the leading source country in 2017, 24.59% of total FDI. Next up are Germany and the UK, each representing 11.48% of total project numbers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Based on the Eurostat\'s data, in 2017, the value of Lithuanian exports recorded the most rapid growth not only in the Baltic countries, but also across Europe, which was 16.9 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the period between 2004 and 2016, one out of five Lithuanians left the country, mostly because of insufficient income situation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> or seeking the new experience and studies abroad. Long term emigration and economy growth has resulted in noticeable shortages on the labor market<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> and growth in salaries being larger than growth in labor efficiency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive_org_11_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-archive_org_11-205">[205]</a></sup> Unemployment rate in 2017 was 8.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup>\n</p><p>As of 2018, Lithuanian mean wealth per adult is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USD" title="USD">$</a>24,600, while total national wealth is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">US$</a>57 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> As of third quarter of 2018, the average gross (pre-tax) monthly salary in Lithuania is 935 euros(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">US$</a>1,064) translating to 728 euros net (after tax),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-https://osp.stat.gov.lt_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-https://osp.stat.gov.lt-208">[208]</a></sup> while average pension is 307 euros per month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage" title="List of countries by average wage">Average wage</a> adjusted for <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>, is around 1912 USD per month, one of the lowest in EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> Although, <a href="/wiki/Cost_of_living" title="Cost of living">cost of living</a> in the country also is sufficiently less with the price level for <a href="/wiki/Household_final_consumption_expenditure" title="Household final consumption expenditure">household final consumption expenditure</a> (HFCE) &#8211; 63, being 39% lower than EU average &#8211; 102 in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania has a <a href="/wiki/Flat_tax" title="Flat tax">flat tax</a> rate rather than a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Graduated_tax" title="Graduated tax">progressive scheme</a>. According to Eurostat,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu-212">[212]</a></sup> the personal income tax (15%) and corporate tax (15%) rates in Lithuania are among the lowest in the EU. The country has the lowest implicit rate of tax on capital (9.8%) in the EU. Corporate tax rate in Lithuania is 15% and 5% for small businesses. 7 <a href="/wiki/Free_economic_zone" title="Free economic zone">Free Economic Zones</a> are operating in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">Information technology</a> production is growing in the country, reaching 1.9 billion euros in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> In 2017 only, 35\n<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FinTech" title="FinTech">FinTech</a> companies came to Lithuania &#8211; a result of Lithuanian government and Bank of Lithuania simplified procedures for obtaining licences for the activities of e-money and payment institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> Europe\'s first international Blockchain Centre launched in Vilnius in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> Lithuania has granted a total of 39 e-money licenses, second in the EU only to the U.K. with 128 licenses. In 2018 <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> setup a payment company in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup>\n</p><p><br/>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Companies">Companies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Companies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Biggest companies in Lithuania in 2016, by revenue:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg/220px-Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg/330px-Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg/440px-Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nerijus_Numavi%C4%8Dius" title="Nerijus Numavi&#269;ius">Nerijus Numavi&#269;ius</a> is the wealthiest Lithuanian and is the first Baltic states billionaire included in <a href="/wiki/The_World%27s_Billionaires" title="The World\'s Billionaires">The Forbes World\'s Billionaires list</a>.</div></div></div>\n<table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;">\n<tbody><tr style="background:#efefef;">\n<th style="text-align:center;">Rank</th>\n<th style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a></td>\n<td>650.063</td>\n<td>107.425</td>\n<td>2.711\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;"><span style="text-align:left;">Girteka logistics, UAB</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius"
