style="text-align:left;">Norfos ma&#382;mena, UAB</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a></td>\n<td>409.921</td>\n<td>9.151</td>\n<td>3.332\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;"><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>8.</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;">Linas Agro, AB</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys" title="Panev&#279;&#382;ys">Panev&#279;&#382;ys</a></td>\n<td>390.412</td>\n<td>4.942</td>\n<td>131\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;"><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>9.</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;">Rivona, UAB</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a></td>\n<td>384.043</td>\n<td>2.046</td>\n<td>1.025\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;"><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>10.</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;">Agrorodeo, UAB</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a></td>\n<td>376.929</td>\n<td>5.635</td>\n<td>33\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Agriculture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Lithuania" title="Agriculture in Lithuania">Agriculture in Lithuania</a></div>\n<p>Agriculture in Lithuania dates to the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> period, about 3,000 to 1,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Before_Christ" title="Before Christ">BC</a>. It has been one of Lithuania\'s most important occupations for many centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> Lithuania\'s accession to the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2004 ushered in a new agricultural era. The EU pursues a very high standard of food safety and purity. In 1999, the <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">Seimas</a> (parliament) of Lithuania adopted a Law on Product Safety, and in 2000 it adopted a Law on Food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> The reform of the agricultural market has been carried out on the basis of these two laws.\n</p><p>In 2016, agricultural production was made for 2.29 billion euros in Lithuania. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cereal_crops" title="Cereal crops">Cereal crops</a> occupied the largest part of it (5709,7 tons), other significant types were <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">sugar beets</a> (933,9 tons), <a href="/wiki/Rapeseed" title="Rapeseed">rapeseed</a> (392,5 tons) and <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potatoes</a> (340,2 tons). Products for 4385,2 million euros were exported from Lithuania to the foreign markets, of which products for 3165,2 million euros were Lithuanian origin. Export of agricultural and food products accounted for 19.4% of all exports of goods from the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Organic_farming" title="Organic farming">Organic farming</a> is constantly becoming more popular in Lithuania. The status of organic growers and producers in the country is granted by the public body <i>Ekoagros</i>. In 2016, there were 2539 such farms that occupied 225541,78 hectares. Of these, 43,13% were cereals, 31,22% were perennial grasses, 13,9% were leguminous crops and 11,75% were others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Science and technology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:208px;max-width:208px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:42px;max-width:42px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Siemenowicz_rocket.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="582" data-file-width="99" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Siemenowicz_rocket.png/40px-Siemenowicz_rocket.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Siemenowicz_rocket.png/60px-Siemenowicz_rocket.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Siemenowicz_rocket.png/80px-Siemenowicz_rocket.png 2x" width="40"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:162px;max-width:162px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="2205" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg/160px-Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg/240px-Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg/320px-Skylab-73-HC-440HR.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:">Lithuanian <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bajoras" title="Bajoras">bajoras</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Artillery" title="Artillery">artillery</a> expert <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kazimieras_Simonavi%C4%8Dius" title="Kazimieras Simonavi&#269;ius">Kazimieras Simonavi&#269;ius</a> is an inventor of a <a href="/wiki/Multistage_rocket" title="Multistage rocket">multistage rocket</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Foundation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Vilnius" title="University of Vilnius">University of Vilnius</a> in 1579 was a major factor of establishing local scientist community in Lithuania and making connections with other universities and scientists of Europe. <a href="/wiki/Georg_Forster" title="Georg Forster">Georg Forster</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean-Emmanuel_Gilibert" title="Jean-Emmanuel Gilibert">Jean-Emmanuel Gilibert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johann_Peter_Frank" title="Johann Peter Frank">Johann Peter Frank</a> and many other visiting scientists have worked at University of Vilnius.\nLithuanian <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bajoras" title="Bajoras">bajoras</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> artillery expert <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kazimieras_Simonavi%C4%8Dius" title="Kazimieras Simonavi&#269;ius">Kazimieras Simonavi&#269;ius</a> is a pioneer of <a href="/wiki/Rocket" title="Rocket">rocketry</a>, who has published <i>Artis Magnae Artilleriae</i> in 1650 that for over two centuries was used in Europe as a basic <a href="/wiki/Artillery" title="Artillery">artillery</a> manual and contains a large chapter on caliber, construction, production and properties of rockets (for military and civil purposes), including <a href="/wiki/Multistage_rocket" title="Multistage rocket">multistage rockets</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rocket_battery" title="Rocket battery">batteries of rockets</a>, and rockets with <a href="/wiki/Delta_wing" title="Delta wing">delta wing</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stabilizer_(aircraft)" title="Stabilizer (aircraft)">stabilizers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> A botanist Jurgis Pabr&#279;&#382;a (1771-1849), created first systematic guide of Lithuanian flora <i>Taislius auguminis</i> (<i>Botany</i>), written in Samogitian dialect, the Latin-Lithuanian dictionary of plant names, first Lithuanian textbook of geography.\n</p><p>During the Interwar period humanitarian and social scientists emerged such as <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Seseman" title="Vasily Seseman">Vosylius Sezemanas</a>, Levas Karsavinas, <a href="/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Pius_R%C3%B6mer" title="Micha&#322; Pius R&#246;mer">Mykolas R&#246;meris</a>.\nDue to the World Wars, Lithuanian science and scientists suffered heavily from the occupants, however some of them reached a world-class achievements in their lifetime. Most notably, <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Gustaitis" title="Antanas Gustaitis">Antanas Gustaitis</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vytautas_Grai%C4%8Di%C5%ABnas" title="Vytautas Grai&#269;i&#363;nas">Vytautas Grai&#269;i&#363;nas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marija_Gimbutas" title="Marija Gimbutas">Marija Gimbutas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Birut%C4%97_Galdikas" title="Birut&#279; Galdikas">Birut&#279; Galdikas</a>, A. J. Klior&#279;, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Algirdas_Julius_Greimas" title="Algirdas Julius Greimas">Algirdas Julius Greimas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medieval_studies" title="Medieval studies">medievalist</a> <a href="/wiki/Jurgis_Baltru%C5%A1aitis_(son)" title="Jurgis Baltru&#353;aitis (son)">Jurgis Baltru&#353;aitis</a>, Algirdas Antanas Avi&#382;ienis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup>\n<a href="/wiki/Jonas_Kubilius" title="Jonas Kubilius">Jonas Kubilius</a>, long-term rector of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Vilnius" title="University of Vilnius">University of Vilnius</a> is known for works in <a href="/wiki/Probabilistic_number_theory" title="Probabilistic number theory">Probabilistic number theory</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kubilius_model" title="Kubilius model">Kubilius model</a>, Theorem of Kubilius and <a href="/wiki/Tur%C3%A1n%E2%80%93Kubilius_inequality" title="Tur&#225;n&#8211;Kubilius inequality">Tur&#225;n&#8211;Kubilius inequality</a> bear his name. Jonas Kubilius successfully resisted attempts to Russify the University of Vilnius.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Nowadays, the country is among moderate innovators group in the <a href="/wiki/International_Innovation_Index" title="International Innovation Index">International Innovation Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup>\nand in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Innovation_Scoreboard" title="European Innovation Scoreboard">European Innovation Scoreboard</a> ranked 15th among EU countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">Lasers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a> are flagship fields of the Lithuanian science and high tech industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> Lithuanian "&#352;viesos konversija" (Light Conversion) has developed a femtosecond laser system that has 80% marketshare worldwide, and is used in DNA research, ophthalmological surgeries, nanotech industry and science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">Vilnius University</a> Laser Research Center has developed one of the most powerful femtosecond lasers in the world dedicated primarily to <a href="/wiki/Oncology" title="Oncology">oncological diseases</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> In 1963, <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Strai%C5%BEys" title="Vytautas Strai&#382;ys">Vytautas Strai&#382;ys</a> and his coworkers created <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_photometric_system" title="Vilnius photometric system">Vilnius photometric system</a> that is used in <a href="/wiki/Astronomy" title="Astronomy">astronomy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> Noninvasive intracranial pressure and blood flow measuring devices were developed by <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_University_of_Technology" title="Kaunas University of Technology">KTU</a> scientist A. Ragauskas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> K.Pyragas contributed to <a href="/wiki/Control_of_chaos" title="Control of chaos">Control of chaos</a> with his way of delayed feedback control &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Pyragas_method" title="Pyragas method">Pyragas method</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kavli_Prize" title="Kavli Prize">Kavli Prize</a> laureate <a href="/wiki/Virginijus_%C5%A0ik%C5%A1nys" title="Virginijus &#352;ik&#353;nys">Virginijus &#352;ik&#353;nys</a> is known for his discoveries in <a href="/wiki/CRISPR" title="CRISPR">CRISPR</a> field &#8211; invention of CRISPR-<a href="/wiki/Cas9" title="Cas9">Cas9</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania has launched three satellites to the cosmos: <a href="/wiki/LitSat-1" title="LitSat-1">LitSat-1</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lituanica_SAT-1" title="Lituanica SAT-1">Lituanica SAT-1</a> and <a href="/wiki/LituanicaSAT-2" title="LituanicaSAT-2">LituanicaSAT-2</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Museum_of_Ethnocosmology" title="Lithuanian Museum of Ethnocosmology">Lithuanian Museum of Ethnocosmology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mol%C4%97tai_Astronomical_Observatory" title="Mol&#279;tai Astronomical Observatory">Mol&#279;tai Astronomical Observatory</a> is located in <a href="/wiki/Kulionys" title="Kulionys">Kulionys</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> 15 R&amp;D institutions are members of <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Space_Association" title="Lithuanian Space Association">Lithuanian Space Association</a>; Lithuania is a cooperating state with <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rimantas_Stankevi%C4%8Dius" title="Rimantas Stankevi&#269;ius">Rimantas Stankevi&#269;ius</a> is the only ethnically Lithuanian <a href="/wiki/Astronaut" title="Astronaut">astronaut</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania in 2018 became Associated Member State of <a href="/wiki/CERN" title="CERN">CERN</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Most advanced scientific research in Lithuania is being conducted at the Life Sciences Center,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> Center For Physical Sciences and Technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> <i>Brolis Semiconductors</i> producing beyond state-of-the-art technology solutions for security and medical sensing applications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup>\n</p><p>As of 2016 calculations, yearly growth of Lithuania\'s biotech and life science sector was 22% over the past 5 years. 16 academic institutions, 15 R&amp;D centres (science parks and innovation valleys) and more than 370 manufacturers operate in the Lithuanian life science and biotech industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2008 the Valley development programme was started aiming to upgrade Lithuanian scientific research infrastructure and encourage business and science cooperation. Five R&amp;D Valleys were launched &#8211; J&#363;rinis (maritime technologies), Nemunas (agro, bioenergy, forestry), Saul&#279;tekis (laser and light, semiconductor), Santara (biotechnology, medicine), Santaka (sustainable chemistry and pharmacy).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> Lithuanian Innovation Center<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> is created to provide support for innovations and research institutions.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Lithuania" title="Tourism in Lithuania">Tourism in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Druskininkai_fountain.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2912" data-file-width="4368" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Druskininkai_fountain.jpg/220px-Druskininkai_fountain.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Druskininkai_fountain.jpg/330px-Druskininkai_fountain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Druskininkai_fountain.jpg/440px-Druskininkai_fountain.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Druskininkai_fountain.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Druskininkai" title="Druskininkai">Druskininkai</a> is a popular <a href="/wiki/Spa_town" title="Spa town">spa town</a></div></div></div>\n<p><br/>\nStatistics of 2016 showed that 1.49 million tourists from foreign countries visited Lithuania and spent at least one night in the country. The largest number of tourists came from <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (174,8 thousand), <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> (171,9 thousand), <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> (150,6 thousand), <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> (148,4 thousand), <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> (134,4 thousand), <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> (84,0 thousand), and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">UK</a> (58,2 thousand).\n</p><p>The total contribution of Travel &amp; Tourism to country GDP was EUR 2,005.5mn, 5.3% of GDP in 2016, and is forecast to rise by 7.3% in 2017, and to rise by 4.2% pa to EUR 3,243.5mn, 6.7% of GDP in 2027.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> Hot air ballooning is very popular in Lithuania, especially in Vilnius and Trakai. Bicycle tourism is growing, especially in Lithuanian Seaside Cycle Route. <a href="/wiki/EuroVelo" title="EuroVelo">EuroVelo</a> routes EV10, EV11, EV13 go through Lithuania. Total length of bicycle tracks amounts to \n3769&#160;km (of which 1988&#160;km is asphalt pavement).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nemunas_Delta_Regional_Park" title="Nemunas Delta Regional Park">Nemunas Delta Regional Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_%C5%BDuvintas" title="Lake &#381;uvintas">&#381;uvintas biosphere reserve</a> are known for birdwatching.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Domestic tourism has been on the rise as well. Currently there are up to 1000 places of attraction in Lithuania. Most tourists visit the big cities&#8212;<a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaip&#279;da">Klaip&#279;da</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a>, seaside resorts, such as <a href="/wiki/Neringa_Municipality" title="Neringa Municipality">Neringa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palanga" title="Palanga">Palanga</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Spa_town" title="Spa town">Spa towns</a> &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Druskininkai" title="Druskininkai">Druskininkai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bir%C5%A1tonas" title="Bir&#353;tonas">Bir&#353;tonas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Infrastructure">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communication">Communication</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Communication">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Lithuania" title="Telecommunications in Lithuania">Telecommunications in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_(2016).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2909" data-file-width="1998" decoding="async" height="248" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_%282016%29.jpg/170px-Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_%282016%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_%282016%29.jpg/255px-Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_%282016%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_%282016%29.jpg/340px-Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_%282016%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bures_business_centre_in_Vilnius_(2016).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Telia_Company" title="Telia Company">Telia</a> (skyscraper with the old <a href="/wiki/Teo_LT" title="Teo LT">Teo LT</a> logo) and <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania has a well developed communications infrastructure. The country has 2,8 million citizens<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> and 5 million SIM cards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> The largest LTE (4G) mobile network covers 97% of Lithuania\'s territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> Usage of fixed phone lines has been rapidly decreasing due to rapid expansion of mobile-cellular services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2017, Lithuania was top 30 in the world by average mobile broadband speeds and top 20 by average fixed broadband speeds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup>\nLithuania was also top 7 in 2017 in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_4G_LTE_penetration" title="List of countries by 4G LTE penetration">List of countries by 4G LTE penetration</a>. In 2016, Lithuania was ranked 17th in United Nations\' e-participation index.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup>\n</p><p>There are four TIER III datacenters in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup>\nLithuania is 44th globally ranked country on data center density according to Cloudscene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Long-term project (2005&#8211;2013) &#8211; Development of Rural Areas Broadband Network (RAIN) was started with the objective to provide residents, state and municipal authorities and businesses with fibre-optic broadband access in rural areas. RAIN infrastructure allows 51 communications operators to provide network services to their clients. The project was funded by the European Union and the Lithuanian government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> 72% of Lithuanian households have access to internet, a number which in 2017 was among EU\'s lowest<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> and in 2016 ranked 97th by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> Number of households with internet access is expected to increase and reach 77% by 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup> Almost 50% of Lithuanians had smartphones in 2016, a number that is expected to increase to 65% by 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup>\nLithuania has the highest FTTH (Fiber to the home) penetration rate in Europe (36.8% in September 2016) according to FTTH Council Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Lithuania" title="Transport in Lithuania">Transport in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania-roads-(E).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="469" data-file-width="595" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png/220px-Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png/330px-Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png/440px-Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania-roads-(E).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Major highways in Lithuania</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania received its first railway connection in the middle of the 19th century, when the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warsaw_%E2%80%93_Saint_Petersburg_Railway" title="Warsaw &#8211; Saint Petersburg Railway">Warsaw &#8211; Saint Petersburg Railway</a> was constructed. It included a stretch from <a href="/wiki/Daugavpils" title="Daugavpils">Daugavpils</a> via Vilnius and Kaunas to Virbalis. The first and only still operating <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Railway_Tunnel" title="Kaunas Railway Tunnel">tunnel</a> was completed in 1860.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Railways" title="Lithuanian Railways">Lithuanian Railways</a>\' main network consists of 1,762&#160;km (1,095&#160;mi) of 1,520&#160;mm (4&#160;ft 11.8&#160;in) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_gauge" title="Russian gauge">Russian gauge</a> railway of which 122&#160;km (76&#160;mi) are electrified. This railway network is incompatible with European <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_gauge" title="Standard gauge">standard gauge</a> and requires train switching. However, Lithuanian railway network also has 115&#160;km (71&#160;mi) of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_gauge" title="Standard gauge">standard gauge</a> lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> More than half of all inland freight transported in Lithuania is carried by rail.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> The Trans-European standard gauge <a href="/wiki/Rail_Baltica" title="Rail Baltica">Rail Baltica</a> railway, linking <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">Helsinki</a>&#8211;<a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>&#8211;<a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">Riga</a>&#8211;<a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a>&#8211;<a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> and continuing on to Berlin is under construction. In 2017, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lietuvos_Gele%C5%BEinkeliai" title="Lietuvos Gele&#382;inkeliai">Lietuvos Gele&#382;inkeliai</a>, a company that operates most railway lines in Lithuania, received EU penalty for breaching EU\'s antitrust laws and restricting competition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg/170px-Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg/255px-Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg/340px-Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marijampol%C4%97s_gele%C5%BEinkelio_stotis_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Marijampol%C4%97_railway_station" title="Marijampol&#279; railway station">Marijampol&#279; railway station</a>, completed in 1924</div></div></div>\n<p>Transportation is the 3rd largest sector in Lithuanian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> Lithuanian transport companies drew attention in 2016<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> and 2017<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> with huge and record-breaking orders of trucks. Almost 90% of commercial truck traffic in Lithuania is international transports, the highest of any EU country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania has an extensive network of motorways. WEF grades Lithuanian roads at 4,7 / 7,0<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup> and Lithuanian road authority (LAKD) at 6,5 / 10,0.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Klaip%C4%97da" title="Port of Klaip&#279;da">Port of Klaip&#279;da</a> is the only commercial cargo port in Lithuania. In 2011 45.5 million tons of cargo were handled (including <a href="/wiki/B%C5%ABting%C4%97_oil_terminal" title="B&#363;ting&#279; oil terminal">B&#363;ting&#279; oil terminal</a> figures)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Klaip%C4%97da" title="Port of Klaip&#279;da">Port of Klaip&#279;da</a> is outside of EU\'s 20 largest ports,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> but it is the 8th largest port in the Baltic Sea region<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup>\n<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup> with ongoing expansion plans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vilnius_International_Airport" title="Vilnius International Airport">Vilnius International Airport</a> is the largest airport in Lithuania, but not among <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe" title="List of the busiest airports in Europe">EU\'s 100 largest airports</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> It served 3.8 million passengers in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup> Other international airports include <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Airport" title="Kaunas Airport">Kaunas International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palanga_International_Airport" title="Palanga International Airport">Palanga International Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai_International_Airport" title="&#352;iauliai International Airport">&#352;iauliai International Airport</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Airport" title="Kaunas Airport">Kaunas International Airport</a> is also a small commercial cargo airport which started regular commercial cargo traffic in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Water supply and sanitation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Heilquelle.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="2176" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Heilquelle.JPG/150px-Heilquelle.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Heilquelle.JPG/225px-Heilquelle.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Heilquelle.JPG/300px-Heilquelle.JPG 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Heilquelle.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mineral water spring in <a href="/wiki/Bir%C5%A1tonas" title="Bir&#353;tonas">Bir&#353;tonas</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania has one of the largest fresh water supplies, compared with other countries in Europe. Lithuania and <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> are the only countries in Europe, which are fully equipped with fresh groundwater. Lithuanians consumes about 0.5 million cubic meters of water per day, which is only 12&#8211;14 percent of all explored fresh groundwater resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup> Water quality in the country is very high and is determined by the fact that drinking water comes from deep layers that are protected from pollution on the surface of the earth. Drilling depth usually reaches 30&#8211;50 meters, but in <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region" title="Klaip&#279;da Region">Klaip&#279;da Region</a> it even reaches 250 meters. Consequently, Lithuania is one of very few European countries where groundwater is used for centralized water supply. With a large underground fresh water reserves, Lithuania exports mineral-rich water to other countries. Approved mineral water quantity is about 2.7 million cubic meters per year, while production is only 4&#8211;5 percent of all mineral water resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> is the only Baltic capital that uses centralized water supplying from deep water springs, which are protected from pollution and has no <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nitrates" title="Nitrates">nitrates</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nitrites" title="Nitrites">nitrites</a> that are harmful to the human body. Water is cleaned without chemicals in Lithuania. About 20% of the consumed water in the state is a non-filtered very high quality water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Energy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Lithuania" title="Energy in Lithuania">Energy in Lithuania</a></div> <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Lithuania" title="Renewable energy in Lithuania">Renewable energy in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da,_Lithuania.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="767" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da%2C_Lithuania.jpg/220px-FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da%2C_Lithuania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da%2C_Lithuania.jpg/330px-FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da%2C_Lithuania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da%2C_Lithuania.jpg/440px-FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da%2C_Lithuania.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FSRU_Independence_in_the_port_of_Klaip%C4%97da,_Lithuania.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/FSRU_Independence" title="FSRU Independence">FSRU Independence</a> in port of Klaip&#279;da</div></div></div>\n<p>Systematic diversification of energy imports and resources is Lithuania\'s key energy strategy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> Long term aims were defined in National Energy Independence strategy in 2012 by Lietuvos Seimas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> It was estimated that strategic energy independence initiatives will cost 6.3&#8211;7.8 billion Eur in total and provide annual savings of 0.9&#8211;1.1 billion EUR.\n</p><p>After the decommissioning of the <a href="/wiki/Ignalina_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant">Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant</a>, Lithuania turned from electricity exporter to electricity importer. Unit No. 1 was closed in December 2004, as a condition of Lithuania\'s entry into the European Union; Unit No. 2 was closed down on 31 December 2009. Proposals have been made to construct a new &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Visaginas_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Visaginas Nuclear Power Plant">Visaginas Nuclear Power Plant</a> in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> However, a non-binding referendum held in October 2012 clouded the prospects for the Visaginas project, as 63% of voters said no to a new nuclear power plant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The country\'s main primary source of electrical power is <a href="/wiki/Elektr%C4%97nai_Power_Plant" title="Elektr&#279;nai Power Plant">Elektr&#279;nai Power Plant</a>. Other primary sources of Lithuania\'s electrical power are <a href="/wiki/Kruonis_Pumped_Storage_Plant" title="Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant">Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Hydroelectric_Power_Plant" title="Kaunas Hydroelectric Power Plant">Kaunas Hydroelectric Power Plant</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kruonis_Pumped_Storage_Plant" title="Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant">Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant</a> is the only in the Baltic states power plant to be used for regulation of the power system\'s operation with generating capacity of 900 MW for at least 12 hours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> As of  2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 66% of electrical power was imported.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> First geothermal heating plant (<a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Geothermal_Demonstration_Plant" title="Klaip&#279;da Geothermal Demonstration Plant">Klaip&#279;da Geothermal Demonstration Plant</a>) in the Baltic Sea region was built in 2004.\n</p><p>Lithuania&#8211;Sweden submarine electricity interconnection <a href="/wiki/NordBalt" title="NordBalt">NordBalt</a> and Lithuania&#8211;Poland electricity interconnection <a href="/wiki/LitPol_Link" title="LitPol Link">LitPol Link</a> were launched at the end of 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In order to break down <a href="/wiki/Gazprom" title="Gazprom">Gazprom</a>\'s monopoly<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> in natural gas market of Lithuania, first large scale LNG import terminal (<a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_LNG_FSRU" title="Klaip&#279;da LNG FSRU">Klaip&#279;da LNG FSRU</a>) in the Baltic region was built in port of Klaip&#279;da in 2014. The Klaip&#279;da LNG terminal was called Independence, thus emphasising the aim to diversify energy market of Lithuania. Norvegian company <a href="/wiki/Equinor" title="Equinor">Equinor</a> supplies 540&#160;million cubic metres (19&#160;billion cubic feet) of natural gas annually from 2015 until 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup> The terminal is able to meet the Lithuania\'s demand 100 percent, and Latvia\'s and Estonia\'s national demand 90 percent in the future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Gas_Interconnection_Poland%E2%80%93Lithuania" title="Gas Interconnection Poland&#8211;Lithuania">Gas Interconnection Poland&#8211;Lithuania</a> (GIPL), also known as Lithuania&#8211;Poland pipeline, is a proposed natural gas pipeline interconnection between Lithuania and Poland that is expected to be finished by 2019. In 2018 synchronising the Baltic States\' electricity grid with the <a href="/wiki/Synchronous_grid_of_Continental_Europe" title="Synchronous grid of Continental Europe">Synchronous grid of Continental Europe</a> has started.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2016, 20,8% of electricity consumed in Lithuania came from renewable sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Lithuania" title="Demographics of Lithuania">Demographics of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="1270" decoding="async" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png/440px-Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png/660px-Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png/880px-Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png 2x" width="440"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Lithuania_1915-2014.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population of Lithuania 1915&#8211;2014</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="610" data-file-width="776" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg/300px-Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg/450px-Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg/600px-Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density</div></div></div>\n<p>Since the Neolithic period the native inhabitants of the Lithuanian territory have not been replaced by any other ethnic group, so there is a high probability that the inhabitants of present-day Lithuania have preserved the genetic composition of their forebears relatively undisturbed by the major demographic movements,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup> although without being actually isolated from them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> The Lithuanian population appears to be relatively homogeneous, without apparent genetic differences among ethnic subgroups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup>\n</p><p>A 2004 analysis of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MtDNA" title="MtDNA">MtDNA</a> in the Lithuanian population revealed that Lithuanians are close to the <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">Slavic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_languages" title="Finno-Ugric languages">Finno-Ugric</a> speaking populations of Northern and Eastern Europe. <a href="/wiki/Y_chromosome" title="Y chromosome">Y-chromosome</a> SNP <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup" title="Haplogroup">haplogroup</a> analysis showed Lithuanians to be closest to <a href="/wiki/Latvians" title="Latvians">Latvians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">Estonians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup>\n</p><p>According to 2014 estimates, the age structure of the population was as follows: 0&#8211;14 years, 13.5% (male 243,001/female 230,674); 15&#8211;64 years: 69.5% (male 1,200,196/female 1,235,300); 65 years and over: 16.8% (male 207,222/female 389,345).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-315">[315]</a></sup> The median age was 41.2 years (male: 38.5, female: 43.7).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility_rate" title="Sub-replacement fertility rate">sub-replacement fertility rate</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) in Lithuania is 1.59 children born/woman (2015 estimates).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup>\nAs of  2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 29% of births were to unmarried women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Age_at_first_marriage" title="Age at first marriage">age at first marriage</a> in 2013 was 27 years for women and 29.3 years for men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Ethnic groups">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_Lithuania" title="Ethnic minorities in Lithuania">Ethnic minorities in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">\n<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:300px; background: white;">\n<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">\n<tbody><tr style="background:#ddd"><th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">Residents of Lithuania by ethnicity (2011)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011a_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-2011a-1">[1]</a></sup></th></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;"></td>\n<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;"></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Lithuanians</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:green; width:84.2%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">84.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Poles</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:red; width:6.6%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">6.6%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Russians</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:blue; width:5.8%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">5.8%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Belarusians</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:purple; width:1.2%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Ukrainians</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:brown; width:0.5%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.5%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:gray; width:1.7%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.7%</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Ethnic Lithuanians make up about five-sixths of the country\'s population and Lithuania has the most homogeneous population in the Baltic States. In 2015, the population of Lithuania stands at 2,921,262, 84.2% of whom are ethnic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_people" title="Lithuanian people">Lithuanians</a> who speak <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>, which is the official language of the country. Several sizeable minorities exist, such as <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a> (6.6%), <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> (5.8%), <a href="/wiki/Belarusians" title="Belarusians">Belarusians</a> (1.2%) and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> (0.5%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011a_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-2011a-1">[1]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Poles_in_Lithuania" title="Poles in Lithuania">Poles in Lithuania</a> are the largest minority, concentrated in southeast Lithuania (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vilnius_region" title="Vilnius region">Vilnius region</a>). <a href="/wiki/Russians_in_Lithuania" title="Russians in Lithuania">Russians in Lithuania</a> are the second largest minority, concentrated mostly in two cities. They constitute sizeable minorities in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> (12%)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaip&#279;da">Klaip&#279;da</a> (19.6%),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-osp.stat.gov.lt_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-osp.stat.gov.lt-321">[321]</a></sup> and a majority in the town of <a href="/wiki/Visaginas" title="Visaginas">Visaginas</a> (52%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup> About 3,000 <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a> live in Lithuania, mostly in Vilnius, <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> and Panev&#279;&#382;ys; their organizations are supported by the National Minority and Emigration Department.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup> For centuries a small <a href="/wiki/Lipka_Tatars" title="Lipka Tatars">Tatar</a> community has flourished in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The official language is <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>, other languages, such as <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarusian_language" title="Belarusian language">Belarusian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>, are spoken in the larger cities, and several municipalities such as <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0al%C4%8Dininkai_District_Municipality" title="&#352;al&#269;ininkai District Municipality">&#352;al&#269;ininkai District Municipality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_District_Municipality" title="Vilnius District Municipality">Vilnius District Municipality</a> and <a href="/wiki/Visaginas_Municipality" title="Visaginas Municipality">Visaginas Municipality</a>. <a href="/wiki/Yiddish" title="Yiddish">Yiddish</a> is spoken by members of the tiny remaining <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Lithuania" title="History of the Jews in Lithuania">Jewish community</a> in Lithuania. According to the Lithuanian population census of 2011,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-osp.stat.gov.lt_321-1"><a href="#cite_note-osp.stat.gov.lt-321">[321]</a></sup> about 85% of the country\'s population speak Lithuanian as their native language, 7,2% are native speakers of Russian and 5,3% of Polish. About 39% of Lithuanian citizens speak Russian as a foreign language, 20% &#8211; English, 9% &#8211; German, 6% &#8211; Polish, 3% &#8211; French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup> Most Lithuanian schools teach English as the first foreign language, but students may also study German, or, in some schools, French or Russian. Schools where Russian or Polish are the primary languages of education exist in the areas populated by these minorities. Minority schools are public, where the education is free (taxpayer-funded).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Lithuania has accepted <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis#Relocation_and_resettlement_of_asylum_seekers" title="European migrant crisis">quota refugees</a> under the migrant plan agreed upon by EU member states in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Urbanization">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Lithuania" title="List of cities in Lithuania">List of cities in Lithuania</a></div>\n<p>There has been a steady <a href="/wiki/Urbanization" title="Urbanization">movement of population to the cities</a> since the 1990s, encouraged by the planning of regional centres, such as <a href="/wiki/Alytus" title="Alytus">Alytus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marijampol%C4%97" title="Marijampol&#279;">Marijampol&#279;</a>, <a href="/wiki/Utena" title="Utena">Utena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plung%C4%97" title="Plung&#279;">Plung&#279;</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ma%C5%BEeikiai" title="Ma&#382;eikiai">Ma&#382;eikiai</a>. By the early 21st century, about two-thirds of the total population lived in urban areas. As of  2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 66.5% of the total population lives in urban areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_315-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-315">[315]</a></sup> Lithuania\'s <a href="/wiki/Larger_urban_zone" title="Larger urban zone">functional urban areas</a> include <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> (population 696,000 in 2016) and <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> (population 387,000 in 2016).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup> The fDI of the Financial Times in their research <i>Cities and Regions of the Future 2018/19</i> ranked Vilnius 4th in the mid-sized European cities category and Vilnius county was ranked 10th in the small European regions category.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0.75em;"><div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">&#160;</div><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a class="mw-selflink selflink"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Talk:Lithuania" title="Talk:Lithuania"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div> <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;"><span style="font-size:110%;">Largest cities or towns in Lithuania</span><br/><div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Statistics_Lithuania" title="Statistics Lithuania">Statistics Lithuania</a> (2015)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup></div></div>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th></th>\n<th>Rank\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Lithuania" title="List of cities in Lithuania">Name</a>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Lithuania" title="Counties of Lithuania">County</a>\n</th>\n<th>Pop.\n</th>\n<th>Rank\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Lithuania" title="List of cities in Lithuania">Name</a>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Lithuania" title="Counties of Lithuania">County</a>\n</th>\n<th>Pop.</th>\n<th>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vilnius_Modern_Skyline_At_Dusk,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg" title="Vilnius"><img alt="Vilnius" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="6258" data-file-width="12000" decoding="async" href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a><br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vytautas_the_Great_Bridge_from_hill,_Kaunas,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg" title="Kaunas"><img alt="Kaunas" 2x" width="120"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">1</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilnius_County" title="Vilnius County">Vilnius</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">542,990</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">11</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/K%C4%97dainiai" title="K&#279;dainiai">K&#279;dainiai</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kaunas_County" title="Kaunas County">Kaunas</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">25,107\n</td>\n<td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Klaip%C4%97da._Senamiestis.jpg" title="Klaip&#279;da"><img alt="Klaip&#279;da" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1898" data-file-width="2530" decoding="async" height="90" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Klaip%C4%97da._Senamiestis.jpg/120px-Klaip%C4%97da._Senamiestis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Klaip%C4%97da._Senamiestis.jpg/180px-Klaip%C4%97da._Senamiestis.jpg 1.5x, style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">6</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Alytus" title="Alytus">Alytus</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Alytus_County" style="text-align:right;">18,882\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">8</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Marijampol%C4%97" style="text-align:right;">37,914</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">18</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Plung%C4%97" title="Plung&#279;">Plung&#279;</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Tel%C5%A1iai_County" title="Tel&#353;iai County">Tel&#353;iai</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">18,717\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">9</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Jonava" title="Jonava">Jonava</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kaunas_County" title="Kaunas County">Kaunas</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">28,719</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">19</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vilkavi%C5%A1kis" title="Vilkavi&#353;kis">Vilkavi&#353;kis</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Marijampol%C4%97_County" title="Marijampol&#279; County">Marijampol&#279;</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">16,707\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Utena" title="Utena">Utena</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Utena_County" title="Utena County">Utena</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">27,120</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">20</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ilut%C4%97" title="&#352;ilut&#279;">&#352;ilut&#279;</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_County" title="Klaip&#279;da County">Klaip&#279;da</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">16,686\n</td></tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Health">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Lithuania" title="Health in Lithuania">Health in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg/220px-Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg/330px-Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg/440px-Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kauno_klinikos_2006_07_23.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Clinics" title="Kaunas Clinics">Kaunas Clinics</a> is the largest and the most advanced medical institution in Lithuania, capable of performing the most advanced surgeries</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania provides free state-funded healthcare to all citizens and registered long-term residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup> Private healthcare is also available in the country. In 2003&#8211;2012, the network of hospitals was restructured, as part of wider healthcare service reforms. It started in 2003&#8211;2005 with the expansion of ambulatory services and primary care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup>\nIn 2016, Lithuania ranked 27th in Europe in the <a href="/wiki/Euro_health_consumer_index" title="Euro health consumer index">Euro health consumer index</a>, a ranking of European healthcare systems based on waiting time, results and other indicators.\n</p><p>As of  2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Lithuanian <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> at birth was 73.4 (67.4 years for males and 78.8 for females)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate was 6.2 per 1,000 births. The annual population growth rate increased by 0.3% in 2007. At 33.5 people per 100,000 in 2012, Lithuania has seen a dramatic rise in suicides in the post-Soviet years, and now records the highest in Europe (cases in rural areas are five times more frequent than in cities)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_suicide_rate" title="List of countries by suicide rate">fourth highest</a> age-standardized suicide rate in the world, according to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">WHO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup> According to experts, this number was largely influenced by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet" title="Soviet">Soviets</a>\' authority because mostly Christian country\'s inhabitants previously considered it as a severe <a href="/wiki/Sin" title="Sin">sin</a> and were afraid to take their lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup>\n</p><p>By 2000 the vast majority of Lithuanian health care institutions were non-profit-making enterprises and a private sector developed, providing mostly outpatient services which are paid for out-of-pocket. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Lithuania)" title="Ministry of Health (Lithuania)">Ministry of Health</a> also runs a few health care facilities and is involved in the running of the two major Lithuanian teaching hospitals. It is responsible for the State Public Health Centre which manages the public health network including ten county public health centres with their local branches. The ten <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Lithuania" title="Counties of Lithuania">counties</a> run county hospitals and specialised health care facilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup>\n</p><p>There is now Compulsory Health Insurance for Lithuanian residents. There are 5 Territorial Health Insurance Funds, covering Vilnius, Kaunas, Klaip&#279;da, &#352;iauliai and Panev&#279;&#382;ys. Contributions for people who are economically active are 9% of income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Emergency medical services are provided free of charge to all residents. Access to hospital treatment is normally by referral by a General Practitioner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> Lithuania also has one of the lowest <a href="/wiki/Health_care" title="Health care">health care</a> prices in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Lithuania" title="Religion in Lithuania">Religion in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">\n<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:300px; background: white;">\n<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">\n<tbody><tr style="background:#ddd"><th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">Residents of Lithuania by religion (2011)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat-rel_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-stat-rel-341">[341]</a></sup></th></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;"></td>\n<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;"></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:green; width:77.2%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">77.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:red; width:4.1%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">4.1%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Eastern Orthodox (<a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">Old Believers</a>)</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:blue; width:0.8%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.8%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutheran</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:yellow; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.6%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Evangelical_Reformed_Church" title="Lithuanian Evangelical Reformed Church">Reformed</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:brown; width:0.2%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:orange; width:0.9%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.9%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">No religion</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:purple; width:6.1%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">6.1%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Did not specify</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:gray; width:10.1%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">10.1%</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1155" data-file-width="3067" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg/390px-Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg/585px-Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg/780px-Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg 2x" width="390"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hill_of_Crosses" title="Hill of Crosses">Hill of Crosses</a> near <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai" title="&#352;iauliai">&#352;iauliai</a></div></div></div>\n<p>According to the 2011 census, 77.2% of residents of Lithuania were Catholics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat-rel_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-stat-rel-341">[341]</a></sup> Catholicism has been the main religion since the official <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianisation_of_Lithuania" title="Christianisation of Lithuania">Christianisation of Lithuania</a> in 1387. The Catholic Church was persecuted by the Russian Empire as part of the <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">Russification</a> policies and by the Soviet Union as part of the overall <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Religion in the Soviet Union">anti-religious campaigns</a>. During the Soviet era, some priests actively led the resistance against the Communist regime, as symbolised by the <a href="/wiki/Hill_of_Crosses" title="Hill of Crosses">Hill of Crosses</a> and exemplified by <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Chronicle_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Lithuania" title="The Chronicle of the Catholic Church in Lithuania">The Chronicle of the Catholic Church in Lithuania</a></i>.\n</p><p>4.1% of the population are <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a>, mainly among the Russian minority. The community of <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">Old Believers</a> (0.8% of population) dates back to 1660s.\n</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants">Protestants</a> are 0.8%, of which 0.6% are <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutheran</a> and 0.2% are <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Evangelical_Reformed_Church" title="Lithuanian Evangelical Reformed Church">Reformed</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> did not impact Lithuania to a great extent as seen in <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>. Before World War II, according to Losch (1932), the Lutherans were 3.3% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lmaleidykla.lt_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-lmaleidykla.lt-342">[342]</a></sup> They were mainly <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">Germans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prussian_Lithuanians" title="Prussian Lithuanians">Prussian Lithuanians</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region" title="Klaip&#279;da Region">Klaip&#279;da Region</a> (Memel territory). This population <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flight_and_expulsion_of_Germans" title="Flight and expulsion of Germans">fled or was expelled after the war</a>, and today Protestantism is mainly represented by ethnic Lithuanians throughout the northern and western parts of the country, as well as in large urban areas.
