Newly arriving <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">evangelical churches</a> have established missions in Lithuania since 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The historical communities of <a href="/wiki/Lipka_Tatars" title="Lipka Tatars">Lipka Tatars</a> maintain <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Lithuania" title="Islam in Lithuania">Islam</a> as their religion. Lithuania was historically home to a significant <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Lithuania" title="History of the Jews in Lithuania">Jewish community</a> and was an important center of Jewish scholarship and culture from the 18th century until the eve of World War II. Of the approximately 220,000 Jews who lived in Lithuania in June 1941, almost all were killed during <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Lithuania" title="The Holocaust in Lithuania">the Holocaust</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bubnys_vanished219_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bubnys_vanished219-344">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup> The Lithuanian Jewish community numbered about 4,000 at the end of 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stats_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stats-346">[346]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Romuva_(religion)" title="Romuva (religion)">Romuva</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neopagan" title="Neopagan">neopagan</a> revival of the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_mythology" title="Lithuanian mythology">ancient religious practices</a>, has gained popularity over the years. Romuva claims to continue living pagan traditions, which survived in folklore and customs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup> Romuva is a <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheistic</a> pagan faith, which asserts the sanctity of nature and has elements of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancestor_worship" title="Ancestor worship">ancestor worship</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[350]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_census_of_2001" title="Lithuanian census of 2001">2001 census</a>, there were 1,270 people of Baltic faith in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> That number jumped to 5,118 in the 2011 census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-osp.stat.gov.lt_321-2"><a href="#cite_note-osp.stat.gov.lt-321">[321]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tnone center"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:592px;max-width:592px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:161px;max-width:161px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:140px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Romuva_sanctuary.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="968" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Romuva_sanctuary.jpg/159px-Romuva_sanctuary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Romuva_sanctuary.jpg/239px-Romuva_sanctuary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Romuva_sanctuary.jpg/318px-Romuva_sanctuary.jpg 2x" width="159"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/Romuva_(temple)" title="Romuva (temple)">Romuva sanctuary</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sambia" title="Sambia">Sambia</a>, where Krivis, the chief priest or "pagan pope", lived and ruled over the religion of all the <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Balts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:148px;max-width:148px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:140px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="6626" data-file-width="6884" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/146px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/219px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/292px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg 2x" width="146"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Peter_and_St._Paul,_Vilnius" title="Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, Vilnius">Church of St. Peter and St. Paul</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> with over 2,000 different interior decor elements. Lithuania has strong Catholic traditions.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:111px;max-width:111px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:140px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Theotokos_vilnius.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2791" data-file-width="2166" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Theotokos_vilnius.jpg/109px-Theotokos_vilnius.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Theotokos_vilnius.jpg/164px-Theotokos_vilnius.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Theotokos_vilnius.jpg/218px-Theotokos_vilnius.jpg 2x" width="109"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Theotokos" title="Cathedral of the Theotokos">Cathedral of the Theotokos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Church</a>. It was built in 1346 by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Duke_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duke of Lithuania">Grand Duke</a> <a href="/wiki/Algirdas" title="Algirdas">Algirdas</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:164px;max-width:164px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:140px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="866" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg/162px-Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg/243px-Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg/324px-Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg 2x" width="162"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choral_Synagogue_of_Vilnius" title="Choral Synagogue of Vilnius">Choral Synagogue of Vilnius</a>. Almost whole rich culture of the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Jews" title="Lithuanian Jews">Litvaks</a> was destroyed during the Nazi occupation.</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Lithuania" title="Education in Lithuania">Education in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GreatCourtyard.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="763" data-file-width="592" decoding="async" height="219" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/GreatCourtyard.jpg/170px-GreatCourtyard.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/GreatCourtyard.jpg/255px-GreatCourtyard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/GreatCourtyard.jpg/340px-GreatCourtyard.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GreatCourtyard.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">Vilnius University</a>, one of the oldest universities in Eastern and Central Europe<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1302" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg/220px-Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg/330px-Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg/440px-Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vilniaus_universiteto_Gyvyb%C4%97s_moksl%C5%B3_centras.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">Vilnius University</a> Life Sciences Center in the Saul&#279;tekis Valley</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">Constitution of Lithuania</a> mandates ten-year education ending at age 16 and guarantees a free public higher education for students deemed \'good\'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_and_Science_of_the_Republic_of_Lithuania" title="Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Lithuania">Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Lithuania</a> proposes national educational policies and goals that are then voted for in the Seimas. Laws govern long-term educational strategy along with general laws on standards for higher education, vocational training, law and science, adult education, and special education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edu1_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-edu1-355">[355]</a></sup> 5.4% of GDP or 15.4% of total public expenditure was spent for education in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edumonitor_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-edumonitor-356">[356]</a></sup>\n</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, the literacy rate among Lithuanians aged 15 years and older is 100%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup> School attendance rates are above EU average and school leave is less common than in the EU. According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> Lithuania leads among other countries of <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU</a> by people with secondary education (93.3%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup> Based on OECD data, Lithuania is among the top 5 countries in the world by postsecondary (tertiary) education attainment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup> As of  2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 54.9% of the population aged 25 to 34, and 30.7% of the population aged 55 to 64 had completed tertiary education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup> The share of tertiary-educated 25&#8211;64 year-olds in STEM (<a href="/wiki/Science,_technology,_engineering,_and_mathematics" title="Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics">Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics</a>) fields in Lithuania were above the OECD average (29% and 26% respectively), similarly to business, administration and law (25% and 23% respectively).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Modern Lithuanian education system has multiple structural problems. Insufficient funding, quality issues, and decreasing student population are the most prevalent. Lithuanian teacher salaries are lowest in entire EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[362]</a></sup> Low teacher salaries was the primary reason behind national teacher strikes in 2014,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup> 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup> and 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[366]</a></sup> Salaries in the higher education sector are also low. Many Lithuanian professors have a second job to supplement their income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup> PISA report from 2010 found that Lithuanian results in math, science and reading were below OECD average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup> PISA report from 2015 reconfirmed these findings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup> The population ages 6 to 19 has decreased by 36% between 2005 and 2015. As a result, the student-teacher ratio is decreasing and expenditure per student is increasing, but schools, particularly in rural areas, are forced into reorganizations and consolidations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edumonitor_356-1"><a href="#cite_note-edumonitor-356">[356]</a></sup> As with other <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic</a> nations, in particular <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, the large volume of higher education graduates within the country, coupled with the high rate of spoken second languages is contributing to an education <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">brain drain</a>.\n</p><p>As of  2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there were 15 public and 6 private universities as well as 16 public and 11 private colleges in Lithuania (see: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Lithuania" title="List of universities in Lithuania">List of universities in Lithuania</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">Vilnius University</a> is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">oldest universities in Northern Europe</a> and the largest university in Lithuania. <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_University_of_Technology" title="Kaunas University of Technology">Kaunas University of Technology</a> is the largest technical university in the Baltic States and the 2nd largest university in Lithuania. In an attempt to reduce costs<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup> and adapt to sharply decreasing number of high-school students,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[372]</a></sup> Lithuanian parliament decided to reduce the number of universities in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup> In early 2018, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Sports_University" title="Lithuanian Sports University">Lithuanian Sports University</a> was merged into <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Health_Sciences" title="Lithuanian University of Health Sciences">Lithuanian University of Health Sciences</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Educational_Sciences" title="Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences">Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aleksandras_Stulginskis_University" title="Aleksandras Stulginskis University">Aleksandras Stulginskis University</a> were merged into <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Magnus_University" title="Vytautas Magnus University">Vytautas Magnus University</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Lithuania" title="Culture of Lithuania">Culture of Lithuania</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lithuanian_language">Lithuanian language</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Lithuanian language">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian language</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:162px;max-width:162px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:186px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG"><img alt="" data-file-height="513" data-file-width="440" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG/160px-Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG/240px-Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG/320px-Konstanty_Szyrwid.PNG 2x" width="160"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">A priest, lexicographer <a href="/wiki/Konstantinas_Sirvydas" title="Konstantinas Sirvydas">Konstantinas Sirvydas</a> &#8211; cherisher of Lithuanian language in 17th century.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:126px;max-width:126px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:186px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="682" data-file-width="454" decoding="async" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg/124px-Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg/186px-Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg/248px-Jonas_Jablonskis.jpg 2x" width="124"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/Jonas_Jablonskis" title="Jonas Jablonskis">Jonas Jablonskis</a> is the father of standard Lithuanian language.</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian language</a> (<i>lietuvi&#371; kalba</i>) is the official state language of Lithuania and is recognized as one of the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>. There are about 2.96 million native Lithuanian speakers in Lithuania and about 0.2 million abroad.\n</p><p>Lithuanian is a <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">Baltic language</a>, closely related to <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a>, although they are not <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">mutually intelligible</a>. It is written in an adapted version of the <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Roman script</a>. Lithuanian is believed to be the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_(language)" title="Conservative (language)">linguistically most conservative</a> living <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European tongue</a>, retaining many features of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto_Indo-European_language" title="Proto Indo-European language">Proto Indo-European</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zinkevicius_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-zinkevicius-377">[377]</a></sup> Lithuanian language studies are important for <a href="/wiki/Comparative_linguistics" title="Comparative linguistics">comparative linguistics</a> and for reconstruction of <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">Proto-Indo-European language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> Lithuanian was studied by linguists such as <a href="/wiki/Franz_Bopp" title="Franz Bopp">Franz Bopp</a>, <a href="/wiki/August_Schleicher" title="August Schleicher">August Schleicher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adalbert_Bezzenberger" title="Adalbert Bezzenberger">Adalbert Bezzenberger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louis_Hjelmslev" title="Louis Hjelmslev">Louis Hjelmslev</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_de_Saussure" title="Ferdinand de Saussure">Ferdinand de Saussure</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Winfred_P._Lehmann" title="Winfred P. Lehmann">Winfred P. Lehmann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Toporov" title="Vladimir Toporov">Vladimir Toporov</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup> and others.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_earliest_known_Lithuanian_glosses_(~1520%E2%80%931530),_words_(tepridau%C5%BEia,_ubagyst%C4%97).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="220" data-file-width="261" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/The_earliest_known_Lithuanian_glosses_%28~1520%E2%80%931530%29%2C_words_%28tepridau%C5%BEia%2C_ubagyst%C4%97%29.jpg/220px-The_earliest_known_Lithuanian_glosses_%28~1520%E2%80%931530%29%2C_words_%28tepridau%C5%BEia%2C_ubagyst%C4%97%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f6/The_earliest_known_Lithuanian_glosses_%28~1520%E2%80%931530%29%2C_words_%28tepridau%C5%BEia%2C_ubagyst%C4%97%29.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_earliest_known_Lithuanian_glosses_(~1520%E2%80%931530),_words_(tepridau%C5%BEia,_ubagyst%C4%97).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The earliest known Lithuanian glosses (~1520&#8211;1530) written in the margins of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Johannes_Herolt" title="Johannes Herolt">Johannes Herolt</a> book <i>Liber Discipuli de eruditione Christifidelium</i>. Words: <i>tepr&#255;dav[&#383;]&#658;&#255;</i> (let it strike), <i>vbag&#255;&#383;te</i> (indigence)</div></div></div>\n<p>In the modern times, the Lithuanian language is divided into two dialects: <a href="/wiki/Auk%C5%A1taitian_dialect" title="Auk&#353;taitian dialect">Auk&#353;taitian dialect</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samogitian_dialect" title="Samogitian dialect">Samogitian dialect</a>. The pronunciation of words varies in both dialects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> The Samogitian dialect also has many completely different words and is even considered as a separate language by some linguists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The groundwork for written Lithuanian was laid in 16th and 17th centuries by Lithuanian noblemen and scholars, who promoted Lithuanian language, created dictionaries and published books &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Dauk%C5%A1a" title="Mikalojus Dauk&#353;a">Mikalojus Dauk&#353;a</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanislovas_Rapolionis" title="Stanislovas Rapolionis">Stanislovas Rapolionis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abraomas_Kulvietis" title="Abraomas Kulvietis">Abraomas Kulvietis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Bretk%C5%ABnas" title="Jonas Bretk&#363;nas">Jonas Bretk&#363;nas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martynas_Ma%C5%BEvydas" title="Martynas Ma&#382;vydas">Martynas Ma&#382;vydas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Konstantinas_Sirvydas" title="Konstantinas Sirvydas">Konstantinas Sirvydas</a>, Simonas Vai&#353;noras-Varni&#353;kis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup>\nThe first grammar book of the Lithuanian language <i>Grammatica Litvanica</i> was published in Latin in 1653 by <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Klein_(grammarian)" title="Daniel Klein (grammarian)">Danielius Kleinas</a>.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Jonas_Jablonskis" title="Jonas Jablonskis">Jonas Jablonskis</a> works and activities are especially important for the Lithuanian literature moving from the use of dialects to a standard Lithuanian language. The linguistic material which he collected was published in the 20 volumes of <a href="/wiki/Academic_Dictionary_of_Lithuanian" title="Academic Dictionary of Lithuanian">Academic Dictionary of Lithuanian</a> and is still being used in research and in editing of texts and books. He also introduced the letter <i>&#363;</i> into Lithuanian writing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_literature" title="Lithuanian literature">Lithuanian literature</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg/140px-Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg/210px-Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg/280px-Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oldest_surviving_writing_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Oldest surviving <a href="/wiki/Manuscript" title="Manuscript">manuscript</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian language</a> (beginning of the 16th century), rewritten from a 15th-century original text</div></div></div>\n<p>There is a great deal of Lithuanian literature written in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, the main scholarly language of the Middle Ages. The edicts of the Lithuanian King <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">Mindaugas</a> is the prime example of the literature of this kind. The <a href="/wiki/Letters_of_Gediminas" title="Letters of Gediminas">Letters of Gediminas</a> are another crucial heritage of the Lithuanian Latin writings.\n</p><p>One of the first Lithuanian authors who wrote in Latin was <a href="/wiki/Miko%C5%82aj_Hussowczyk" title="Miko&#322;aj Hussowczyk">Nicolaus Hussovianus</a> (around 1480 &#8211; after 1533). His poem <i>Carmen de statura, feritate ac venatione bisontis</i> (<i>A Song about the Appearance, Savagery and Hunting of the Bison</i>), published in 1523, describes the Lithuanian landscape, way of life and customs, touches on some actual political problems, and reflects the clash of paganism and Christianity. A person under the pseudonym <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michalo_Lituanus" title="Michalo Lituanus">Michalo Lituanus</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michalo_Lituanus" title="lt:Michalo Lituanus">lt</a>]</span> (around 1490 &#8211; 1560) wrote a treatise <i><a href="/wiki/De_moribus_tartarorum,_lituanorum_et_moscorum" title="De moribus tartarorum, lituanorum et moscorum">De moribus tartarorum, lituanorum et moscorum</a></i> (<i>On the Customs of Tatars, Lithuanians and Muscovites</i>) in the middle of the 16th century, but it was not published until 1615. An extraordinary figure in the cultural life of Lithuania in the 16th century was the lawyer and poet of Spanish origin Petrus Roysius Maurus Alcagnicensis (around 1505 &#8211; 1571). The publicist, lawyer, and mayor of Vilnius, <a href="/wiki/Augustinus_Rotundus" title="Augustinus Rotundus">Augustinus Rotundus</a> (around 1520 -1582) wrote a no longer existent history of Lithuania in Latin around the year 1560. loannes Radvanus, a humanist poet of the second half of the 16th century, wrote an epic poem imitating the <a href="/wiki/Aeneid" title="Aeneid">Aeneid</a> of <a href="/wiki/Virgil" title="Virgil">Vergil</a>. His <i>Radivilias</i>, intended to become the Lithuanian national epic, was published in Vilnius in 1588.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas,_Vilnius.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas%2C_Vilnius.jpg/170px-Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas%2C_Vilnius.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas%2C_Vilnius.jpg/255px-Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas%2C_Vilnius.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas%2C_Vilnius.jpg/340px-Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas%2C_Vilnius.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ma%C5%BEvydo_Katekizmas,_Vilnius.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The first Lithuanian <a href="/wiki/Printing" title="Printing">printed</a> book <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_Martynas_Ma%C5%BEvydas" title="Catechism of Martynas Ma&#382;vydas">Catechism of Martynas Ma&#382;vydas</a></i> (1547, K&#246;nigsberg)</div></div></div>\n<p>17th century Lithuanian scholars also wrote in Latin &#8211; Kazimieras Kojelavi&#269;ius-Vij&#363;kas, <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDygimantas_Liauksminas" title="&#381;ygimantas Liauksminas">&#381;ygimantas Liauksminas</a> are known for their Latin writings in theology, rhetorics and music. Albertas Kojalavi&#269;ius-Vij&#363;kas wrote first printed Lithuanian history <i>Historia Lithuania</i>.\n</p><p>Lithuanian literary works in the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian language</a> started being first published in the 16th century. In 1547 <a href="/wiki/Martynas_Ma%C5%BEvydas" title="Martynas Ma&#382;vydas">Martynas Ma&#382;vydas</a> compiled and published the first printed Lithuanian book <i>Katekizmo prasti &#382;od&#382;iai</i> (<i>The Simple Words of Catechism</i>), which marks the beginning of literature, printed in Lithuanian. He was followed by <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Dauk%C5%A1a" title="Mikalojus Dauk&#353;a">Mikalojus Dauk&#353;a</a> with <i>Katechizmas</i>. In the 16th and 17th centuries, as in the whole Christian Europe, Lithuanian literature was primarily religious.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Radivilias.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="688" data-file-width="522" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Radivilias.jpg/170px-Radivilias.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Radivilias.jpg/255px-Radivilias.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Radivilias.jpg/340px-Radivilias.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Radivilias.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The title page of <i>Radivilias</i> (1592, Vilnius). The poem celebrating commander <a href="/wiki/Miko%C5%82aj_%22the_Red%22_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82" title=\'Miko&#322;aj "the Red" Radziwi&#322;&#322;\'>Mikalojus Radvila Rudasis</a> (1512&#8211;1584) and recounts the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ula" title="Battle of Ula">famous victory</a> of Lithuanian armed forces over Moscow troops (1564).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The evolution of the old (14th&#8211;18th century) Lithuanian literature ends with <a href="/wiki/Kristijonas_Donelaitis" title="Kristijonas Donelaitis">Kristijonas Donelaitis</a>, one of the most prominent authors of the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>. Donelaitis\' poem <i>Metai</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Seasons_(poem)" title="The Seasons (poem)">The Seasons</a></i>) is a landmark of the Lithuanian fiction literature, written in <a href="/wiki/Hexameter" title="Hexameter">hexameter</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INST_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-INST-388">[388]</a></sup>\n</p><p>With a mix of <a href="/wiki/Classicism" title="Classicism">Classicism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sentimentalism_(literature)" title="Sentimentalism (literature)">Sentimentalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a>, the Lithuanian literature of the first half of the 19th century is represented by <a href="/wiki/Maironis" title="Maironis">Maironis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Baranauskas" title="Antanas Baranauskas">Antanas Baranauskas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simonas_Daukantas" title="Simonas Daukantas">Simonas Daukantas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Simonas_Stanevi%C4%8Dius" title="Simonas Stanevi&#269;ius">Simonas Stanevi&#269;ius</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INST_388-1"><a href="#cite_note-INST-388">[388]</a></sup> During the Tsarist annexation of Lithuania in the 19th century, the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_press_ban" title="Lithuanian press ban">Lithuanian press ban</a> was implemented, which led to the formation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knygne%C5%A1iai" title="Knygne&#353;iai">Knygne&#353;iai</a> (Book smugglers) movement. This movement is thought to be the very reason the Lithuanian language and literature survived until today.\n</p><p>20th-century Lithuanian literature is represented by <a href="/wiki/Juozas_Tumas-Vai%C5%BEgantas" title="Juozas Tumas-Vai&#382;gantas">Juozas Tumas-Vai&#382;gantas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Vienuolis" title="Antanas Vienuolis">Antanas Vienuolis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bernardas_Brazd%C5%BEionis" title="Bernardas Brazd&#382;ionis">Bernardas Brazd&#382;ionis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antanas_%C5%A0k%C4%97ma" title="Antanas &#352;k&#279;ma">Antanas &#352;k&#279;ma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balys_Sruoga" title="Balys Sruoga">Balys Sruoga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Ma%C4%8Dernis" title="Vytautas Ma&#269;ernis">Vytautas Ma&#269;ernis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Justinas_Marcinkevi%C4%8Dius" title="Justinas Marcinkevi&#269;ius">Justinas Marcinkevi&#269;ius</a>.\n</p><p>In 21st-century debuted <a href="/wiki/Kristina_Sabaliauskait%C4%97" title="Kristina Sabaliauskait&#279;">Kristina Sabaliauskait&#279;</a>, Renata &#352;erelyt&#279;, Valdas Papievis, <a href="/wiki/Laura_Sintija_%C4%8Cerniauskait%C4%97" title="Laura Sintija &#268;erniauskait&#279;">Laura Sintija &#268;erniauskait&#279;</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ruta_Sepetys" title="Ruta Sepetys">R&#363;ta &#352;epetys</a>.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Architecture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wilno_Katedra.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="345" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Wilno_Katedra.jpg/180px-Wilno_Katedra.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Wilno_Katedra.jpg/270px-Wilno_Katedra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Wilno_Katedra.jpg/360px-Wilno_Katedra.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wilno_Katedra.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Cathedral" title="Vilnius Cathedral">Vilnius Cathedral</a> by <a href="/wiki/Laurynas_Gucevi%C4%8Dius" title="Laurynas Gucevi&#269;ius">Laurynas Gucevi&#269;ius</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_architects_from_Lithuania" title="List of architects from Lithuania">famous Lithuania-related architects</a> are notable for their achievements in the field of architecture. <a href="/wiki/Johann_Christoph_Glaubitz" title="Johann Christoph Glaubitz">Johann Christoph Glaubitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marcin_Knackfus" title="Marcin Knackfus">Marcin Knackfus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laurynas_Gucevi%C4%8Dius" title="Laurynas Gucevi&#269;ius">Laurynas Gucevi&#269;ius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karol_Podczaszy%C5%84ski" title="Karol Podczaszy&#324;ski">Karol Podczaszy&#324;ski</a> were instrumental in introducing <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">Baroque</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">neoclassical</a> architectural movements to the Lithuanian architecture during the seventeenth to nineteenth centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> is considered as a capital of the Eastern Europe Baroque.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Old_Town" title="Vilnius Old Town">Vilnius Old Town</a> that is full of astonishing Baroque churches and other buildings is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Grycia,_2007-04-21.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1102" data-file-width="1469" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Grycia%2C_2007-04-21.jpg/220px-Grycia%2C_2007-04-21.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Grycia%2C_2007-04-21.jpg/330px-Grycia%2C_2007-04-21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Grycia%2C_2007-04-21.jpg/440px-Grycia%2C_2007-04-21.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Grycia,_2007-04-21.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Gry&#269;ia</i> (traditional dwelling house, built in the 19th century)</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania is also known for <a href="/wiki/List_of_castles_in_Lithuania" title="List of castles in Lithuania">numerous castles</a>. About twenty castles exist in Lithuania. Some castles had to be rebuilt or survive partially. Many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_noble" title="Lithuanian noble">Lithuanian nobles</a>\' historic <a href="/wiki/List_of_palaces_and_manor_houses_in_Lithuania" title="List of palaces and manor houses in Lithuania">palaces and manor houses</a> have remained till the nowadays and were reconstructed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup> Lithuanian village life has existed since the days of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great" title="Vytautas the Great">Vytautas the Great</a>. <a href="/wiki/Zervynos" title="Zervynos">Zervynos</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kapini%C5%A1k%C4%97s" title="Kapini&#353;k&#279;s">Kapini&#353;k&#279;s</a> are two of many <a href="/wiki/Ethnographic_village" title="Ethnographic village">ethnographic villages</a> in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rum%C5%A1i%C5%A1k%C4%97s" title="Rum&#353;i&#353;k&#279;s">Rum&#353;i&#353;k&#279;s</a> is an open space museum where old ethnographic architecture is preserved.\n</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">interwar period</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a>, Lithuanian National Romanticism architectural style buildings were constructed in the Lithuania\'s temporary capital <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a>. Its architecture is regarded as one of the finest examples of the European Art Deco and has received the <a href="/wiki/European_Heritage_Label" title="European Heritage Label">European Heritage Label</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_museums">Arts and museums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Arts and museums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Lithuania" title="List of museums in Lithuania">List of museums in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_(FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS)_-_1909.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2167" data-file-width="2309" decoding="async" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_%28FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS%29_-_1909.jpg/220px-Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_%28FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS%29_-_1909.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_%28FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS%29_-_1909.jpg/330px-Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_%28FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS%29_-_1909.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_%28FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS%29_-_1909.jpg/440px-Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_%28FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS%29_-_1909.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mikalojus_Konstantinas_Ciurlionis_-_FAIRY_TALE_(FAIRY_TALE_OF_KINGS)_-_1909.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Kings\' Fairy Tale</i> (1908&#8211;1909) by <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis">Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis</a></div></div></div>\n<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pranci%C5%A1kus_Smuglevi%C4%8Dius" title="Pranci&#353;kus Smuglevi&#269;ius">Pranci&#353;kus Smuglevi&#269;ius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jan_Rustem" title="Jan Rustem">Jan Rustem</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Juozapas_Ole%C5%A1kevi%C4%8Dius" title="Juozapas Ole&#353;kevi&#269;ius">Juozapas Ole&#353;kevi&#269;ius</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kanutas_Ruseckas" title="Kanutas Ruseckas">Kanutas Ruseckas</a> are the most prominent Lithuanian painters of the 18th and 19th centuries.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Art_Museum" title="Lithuanian Art Museum">Lithuanian Art Museum</a> was founded in 1933 and is the largest museum of art conservation and display in Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup> Among other important museums are the <a href="/wiki/Palanga_Amber_Museum" title="Palanga Amber Museum">Palanga Amber Museum</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Amber" title="Amber">amber</a> pieces comprise a major part of the collection, National Gallery of Art, presenting collection of Lithuanian art of the 20th and 21st Century, <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Lithuania" title="National Museum of Lithuania">National Museum of Lithuania</a> presenting Lithuanian archaeology, history and ethnic culture. In 2018 two private museums were opened - <a href="/wiki/MO_Museum" title="MO Museum">MO Museum</a> devoted to modern and contemporary Lithuanian art and <i>Tartle</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> exhibiting a collection of Lithuanian art heritage and artefacts.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jonas_Mekas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="533" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Jonas_Mekas.jpg/150px-Jonas_Mekas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Jonas_Mekas.jpg/225px-Jonas_Mekas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Jonas_Mekas.jpg/300px-Jonas_Mekas.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jonas_Mekas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jonas_Mekas" title="Jonas Mekas">Jonas Mekas</a> is regarded as godfather of American <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avant-garde_cinema" title="Avant-garde cinema">avant-garde cinema</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Perhaps the most renowned figure in Lithuania\'s art community was the composer <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis">Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis</a> (1875&#8211;1911), an internationally renowned musician. The <a href="/wiki/2420_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="2420 &#268;iurlionis">2420 &#268;iurlionis</a> <a href="/wiki/Asteroid" title="Asteroid">asteroid</a>, identified in 1975, honors his achievements. The <a href="/wiki/M._K._%C4%8Ciurlionis_National_Art_Museum" title="M. K. &#268;iurlionis National Art Museum">M. K. &#268;iurlionis National Art Museum</a>, as well as the only military museum in Lithuania, <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great_War_Museum" title="Vytautas the Great War Museum">Vytautas the Great War Museum</a>, are located in Kaunas.\n</p><p>Other notable artists includes <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Mekas" title="Jonas Mekas">Jonas Mekas</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Maciunas" title="George Maciunas">Jurgis Ma&#269;i&#363;nas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petras_Kalpokas" title="Petras Kalpokas">Petras Kalpokas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antanas_%C5%BDmuidzinavi%C4%8Dius" title="Antanas &#381;muidzinavi&#269;ius">Antanas &#381;muidzinavi&#269;ius</a>, Jonas &#352;ileika, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Justinas_Vieno%C5%BEinskis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Justinas Vieno&#382;inskis (page does not exist)">Justinas Vieno&#382;inskis</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justinas_Vieno%C5%BEinskis" title="lt:Justinas Vieno&#382;inskis">lt</a>]</span>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Kajetonas_Skl%C4%97rius&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Kajetonas Skl&#279;rius (page does not exist)">Kajetonas Skl&#279;rius</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kajetonas_Skl%C4%97rius" title="lt:Kajetonas Skl&#279;rius">lt</a>]</span>, <a href="/wiki/Adomas_Varnas" title="Adomas Varnas">Adomas Varnas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petras_Rim%C5%A1a" title="Petras Rim&#353;a">Petras Rim&#353;a</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juozas_Zikaras" title="Juozas Zikaras">Juozas Zikaras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Kairi%C5%ABk%C5%A1tis" title="Vytautas Kairi&#363;k&#353;tis">Vytautas Kairi&#363;k&#353;tis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vincas_Grybas" title="Vincas Grybas">Vincas Grybas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stasys_U%C5%A1inskas" title="Stasys U&#353;inskas">Stasys U&#353;inskas</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bronius_Pundzius&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bronius Pundzius (page does not exist)">Bronius Pundzius</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bronius_Pundzius" title="lt:Bronius Pundzius">lt</a>]</span>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Liudas_Truikys&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Liudas Truikys (page does not exist)">Liudas Truikys</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liudas_Truikys" title="lt:Liudas Truikys">lt</a>]</span>, Robertas Antinis, Antanas Gudaitis, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Antanas_Samuolis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Antanas Samuolis (page does not exist)">Antanas Samuolis</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antanas_Samuolis" title="lt:Antanas Samuolis">lt</a>]</span>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jonas_Mik%C4%97nas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jonas Mik&#279;nas (page does not exist)">Jonas Mik&#279;nas</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Mik%C4%97nas" title="lt:Jonas Mik&#279;nas">lt</a>]</span>, Antanas &#381;ukauskas, Viktoras Vizgirda, <a href="/wiki/Rimantas_Dichavi%C4%8Dius" title="Rimantas Dichavi&#269;ius">Rimantas Dichavi&#269;ius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elvyra_Katalina_Kriau%C4%8Di%C5%ABnait%C4%97" title="Elvyra Katalina Kriau&#269;i&#363;nait&#279;">Elvyra Katalina Kriau&#269;i&#363;nait&#279;</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ar%C5%ABnas_Sauka" title="&#352;ar&#363;nas Sauka">&#352;ar&#363;nas Sauka</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Juozas_Statkevi%C4%8Dius&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Juozas Statkevi&#269;ius (page does not exist)">Juozas Statkevi&#269;ius</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juozas_Statkevi%C4%8Dius" title="lt:Juozas Statkevi&#269;ius">lt</a>]</span>.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre">Theatre</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Theatre">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre,_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1839" data-file-width="2894" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre%2C_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg/220px-Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre%2C_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre%2C_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg/330px-Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre%2C_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre%2C_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg/440px-Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre%2C_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre,_photo_by_Dmitrij_Matvejev..jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre" title="Lithuanian National Drama Theatre">Lithuanian National Drama Theatre</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania has some very famous theatre directors well known in the country and abroad. One of them is <a href="/wiki/Oskaras_Kor%C5%A1unovas" title="Oskaras Kor&#353;unovas">Oskaras Kor&#353;unovas</a>. He was awarded more than forty times with special prizes. Possibly most prestigious award is Swedish Commander Grand Cross: <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Polar_Star" title="Order of the Polar Star">Order of the Polar Star</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup> Today\'s the most famous theatres in Lithuania are in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaip&#279;da">Klaip&#279;da</a> and <a href="/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys" title="Panev&#279;&#382;ys">Panev&#279;&#382;ys</a>. It is <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre" title="Lithuanian National Drama Theatre">Lithuanian National Drama Theatre</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Keistuoli%C5%B3_Teatras" title="Keistuoli&#371; Teatras">Keistuoli&#371; teatras</a></i> (Theatre of Freaks) in Vilnius, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kaunas_National_Drama_Theatre" title="Kaunas National Drama Theatre">Kaunas National Drama Theatre</a>, Theatre of Oskaras Kor&#353;unovas, Klaip&#279;da Drama Theatre, Theatre of Gytis Ivanauskas, Miltinis Drama Theatre in Panev&#279;&#382;ys, The Doll\'s Theatre, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Drama_Theatre_of_Lithuania" title="Russian Drama Theatre of Lithuania">Russian Drama Theatre</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup> There are some very popular theatre festivals like <i>Sirenos</i> (Sirens), <i>TheATRIUM</i>, <i>Nerk &#303; teatr&#261;</i> (Dive into the Theatre) and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup> The figures dominating in Lithuanian theatre world are directors like <a href="/wiki/Eimuntas_Nekro%C5%A1ius" title="Eimuntas Nekro&#353;ius">Eimuntas Nekro&#353;ius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Vaitkus" title="Jonas Vaitkus">Jonas Vaitkus</a>, Cezaris Grau&#382;inis, Gintaras Varnas, <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Ibelhauptait%C4%97" title="Dalia Ibelhauptait&#279;">Dalia Ibelhauptait&#279;</a>, Art&#363;ras Areima; number of talented actors like Dainius Gavenonis, Rolandas Kazlas, Saulius Balandis, Gabija Jaraminait&#279; and many others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Cinema">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Lithuania" title="Cinema of Lithuania">Cinema of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kinas_Romuva.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3888" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Kinas_Romuva.JPG/220px-Kinas_Romuva.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Kinas_Romuva.JPG/330px-Kinas_Romuva.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Kinas_Romuva.JPG/440px-Kinas_Romuva.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kinas_Romuva.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Romuva_Cinema" title="Romuva Cinema">Romuva Cinema</a>, the oldest still operational <a href="/wiki/Movie_theater" title="Movie theater">movie theater</a> in Lithuania</div></div></div>\n<p>On 28 July 1896, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Edison" title="Thomas Edison">Thomas Edison</a> live photography session was held in the Concerts Hall of the <a href="/wiki/Botanical_Garden_of_Vilnius_University" title="Botanical Garden of Vilnius University">Botanical Garden of Vilnius University</a>. After a year, similar American movies were available with the addition of special <a href="/wiki/Phonograph_record" title="Phonograph record">phonograph records</a> that also provided sound. In 1909, Lithuanian cinema pioneers <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Antanas_Ra%C4%8Di%C5%ABnas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Antanas Ra&#269;i&#363;nas (page does not exist)">Antanas Ra&#269;i&#363;nas</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antanas_Ra%C4%8Di%C5%ABnas" title="lt:Antanas Ra&#269;i&#363;nas">lt</a>]</span> and <a href="/wiki/Ladislas_Starevich" title="Ladislas Starevich">Ladislas Starevich</a> released their first movies. Soon the Ra&#269;i&#363;nas\' recordings of Lithuania\'s views became very popular among the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Americans" title="Lithuanian Americans">Lithuanian Americans</a> abroad. In 1925, Pranas Valuskis filmed movie <i>Naktis Lietuvoje</i> (Night in Lithuania) about <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_book_smugglers" title="Lithuanian book smugglers">Lithuanian book smugglers</a> that left the first bright Lithuanian footprint in <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>. The most significant and mature Lithuanian American movie of the time <i>Aukso &#382;&#261;sis</i> (Golden goose) was created in 1965 by <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Birut%C4%97_P%C5%ABkelevi%C4%8Di%C5%ABt%C4%97&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Birut&#279; P&#363;kelevi&#269;i&#363;t&#279; (page does not exist)">Birut&#279; P&#363;kelevi&#269;i&#363;t&#279;</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birut%C4%97_P%C5%ABkelevi%C4%8Di%C5%ABt%C4%97" title="lt:Birut&#279; P&#363;kelevi&#269;i&#363;t&#279;">lt</a>]</span> that featured motifs from the <a href="/wiki/Brothers_Grimm" title="Brothers Grimm">Brothers Grimm</a> fairy tales. In 1940, <a href="/wiki/Romuva_Cinema" title="Romuva Cinema">Romuva Cinema</a> was opened in <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> and currently is the oldest still operational movie theater in Lithuania. After the occupation of the state, movies mostly were used for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_propaganda" title="Soviet propaganda">Soviet propaganda</a> purposes, nethertheless Almantas Grikevi&#269;ius, Gytis Luk&#353;as, Henrikas &#352;ablevi&#269;ius, Ar&#363;nas &#381;ebri&#363;nas, Raimondas Vabalas were able to overcome the obstacles and create valuable films. After the restoration of the independence, <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ar%C5%ABnas_Bartas" title="&#352;ar&#363;nas Bartas">&#352;ar&#363;nas Bartas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Audrius_Stonys" title="Audrius Stonys">Audrius Stonys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ar%C5%ABnas_Matelis" title="Ar&#363;nas Matelis">Ar&#363;nas Matelis</a>, Audrius Juz&#279;nas, <a href="/wiki/Algimantas_Puipa" title="Algimantas Puipa">Algimantas Puipa</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Janina_Lapinskait%C4%97&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Janina Lapinskait&#279; (page does not exist)">Janina Lapinskait&#279;</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janina_Lapinskait%C4%97" title="lt:Janina Lapinskait&#279;">lt</a>]</span>, Dijana and her husband Kornelijus Matuzevi&#269;ius received success in international movie festivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Lithuania" title="Music of Lithuania">Music of Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_folk_music" title="Lithuanian folk music">Lithuanian folk music</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:492px;max-width:492px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:230px;max-width:230px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:171px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg/228px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg/342px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg/456px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg 2x" width="228"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:258px;max-width:258px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:171px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1698" data-file-width="2534" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/256px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/384px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/512px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg 2x" width="256"/></a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:transparent">Lithuanians dancing at <i>Skamba skamba kankliai</i> festival and singing at <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Song_Festival" title="Lithuanian Song Festival">Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vingis_Park" title="Vingis Park">Vingis Park</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuanian folk music belongs to <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">Baltic</a> music branch which is connected with <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">neolithic</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corded_ware" title="Corded ware">corded ware</a> culture. Two instrument cultures meet in the areas inhabited by Lithuanians: stringed (<a href="/wiki/Kankl%C4%97s" title="Kankl&#279;s">kankli&#371;</a>) and wind instrument cultures. Lithuanian folk music is archaic, mostly used for ritual purposes, containing elements of <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">paganism</a> faith. There are three ancient styles of singing in Lithuania connected with ethnographical regions: <a href="/wiki/Monophony" title="Monophony">monophony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heterophony" title="Heterophony">heterophony</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polyphony" title="Polyphony">polyphony</a>. Folk song genres: Sutartin&#279;s (Multipart Songs),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup> Wedding Songs, War-Historical Time Songs, Calendar Cycle and Ritual Songs and Work Songs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1621" data-file-width="1135" decoding="async" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg/150px-Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg/225px-Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg/300px-Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis_photo_portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Painter and composer <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis">M.K. &#268;iurlionis</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Italian artists organized the first <a href="/wiki/Opera" title="Opera">opera</a> in Lithuania on 4 September 1636 in the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania" title="Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania">Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania</a> by <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_IV_Vasa" title="W&#322;adys&#322;aw IV Vasa">W&#322;adys&#322;aw IV Vasa</a> order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis">Mikalojus Konstantinas &#268;iurlionis</a> is the most renowned Lithuanian painter and composer. During his short life he created about 200 pieces of music. His works have had profound influence on modern Lithuanian culture. His <a href="/wiki/Symphonic_poem" title="Symphonic poem">symphonic poems</a> <i>In the Forest</i> (<i>Mi&#353;ke</i>) and <i>The Sea</i> (<i>J&#363;ra</i>) were performed only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Posthumous_work" title="Posthumous work">posthumously</a>. &#268;iurlionis contributed to symbolism and art nouveau and was representative of the fin de si&#232;cle epoch. He has been considered one of the pioneers of abstract art in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO,_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="894" data-file-width="1114" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO%2C_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg/220px-Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO%2C_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO%2C_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg/330px-Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO%2C_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO%2C_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg/440px-Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO%2C_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mirga_Gra-inyt--Tyla_conducts_the_CBSO,_Aldeburgh_Voices_and_Aldeburgh_Music_Club_at_Aldeburgh_Festival-crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mirga Gra&#382;inyt&#279;-Tyla conducting the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Birmingham_Symphony_Orchestra" title="City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra">City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In Lithuania, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choral_music" title="Choral music">choral music</a> is very important. <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> is the only city with three choirs laureates (Brevis, Jauna Muzika and Chamber Choir of the Conservatoire) at the <a href="/wiki/European_Grand_Prix_for_Choral_Singing" title="European Grand Prix for Choral Singing">European Grand Prix for Choral Singing</a>. There is a long-standing tradition of the <i>Dain&#371; &#353;vent&#279;</i> (<a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Song_Festival" title="Lithuanian Song Festival">Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival</a>). The first one took place in <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> in 1924. Since 1990, the festival has been organised every four years and summons roughly 30,000 singers and folk dancers of various professional levels and age groups from across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup> In 2008, Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival together with its <a href="/wiki/Latvian_Song_and_Dance_Festival" title="Latvian Song and Dance Festival">Latvian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival" title="Estonian Song Festival">Estonian</a> versions was inscribed as <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/Masterpieces_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup> <i>Gatv&#279;s muzikos diena</i> (Street Music Day) gathers musicians of various genres annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[410]</a></sup>\nOperas are staged in <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre" title="Lithuanian National Opera and Ballet Theatre">Lithuanian National Opera and Ballet Theatre</a> and also by independent troupe <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_City_Opera" title="Vilnius City Opera">Vilnius City Opera</a>.\n</p><p>Conductor <a href="/wiki/Mirga_Gra%C5%BEinyt%C4%97-Tyla" title="Mirga Gra&#382;inyt&#279;-Tyla">Mirga Gra&#382;inyt&#279;-Tyla</a> performing on the scenes of Rome, New York and Birmingham.\n</p><p>Modern classical composers emerged in seventies &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Bronius_Kutavi%C4%8Dius" title="Bronius Kutavi&#269;ius">Bronius Kutavi&#269;ius</a>, Feliksas Bajoras, <a href="/wiki/Osvaldas_Balakauskas" title="Osvaldas Balakauskas">Osvaldas Balakauskas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Onut%C4%97_Narbutait%C4%97" title="Onut&#279; Narbutait&#279;">Onut&#279; Narbutait&#279;</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vidmantas_Bartulis" title="Vidmantas Bartulis">Vidmantas Bartulis</a> and others. Most of those composers explored archaic Lithuanian music and its harmonic combination with modern minimalism and neoromanticism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[411]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Jazz scene was active even during the years of Soviet occupation. The real breakthrough would occur in 1970&#8211;71 with the coming together of the Ganelin/Tarasov/Chekasin trio, the alleged instigators of the Vilnius Jazz School.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup> Most known annual events are <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Jazz_Festival" title="Vilnius Jazz Festival">Vilnius Jazz Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Jazz" title="Kaunas Jazz">Kaunas Jazz</a>, Bir&#353;tonas Jazz.\n<a href="/wiki/Music_Information_Centre_Lithuania" title="Music Information Centre Lithuania">Music Information Centre Lithuania</a> (MICL) collects, promotes and shares information on Lithuanian musical culture.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rock_and_protest_music">Rock and protest music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Rock and protest music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_Lithuania" title="Rock music in Lithuania">Rock music in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antis_(2008-09-07)4.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="2756" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg/220px-Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg/330px-Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg/440px-Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Antis_(2008-09-07)4.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Under a firm <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Censorship in the Soviet Union">censorship</a>, band <a href="/wiki/Antis" title="Antis">Antis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Kernagis" title="Vytautas Kernagis">Vytautas Kernagis</a> actively mocked the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> regime by using <a href="/wiki/Metaphor" title="Metaphor">metaphors</a> in their lyrics</div></div></div>\n<p>After the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1944)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1944)">Soviet reoccupation of Lithuania in 1944</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Censorship in the Soviet Union">Soviet\'s censorship</a> continued firmly controlling all artistic expressions in Lithuania, and any violations by criticizing the regime would immediately result in punishments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup> The first local rock bands started to emerge around 1965 and included <i>Kertukai</i>, <i>Aitvarai</i> and <i>Nuogi ant slenks&#269;io</i> in Kaunas, and <a href="/wiki/K%C4%99stutis_Antan%C4%97lis" title="K&#281;stutis Antan&#279;lis">K&#281;stutis Antan&#279;lis</a>, <i>Vienuoliai</i>, and <i>G&#279;li&#371; Vaikai</i> in Vilnius, among others. Unable to express their opinions directly, the Lithuanian artists began organizing patriotic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roko_Mar%C5%A1as" title="Roko Mar&#353;as">Roko Mar&#353;ai</a> and were using <a href="/wiki/Metaphor" title="Metaphor">metaphors</a> in their songs lyrics, which were easily identified for their true meanings by the locals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Postmodernist" title="Postmodernist">Postmodernist</a> <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> band <a href="/wiki/Antis" title="Antis">Antis</a> and its vocalist <a href="/wiki/Algirdas_Kau%C5%A1p%C4%97das" title="Algirdas Kau&#353;p&#279;das">Algirdas Kau&#353;p&#279;das</a> were one of the most active performers who mocked the Soviet regime by using metaphors. For example, in the song <i>Zombiai</i> (Zombies), the band indirectly sang about the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> soldiers who occupied the state and its military base in <a href="/wiki/Ukmerg%C4%97" title="Ukmerg&#279;">Ukmerg&#279;</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[417]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Kernagis" title="Vytautas Kernagis">Vytautas Kernagis</a>\' song <i>Kolorado vabalai</i> (<a href="/wiki/Colorado_potato_beetle" title="Colorado potato beetle">Colorado beetles</a>) was also a favorite due to its lyrics in which true meaning of the Colorado beetles was intended to be the Soviets decorated with the <a href="/wiki/Ribbon_of_Saint_George" title="Ribbon of Saint George">Ribbons of Saint George</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the early independence years, rock band <a href="/wiki/Foje" title="Foje">Foje</a> was particularly popular and gathered tens of thousands of spectators to the concerts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> After disbanding in 1997, Foje vocalist <a href="/wiki/Andrius_Mamontovas" title="Andrius Mamontovas">Andrius Mamontovas</a> remained one of the most prominent Lithuanian performers and an active participant in various <a href="/wiki/Charity_(practice)" title="Charity (practice)">charity</a> events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marijonas_Mikutavi%C4%8Dius" title="Marijonas Mikutavi&#269;ius">Marijonas Mikutavi&#269;ius</a> is famous for creating unofficial Lithuania sport anthem <i>Trys milijonai</i> (Three million) and official anthem of the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2011" title="EuroBasket 2011">EuroBasket 2011</a> <i>Nebetyli sirgaliai</i> (English version was named <i>Celebrate Basketball</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Cuisine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_cuisine" title="Lithuanian cuisine">Lithuanian cuisine</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Juoda_duona.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2071" data-file-width="3247" decoding="async" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Juoda_duona.JPG/180px-Juoda_duona.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Juoda_duona.JPG/270px-Juoda_duona.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Juoda_duona.JPG/360px-Juoda_duona.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal"
