href="/wiki/File:Juoda_duona.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuanian dark rye bread</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG/180px-Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG/270px-Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG/360px-Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Karm%C4%97lavos_Cepelinas.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Cepelinai" title="Cepelinai">Cepelinai</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potato</a>-based dumpling dish characteristic of <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_cuisine" title="Lithuanian cuisine">Lithuanian cuisine</a> with meat, <a href="/wiki/Curd" title="Curd">curd</a> or mushrooms</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuanian cuisine features the products suited to the cool and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" title="Maritime climate">moist</a> <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">northern climate</a> of Lithuania: <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beet" title="Beet">beets</a>, greens, berries, and <a href="/wiki/Mushroom" title="Mushroom">mushrooms</a> are locally grown, and dairy products are one of its specialties. <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">Fish</a> dishes are very popular in the coastal region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup> Since it shares its climate and agricultural practices with Northern Europe, Lithuanian cuisine has some similarities to <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Scandinavian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Scandinavian cuisine (page does not exist)">Scandinavian cuisine</a>. Nevertheless, it has its own distinguishing features, which were formed by a variety of influences during the country\'s long and difficult history.\nDairy products are an important part of traditional Lithuanian cuisine. These include white cottage cheese (<i>var&#353;k&#279;s s&#363;ris</i>), curd (<i>var&#353;k&#279;</i>), soured milk (<i>r&#363;gpienis</i>), sour cream (<i>grietin&#279;</i>), butter (<i>sviestas</i>), and sour cream butter <i>kastinis</i>. Traditional meat products are usually seasoned, matured and smoked &#8211; smoked sausages (<i>de&#353;ros</i>), lard (<i>la&#353;iniai</i>), <i><a href="/wiki/Skilandis" title="Skilandis">skilandis</a></i>, smoked ham (<i>kumpis</i>). Soups (<i>sriubos</i>) &#8211; boletus soup, cabbage soup, beer soup, milk soup and various kinds of porages (<i>ko&#353;&#279;s</i>) are part of tradition and daily diet. Freshwater fish, herring, wild berries and mushrooms, honey are highly popular diet to this day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup>\n</p><p>One of the oldest and most fundamental Lithuanian food products was and is rye bread. Rye bread is eaten every day for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Bread played an important role in family rituals and agrarian ceremonies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_(9834933134).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_%289834933134%29.jpg/140px-Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_%289834933134%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_%289834933134%29.jpg/210px-Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_%289834933134%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_%289834933134%29.jpg/280px-Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_%289834933134%29.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bir%C5%BE%C5%B3_1686_Jubiliejinis_Alus_(9834933134).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lithuania has longlasting beer brewing traditions</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuanians and other nations that once formed part of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a> share many dishes and beverages. <a href="/wiki/German_cuisine" title="German cuisine">German traditions</a> also influenced Lithuanian cuisine, introducing pork and potato dishes, such as potato pudding (<i>kugelis</i> or kugel) and <a href="/wiki/Kishka_(food)" title="Kishka (food)">potato sausages</a> (<i>v&#279;darai</i>), as well as the baroque tree cake known as <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%A0akotis" title="&#352;akotis">&#352;akotis</a></i>. The most exotic of all the influences is Eastern (Karaite) cuisine &#8211; the <i><a href="/wiki/Kibinai" title="Kibinai">kibinai</a></i> are popular in Lithuania. Lithuanian noblemen usually hired French chefs, so <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">French cuisine</a> influence came to Lithuania in this way .<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Balts</a> were using <a href="/wiki/Mead" title="Mead">mead</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Midus" title="Midus">midus</a></i>) for thousands of years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup> Beer (<i>alus</i>) is the most common alcoholic beverage. Lithuania has a long farmhouse <a href="/wiki/Beer_in_Lithuania" title="Beer in Lithuania">beer tradition</a>, first mentioned in 11th century chronicles. Beer was brewed for ancient Baltic <a href="/wiki/Festival" title="Festival">festivities</a> and rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> Farmhouse brewing survived to a greater extent in Lithuania than anywhere else, and through accidents of history the Lithuanians then developed a commercial brewing culture from their unique farmhouse traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup> Lithuania is top 5 by consumption of beer per capita in Europe in 2015, counting 75 active breweries, 32 of them are microbreweries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup> The microbrewery scene in Lithuania has been growing in later years, with a number of bars focusing on these beers popping up in Vilnius and also in other parts of the country.\n</p><p>8 Lithuanian restaurants are listed in White Guide Baltic Top 30.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Media">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1936" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG/180px-Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG/270px-Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG/360px-Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Editorial_office_of_Lietuvos_rytas.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Editorial office of the best-selling Lithuanian daily newspaper <a href="/wiki/Lietuvos_rytas" title="Lietuvos rytas">Lietuvos rytas</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">Constitution of Lithuania</a> provides for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">press</a>, and the government generally respects these rights in practice. An independent press, an effective judiciary, and a functioning democratic political system combine to promote these freedoms. However, the constitutional definition of freedom of expression does not protect certain acts, such as incitement to national, racial, religious, or social hatred, violence and discrimination, or slander, and disinformation. It is a crime to deny or "grossly trivialize" Soviet or Nazi German crimes against Lithuania or its citizens, or to deny genocide, <a href="/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity" title="Crimes against humanity">crimes against humanity</a>, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_crimes" title="War crimes">war crimes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Best-selling daily national newspapers in Lithuania are <i><a href="/wiki/Lietuvos_rytas" title="Lietuvos rytas">Lietuvos rytas</a></i> (about 18,8% of all daily readers), <i><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Vakaro_%C5%BEinios&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Vakaro &#382;inios (page does not exist)">Vakaro &#382;inios</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vakaro_%C5%BEinios" title="lt:Vakaro &#382;inios">lt</a>]</span></i> (12,5%), <i><a href="/wiki/Kauno_diena" title="Kauno diena">Kauno diena</a></i> (3,7%), <i><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=%C5%A0iauli%C5%B3_kra%C5%A1tas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="&#352;iauli&#371; kra&#353;tas (page does not exist)">&#352;iauli&#371; kra&#353;tas</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%A0iauli%C5%B3_kra%C5%A1tas" title="lt:&#352;iauli&#371; kra&#353;tas">lt</a>]</span></i> (3,2%) and <i><a href="/wiki/Vakar%C5%B3_ekspresas" title="Vakar&#371; ekspresas">Vakar&#371; ekspresas</a></i> (2,7%). Best-selling weekly newspapers are <i>Savait&#279;</i> (about 34% of all weekly readers), <i>&#381;mon&#279;s</i> (17%), <i>Prie kavos</i> (11,9%), <i>Ji</i> (8,7%) and <i>Ekspress nedelia</i> (5,4%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In July 2018, the most popular national <a href="/wiki/Television_channel" title="Television channel">television channels</a> in Lithuania were <a href="/wiki/TV3_Lithuania" title="TV3 Lithuania">TV3</a> (about 35,9% of the auditorium), <a href="/wiki/LNK_(television_station)" title="LNK (television station)">LNK</a> (32,8%), <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Radio_and_Television" title="Lithuanian National Radio and Television">Lithuanian National Radio and Television</a> (30,6%), <a href="/wiki/BTV_(Lithuania)" title="BTV (Lithuania)">BTV</a> (19,9%), <a href="/wiki/Lietuvos_rytas_TV" title="Lietuvos rytas TV">Lietuvos rytas TV</a> (19,1%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The most popular <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radio_station" title="Radio station">radio stations</a> in Lithuania are <a href="/wiki/M-1_(Lithuanian_radio_station)" title="M-1 (Lithuanian radio station)">M-1</a> (about 15,8% of all listeners), <i>Lietus</i> (12,2%), <i>LRT Radijas</i> (10,5%) and <i>Radiocentras</i> (10,5%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_holidays_and_festivals">Public holidays and festivals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Public holidays and festivals">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Lithuania" title="Public holidays in Lithuania">Public holidays in Lithuania</a></div>\n<p>As a result of a thousand-years history, Lithuania has two <a href="/wiki/National_day" title="National day">National days</a>. First one is the <a href="/wiki/Statehood_Day_(Lithuania)" title="Statehood Day (Lithuania)">Statehood Day</a> on 6 July, marking the establishment of the medieval <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lithuania" title="Kingdom of Lithuania">Kingdom of Lithuania</a> by <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">Mindaugas</a> in 1253. Creation of modern Lithuanian state is commemorated on 16 February as a <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">Lithuanian State Reestablishment Day</a> on which declaration of independence from Russia and Germany was declared in 1918. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jonin%C4%97s" title="Jonin&#279;s">Jonin&#279;s</a> (previously known as <i>Rasos</i>) is a public holiday with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pagan" title="Pagan">paganic</a> roots that celebrates a <a href="/wiki/Solstice" title="Solstice">solstice</a>. As of 2018, there are 13 public holidays (which come with a day off).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[438]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kaziuko_mug%C4%97" title="Kaziuko mug&#279;">Kaziuko mug&#279;</a> is an annual <a href="/wiki/Fair" title="Fair">fair</a> held since the beginning of the 17th century that commemorates the anniversary of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Casimir" title="Saint Casimir">Saint Casimir\'s</a> death and gathers thousands of visitors and many craftsmen. Other notable festivals are <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_International_Film_Festival" title="Vilnius International Film Festival">Vilnius International Film Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kauno_Miesto_Diena" title="Kauno Miesto Diena">Kauno Miesto Diena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Sea_Festival" title="Klaip&#279;da Sea Festival">Klaip&#279;da Sea Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mados_infekcija" title="Mados infekcija">Mados infekcija</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Book_Fair" title="Vilnius Book Fair">Vilnius Book Fair</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Marathon" title="Vilnius Marathon">Vilnius Marathon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Devilstone_Open_Air" title="Devilstone Open Air">Devilstone Open Air</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Apuol%C4%97_854&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Apuol&#279; 854 (page does not exist)">Apuol&#279; 854</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;[<a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apuol%C4%97_854" title="lt:Apuol&#279; 854">lt</a>]</span>, <a href="/wiki/Great_%C5%BDemai%C4%8Di%C5%B3_Kalvarija_Festival" title="Great &#381;emai&#269;i&#371; Kalvarija Festival">Great &#381;emai&#269;i&#371; Kalvarija Festival</a>.\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%">\n<tbody><tr style="font-size:100%; text-align:left">\n<th style="width: 17em"><a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Lithuania" title="Public holidays in Lithuania">Public holidays in Lithuania</a>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Date</th>\n<th>English name</th>\n<th>Local name</th>\n<th>Remarks\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>January 1</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day" title="New Year\'s Day">New Year\'s Day</a></td>\n<td>Naujieji metai</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>February 16</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">the Day of Restoration of the State of Lithuania (1918)</a></td>\n<td>Lietuvos valstyb&#279;s atk&#363;rimo diena</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>March 11</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">Day of Restoration of Independence of Lithuania</a> (from the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, 1990)</td>\n<td>Lietuvos nepriklausomyb&#279;s atk&#363;rimo diena</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>The first Sunday after the full moon that occurs on or soonest after 21 March and following Monday</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a></td>\n<td>Velykos</td>\n<td>Commemorates resurrection of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>May 1</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers\' Day">International Workers\' Day</a></td>\n<td>Tarptautin&#279; darbo diena\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>First Sunday in May</td>\n<td>Mother\'s Day</td>\n<td>Motinos diena</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>First Sunday in June</td>\n<td>Father\'s Day</td>\n<td>T&#279;vo diena</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>June 24</td>\n<td>St. John\'s Day [Christian name], Day of Dew [original pagan name]</td>\n<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jonin%C4%97s" title="Jonin&#279;s">Jonin&#279;s</a>, Rasos</td>\n<td>Celebrated according to mostly pagan traditions. (aka: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Midsummer_Day" title="Midsummer Day">Midsummer Day</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Jonas_Day" title="Saint Jonas Day">Saint Jonas Day</a>)\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>July 6</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Statehood_Day_(Lithuania)" title="Statehood Day (Lithuania)">Statehood Day</a></td>\n<td>Valstyb&#279;s (Lietuvos karaliaus Mindaugo kar&#363;navimo) diena</td>\n<td>Commemorates coronation of the first king, <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">Mindaugas</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>August 15</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">Assumption Day</a></td>\n<td>&#381;olin&#279; (&#352;v&#269;. Mergel&#279;s Marijos &#279;mimo &#303; dang&#371; diena)</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>November 1</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/All_Saints%27_Day" title="All Saints\' Day">All Saints\' Day</a></td>\n<td>Vis&#371; &#353;vent&#371;j&#371; diena (V&#279;lin&#279;s)</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>December 24</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Christmas_Eve" title="Christmas Eve">Christmas Eve</a></td>\n<td>&#352;v. K&#363;&#269;ios</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>December 25 and 26</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a></td>\n<td>&#352;v. Kal&#279;dos</td>\n<td>Commemorates birth of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>\n</td></tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Sports">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Lithuania" title="Sport in Lithuania">Sport in Lithuania</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="382" decoding="async" height="258" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg/170px-R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg/255px-R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg/340px-R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97" title="R&#363;ta Meilutyt&#279;">R&#363;ta Meilutyt&#279;</a> &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Swimming_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Swimming at the Summer Olympics">Olympic</a>, multiple <a href="/wiki/FINA_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="FINA World Aquatics Championships">World</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Short_Course_Swimming_Championships" title="European Short Course Swimming Championships">European</a> champion.</div></div></div>\n<p>Basketball is the most popular and <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a> of Lithuania. The <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Lithuania men\'s national basketball team">Lithuania national basketball team</a> has had significant success in international basketball events, having won the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket" title="EuroBasket">EuroBasket</a> on three occasions (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_1937" title="Eurobasket 1937">1937</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_1939" title="Eurobasket 1939">1939</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_2003" title="Eurobasket 2003">2003</a>), as well a total of 8 other medals in the Eurobasket, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Championship" title="FIBA World Championship">World Championships</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the Summer Olympics">Olympic Games</a>. The men\'s national team also has extremely high TV ratings as about 76% of the country\'s population watched their games live in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> Lithuania hosted the Eurobasket in 1939 and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_2011" title="Eurobasket 2011">2011</a>. The historic Lithuanian basketball team <a href="/wiki/BC_%C5%BDalgiris" title="BC &#381;algiris">BC &#381;algiris</a>, from Kaunas, won the European basketball league <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euroleague" title="Euroleague">Euroleague</a> in 1999. Lithuania has produced a number of <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">NBA</a> players, including <a href="/wiki/Naismith_Memorial_Basketball_Hall_of_Fame" title="Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame">Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame</a> inductees <a href="/wiki/Arvydas_Sabonis" title="Arvydas Sabonis">Arvydas Sabonis</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ar%C5%ABnas_Mar%C4%8Diulionis" title="&#352;ar&#363;nas Mar&#269;iulionis">&#352;ar&#363;nas Mar&#269;iulionis</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup> and current NBA players <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Valan%C4%8Di%C5%ABnas" title="Jonas Valan&#269;i&#363;nas">Jonas Valan&#269;i&#363;nas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Domantas_Sabonis" title="Domantas Sabonis">Domantas Sabonis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3214" data-file-width="4478" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg/220px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg/330px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg/440px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lithuania_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Lithuania men\'s national basketball team">Lithuania men\'s national basketball team</a> is ranked 6th worldwide in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_Rankings" title="FIBA Rankings">FIBA Rankings</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania has won a total of <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_at_the_Olympics" title="Lithuania at the Olympics">25 medals at the Olympic Games</a>, including 6 gold medals in <a href="/wiki/Sport_of_athletics" title="Sport of athletics">athletics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Modern_pentathlon" title="Modern pentathlon">modern pentathlon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shooting_sport" title="Shooting sport">shooting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">swimming</a>. Numerous other Lithuanians won Olympic medals representing Soviet Union. <a href="/wiki/Discus_throw" title="Discus throw">Discus thrower</a> <a href="/wiki/Virgilijus_Alekna" title="Virgilijus Alekna">Virgilijus Alekna</a> is the most successful Olympic athlete of independent Lithuania, having won gold medals in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2000_Sydney_Olympics" title="2000 Sydney Olympics">2000 Sydney</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2004_Athens" title="2004 Athens">2004 Athens</a> games, as well as a bronze in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Beijing" title="2008 Beijing">2008 Beijing</a> Olympics and numerous <a href="/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="IAAF World Championships in Athletics">World Championship</a> medals. More recently, the gold medal won by a then 15-year-old swimmer <a href="/wiki/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97" title="R&#363;ta Meilutyt&#279;">R&#363;ta Meilutyt&#279;</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> in London sparked a rise in popularity for the sport in Lithuania.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Snow_Arena.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2248" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Snow_Arena.JPG/220px-Snow_Arena.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Snow_Arena.JPG/330px-Snow_Arena.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Snow_Arena.JPG/440px-Snow_Arena.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Snow_Arena.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Druskininkai <a href="/wiki/Snow_Arena" title="Snow Arena">Snow Arena</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Lithuania has produced prominent athletes in athletics, modern pentathlon, <a href="/wiki/Road_cycling" title="Road cycling">road</a> and <a href="/wiki/Track_cycling" title="Track cycling">track cycling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rowing" title="Rowing">rowing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aerobatics" title="Aerobatics">aerobatics</a>, <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Strongest_Man" title="World\'s Strongest Man">strongman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">mixed martial arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyokushin" title="Kyokushin">Kyokushin Karate</a> and other sports.\n</p><p>Few Lithuanian athletes have found success in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_Sport" title="Winter Sport">winter sports</a>, although facilities are provided by several ice rinks and skiing slopes, including <a href="/wiki/Snow_Arena" title="Snow Arena">Snow Arena</a>, the first indoor ski slope in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltics" title="Baltics">Baltics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup> In 2018 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuania_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Lithuania national ice hockey team">Lithuania national ice hockey team</a> won gold medals at the <a href="/wiki/2018_IIHF_World_Championship_Division_I" title="2018 IIHF World Championship Division I">2018 IIHF World Championship Division I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup>\n</p><p>A Lithuanian ethnic sport, known since the 17th century is <a href="/wiki/Ritinis" title="Ritinis">ritinis</a>.\n</p><p>Lithuanians annually participates in the <a href="/wiki/Dakar_Rally" title="Dakar Rally">Dakar Rally</a>. <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Juknevi%C4%8Dius" title="Antanas Juknevi&#269;ius">Antanas Juknevi&#269;ius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Benediktas_Vanagas" title="Benediktas Vanagas">Benediktas Vanagas</a> are well known internationally.\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_rankings">International rankings</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: International rankings">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>The following are links to international rankings of Lithuania from selected research institutes and foundations including economic output and various composite indices.\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th style="width:65%;">Index\n</th>\n<th also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" role="navigation" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">\n<ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">\n<li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><img alt="flag" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="19" title="Index of Lithuania-related articles">Index of Lithuania-related articles</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Lithuanians" title="List of Lithuanians">List of Lithuanians</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Lithuania" title="Outline of Lithuania">Outline of Lithuania</a></li></ul>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<p><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_NoteA"><b><a href="#ref_NoteA">^</a></b></span> <small>Various sources classify Lithuania differently for statistical and other purposes. For example, United Nations<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN-457">[457]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Eurovoc" title="Eurovoc">Eurovoc</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[458]</a></sup> among others, classify it as northern Europe, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_315-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-315">[315]</a></sup> classifies it as eastern Europe, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_Britannica" title="Encyclopedia Britannica">Encyclopedia Britannica</a> locates it in northeastern Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup> Usage varies greatly, and controversially,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[460]</a></sup> in press sources.</small>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">\n<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-2011a-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-2011a_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2011a_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2011a_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://osp.stat.gov.lt/informaciniai-pranesimai?articleId=223122" rel="nofollow">"Ethnicity, mother tongue and religion"</a>. <i>Official Statistics Portal</i>. Statistics Lithuania. 15 March 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. href="#cite_ref-Lina_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Kulikauskien&#279;, Lina (2002). <i>Lietuvos Respublikos Konstitucija</i> [<i>The Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania</i>] (in Lithuanian). Native History, CD. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9986-9216-7-8" title="Special:BookSources/9986-9216-7-8">9986-9216-7-8</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Lietuvos+Respublikos+Konstitucija&amp;rft.pub=Native+History%2C+CD.&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=9986-9216-7-8&amp;rft.aulast=Kulikauskien%C4%97&amp;rft.aufirst=Lina&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Veser, Ernst (23 September 1997). <a class="external text" href="http://www.rchss.sinica.edu.tw/publication/ebook/journal/11-01-1999/11_1_2.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Semi-Presidentialism-Duverger\'s Concept &#8212; A New Political System Model"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (in English and Chinese). Department of Education, School of Education, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cologne" title="University of Cologne">University of Cologne</a>: 39&#8211;60<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 August</span> 2017</span>. <q>Duhamel has developed the approach further: He stresses that the French construction does not correspond to either parliamentary or the presidential form of government, and then develops the distinction of \'syst&#232;me politique\' and \'r&#233;gime constitutionnel\'. While the former comprises the exercise of power that results from the dominant institutional practice, the latter is the totality of the rules for the dominant institutional practice of the power. In this way, France appears as \'presidentialist system\' endowed with a \'semi-presidential regime\' (1983: 587). By this standard he recognizes Duverger\'s <i>pl&#233;iade</i> as semi-presidential regimes, as well as Poland, Romania, Bulgaria and Lithuania (1993: 87).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Semi-Presidentialism-Duverger%27s+Concept+%E2%80%94+A+New+Political+System+Model&amp;rft.pages=39-60&amp;rft.date=1997-09-23&amp;rft.aulast=Veser&amp;rft.aufirst=Ernst&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rchss.sinica.edu.tw%2Fpublication%2Febook%2Fjournal%2F11-01-1999%2F11_1_2.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Draft-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Draft_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal" id="CITEREFShugart2005"><a href="/wiki/Matthew_S%C3%B8berg_Shugart" title="Matthew S&#248;berg Shugart">Shugart, Matthew S&#248;berg</a> (September 2005). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080819200307/http://dss.ucsd.edu/~mshugart/semi-presidentialism.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Semi-Presidential Systems: Dual Executive and Mixed Authority Patterns"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies</i>. United States: University of California, San Diego. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://dss.ucsd.edu/~mshugart/semi-presidentialism.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 19 August 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 August</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Graduate+School+of+International+Relations+and+Pacific+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Semi-Presidential+Systems%3A+Dual+Executive+and+Mixed+Authority+Patterns&amp;rft.date=2005-09&amp;rft.aulast=Shugart&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew+S%C3%B8berg&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdss.ucsd.edu%2F~mshugart%2Fsemi-presidentialism.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Dual-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dual_5-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal" id="CITEREFShugart2005"><a href="/wiki/Matthew_S%C3%B8berg_Shugart" title="Matthew S&#248;berg Shugart">Shugart, Matthew S&#248;berg</a> (December 2005). <a class="external text" href="http://www.palgrave-journals.com/fp/journal/v3/n3/pdf/8200087a.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Semi-Presidential Systems: Dual Executive And Mixed Authority Patterns"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>French Politics</i>. <a href="/wiki/Palgrave_Macmillan" title="Palgrave Macmillan">Palgrave Macmillan</a> Journals. <b>3</b> (3): 323&#8211;351. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1057%2Fpalgrave.fp.8200087" rel="nofollow">10.1057/palgrave.fp.8200087</a></span><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 August</span> 2017</span>. <q>A pattern similar to the French case of compatible majorities alternating with periods of cohabitation emerged in Lithuania, where Talat-Kelpsa (2001) notes that the ability of the Lithuanian president to influence government formation and policy declined abruptly when he lost the sympathetic majority in parliament.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=French+Politics&amp;rft.atitle=Semi-Presidential+Systems%3A+Dual+Executive+And+Mixed+Authority+Patterns&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=323-351&amp;rft.date=2005-12&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1057%2Fpalgrave.fp.8200087&amp;rft.aulast=Shugart&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew+S%C3%B8berg&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.palgrave-journals.com%2Ffp%2Fjournal%2Fv3%2Fn3%2Fpdf%2F8200087a.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external free" href="https://osp.stat.gov.lt" rel="nofollow">https://osp.stat.gov.lt</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-imf2-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_7-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_7-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_7-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_7-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2018/02/weodata/weorept.aspx?pr.x=65&amp;pr.y=19&amp;sy=2018&amp;ey=2023&amp;scsm=1&amp;ssd=1&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1&amp;c=946%2C939%2C941&amp;s=NGDPD%2CPPPGDP%2CNGDPDPC%2CPPPPC&amp;grp=0&amp;a=" rel="nofollow">"Lithuania"</a>. London: Guardian Media Group. 12 March 1990<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 June</span> 2018</span>. <q>Lithuania last night became the first republic to break away from the Soviet Union, by proclaiming the restoration of its pre-war independence. The newly-elected parliament, \'reflecting the people\'s will,\' decreed the restoration of \'the sovereign rights of the Lithuanian state, infringed by alien forces in 1940,\' and declared that from that moment Lithuania was again an independent state.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Theguardian.com&amp;rft.atitle=Lithuania+breaks+away+from+the+Soviet+Union&amp;rft.date=1990-03-12&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fworld%2F1990%2Fmar%2F12%2Feu.politics&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Baranauskas, Tomas (Fall 2009). Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 November</span> 2018</span>. <q>For over two years Lithuania has been moving toward reclaiming its independence. This drive reached a crescendo on March 11, 1990, when the Supreme Soviet of Lithuania declared the republic no longer bound by Soviet law. The act reasserted the independence Lithuania had declared more than seventy years before, a declaration unilaterally annulled by the U.S.S.R. in 1940 when it annexed Lithuania as the result of a pact between Stalin and Hitler.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.foreignaffairs.com&amp;rft.atitle=The+Lithuanian+Crisis&amp;rft.date=1990&amp;rft.au=Martha+Brill+Olcott&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.foreignaffairs.com%2Farticles%2Frussian-federation%2F1990-06-01%2Flithuanian-crisis&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-101">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/10-svarbiausiu-1991-uju-sausio-ivykiu-kuriuos-privalote-zinoti-56-565845" rel="nofollow">"10 svarbiausi&#371; 1991&#8211;&#371;j&#371; sausio &#303;vyki&#371;, kuriuos privalote &#382;inoti"</a>. <i>15min.lt</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Slovenia">Slovenia</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Spain" title="Economy of Spain">Spain</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Sweden" title="Economy of Sweden">Sweden</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Economy of the United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a></li></ul>\n</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>\n</div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div>\n<ol><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of the People\'s Republic of China">Special administrative regions of the People\'s Republic of China</a>, participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".</li>\n<li>Officially the Republic of China, participates as "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu</a>", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.</li></ol>\n</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>\n<div aria-labelledby="Member_states_of_the_Council_of_the_Baltic_Sea_States" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table
